['Who is Thomas Berry and what is his role in environmental advocacy?', 'Cullinan, Berry, and others have written extensively about the important legal tenets of earth jurisprudence; however, it is not a legal doctrine officially adopted by the United States or any of its states to date.']

['What is the connection between the concept of earth justice and the economic theory of "tragedy of the commons"?', 'The concept of earth justice is tied indirectly to the economic theory of the “tragedy of the commons,” a phrase derived from British economist William Forster Lloyd, who, in the mid-nineteenth century, used a hypothetical example of unregulated grazing on common land to explain the human tendency to act independently, putting self-interest first, without regard for the common good of all users.']

['What are some examples of how the theory of the "tragedy of the commons" can be applied to environmental issues?', 'The theory was later popularized by ecologist and philosopher Garrett Hardin, who tied it directly to environmental issues.']

['What are the long-term environmental effects of individuals using natural resources without considering the needs of others?', 'In other words, when it comes to natural resources, the tragedy of the commons holds that people generally use as much of a free resource as they want, without regard for the needs of others or for the long-term environmental effects.']

['What are some of the tenets of earth justice that Cormac Cullinan and others have written about?', 'As a way of combating the tragedy of the commons, Cullinan and others have written about the concept of earth justice,24 which includes the following tenets:']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what do supporters of the environment argue the government should do in relation to businesses?', 'Today, supporters of the environment assert that government has both a right and an obligation to ensure that businesses do not overuse any resource, and to mandate adequate environmental protection when doing so.']

['What are some examples of fees that may be collected for the use of natural resources according to the passage?', 'In addition, some form of fee may be collected for using up a natural resource, such as severance taxes imposed on the removal of nonrenewable resources like oil and gas, or deposits required for possible cleanup costs after projects have been abandoned.']

['What role do nonprofit educational organizations and NGOs play in the concept of environmental justice, according to the passage?', 'As part of the growing acceptance of the concept of earth justice, several nonprofit educational organizations and NGOs have become active in both lobbying and environmental litigation.']

['What are some examples of nonprofit educational organizations and NGOs that engage in lobbying and environmental litigation, as mentioned in the passage?', 'One such organization is the Center for Earth Jurisprudence (housed at the Barry School of Law in Orlando), a nonprofit group that conducts research in this area.']
['Teacher: Can you explain why the idea of treating the environment as a person is considered relatively new?', 'The notion that the environment should be treated as a person is relatively new.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for well-managed businesses today to have an awareness of the tenuous balance between the health of the environment and corporate profits?', 'But given the prominence of the environmental movement worldwide, no well-managed business today should be conducted without an awareness of the tenuous balance between the health of the environment and corporate profits.']

["Teacher: Why is safeguarding the natural environment crucial for a business's long-term sustainability and profitability?", 'It is quite simply good business practice for executives to be aware that their enterprise’s long-term sustainability, and indeed its profitability, depend greatly on their safeguarding the natural environment.']

['Teacher: How can ignoring the interrelationship between business and the environment potentially impact companies?', 'Ignoring this interrelationship between business and the environment not only elicits public condemnation and the attention of lawmakers who listen to their constituents, but it also risks destroying the viability of the companies themselves.']
['Teacher: How does the dependence of businesses on natural resources relate to the concept of sustainability?', 'Virtually all businesses depend on natural resources in one way or another.']

['Teacher: What is the multifaceted nature of sustainability that progressive corporate managers recognize?', 'Progressive corporate managers recognize the multifaceted nature of sustainability—a long-term approach to business activity, environmental responsibility, and societal impact.']

['Teacher: How does sustainability impact stakeholders other than the environment, according to progressive corporate managers?', 'Sustainability affects not only the environment but also other stakeholders, including employees, the community, politics, law, science, and philosophy.']

['Teacher: Why is the commitment of every part of the company important for a successful sustainability program, according to the passage?', 'A successful sustainability program thus requires the commitment of every part of the company.']

['Teacher: How are engineers contributing to sustainability efforts in companies dedicated to sustainability?', 'For example, engineers are designing manufacturing and production processes to meet the demands of companies dedicated to sustainability, and the idea of company-wide sustainability is now mainstream.']

['Teacher: Why do many of the largest companies in the world view sustainability as an important part of their future survivability?', 'Many of the largest companies in the world see sustainability as an important part of their future survivability.']

['Teacher: What is the name of the Canadian research and publishing company that creates the Global 100 list?', 'Corporate Knights is a Canadian research and publishing company that compiles an annual list called the Global 100, identifying the world’s most sustainable companies.']

['Teacher: Where was the 2018 edition of the Global 100 list presented?', '27 The 2018 edition of the list, presented at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, shows that an increasing number of major multinational companies take sustainability seriously, including many U.S. businesses.']
['Teacher: Who was the highest-ranking U.S. company on the 2018 Global 100 list?', 'The highest-ranking U.S. company is technology giant Cisco, which ranks seventh on the Global 100 list.']

['Teacher: Can you name some other U.S. companies that were listed in the top twenty-five of the 2018 Global 100 list?', '28 Other U.S. companies in the top twenty-five include Autodesk, Merck, and McCormick & Co.']

['Teacher: Which country has the highest number of companies listed in the 2018 Global 100?', 'The countries with the best representation on the list are primarily from North America and Western Europe: the United States (18), France (15), the United Kingdom (10), Germany (7), Brazil (5), Finland (5), and Sweden (5).']

['Teacher: What might be a common assumption about the profitability of companies dedicated to sustainability in the long run?', 'You may expect that companies dedicated to sustainability would be less profitable in the long run as they face additional costs.']

["What does the data from the Global 100's return on investment show about the profitability of companies dedicated to sustainability in the long run?", 'In fact, data from the Global 100’s return on investment shows this is not the case.']
["Teacher: What evidence from the Global 100's return on investment supports the claim that companies dedicated to sustainability can be profitable in the long run?", 'Let’s examine the evidence.']

['What is the difference in return on investment between Global 100 companies and a typical index fund for the period of 2005 to 2015?', 'If an investor had put $250 in Global 100 companies in 2005, it would have been worth $580 in 2015, compared to $520 for the same amount invested in a typical index fund.']

["What does the Global 100's data suggest about the profitability of high-sustainability firms compared to traditional investments?", 'The Global 100’s cumulative return on high-sustainability firms is about 25 percent higher than a traditional investment.']
["What is the percentage increase in the cumulative return on high-sustainability firms compared to traditional investments according to the Global 100's data?", '29']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a company from The Global 100 list that incorporates green procurement and sustainable sourcing into its supply chain?', 'Cisco Systems, number seven on the global list, is a good example of how green procurement and sustainable sourcing have become a regular part of the supply chain.']

['Teacher: How does Cisco Systems demonstrate its commitment to green procurement and sustainable sourcing in its supply chain?', 'At Cisco, according to a top-level supply chain executive, “we take seriously the responsibility of delivering products in an ethical and environmentally responsible manner.']

['Teacher: What are some specific ways in which Cisco Systems ensures ethical and environmentally responsible practices within its supply chain?', '”30 Cisco relies on its Supplier Code of Conduct to set standards for suppliers so they follow fair labor practices, ensure safe working conditions, and reduce their carbon footprint, the amount of carbon dioxide and other carbon compounds released by the consumption of fossil fuels, which can be measured quantitatively (see the link below).']
['Teacher: How does Cisco Systems embed sustainability into supply chain management at all levels?', 'Cisco is in the process of embedding sustainability into supply chain management at all levels.']

['Teacher: Can you tell me which company achieved the ninth position on the 2018 Global 100 list of sustainability rankings?', 'Another company dedicated to sustainability is Siemens, which was ranked number nine on the 2018 list.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of the various sectors in which Siemens operates?', 'Siemens is a multinational industrial conglomerate headquartered in Germany, whose businesses range from power plants to electrical systems and equipment in the medical field and high-tech electronics.']

['Teacher: Why was Siemens rated the most energy-efficient firm in its sector?', 'Siemens was rated the most energy-efficient firm in its sector, because it produced more dollars in revenue per kilowatt used than any other industrial corporation.']

["Teacher: How does Siemens' energy efficiency contribute to its low carbon footprint?", 'This is a standard technique to judge efficiency and demonstrates that Siemens has a low carbon footprint for a company in the industries in which it operates.']

['Teacher: In what ways does Siemens demonstrate its commitment to sustainability through its product offerings?', 'The commitment of Siemens to sustainability is further demonstrated by its decision to manufacture and sell more environmentally friendly infrastructure products such as green heating and air conditioning systems.']

['Teacher: What is the key factor for a supply chain to be sustainable, according to the passage?', 'Cisco and Siemens show that businesses across the globe are starting to understand that for a supply chain to be sustainable, companies and their vendors must be partners in a clean and safe environment.']

['What is the reason behind businesses adopting sustainability as a policy, according to the passage?', 'There is abundant evidence that sustainability has become a policy adopted by businesses for financial reasons, not simply public relations.']

['Teacher: What is McKinsey & Company known for in the field of management consulting?', 'McKinsey & Company is one of the world’s largest management consulting firms and a leader in the use of data analytics, both qualitative and quantitative, to evaluate management decisions.']

['Teacher: Why is McKinsey & Company considered a leader in the field of management consulting?', 'McKinsey conducts periodic surveys of companies around the world on matters of importance to corporate leaders.']

["Teacher: What are some findings from McKinsey & Company's 2014 survey on sustainability's strategic worth?", 'In the 2010 survey, 76 percent of executives agreed that sustainability provides shareholders long-term value, and in the 2014 survey, entitled “Sustainability’s Strategic Worth,” the data indicated that many companies consider cost savings to be the number-one reason for adopting such policies.']

["Teacher: What were the primary reasons for adopting sustainability policies according to McKinsey & Company's 2014 survey on sustainability's strategic worth?", 'Cost cutting, improved operations, and efficiency were indicated as the primary reasons for adopting sustainability policies by over one-third of all companies (36%).31']
['Teacher: Can you please elaborate on what you mean by "similar results"?', 'Other major studies have demonstrated similar results.']
['Teacher: Can you provide any specific examples of these other major studies that have demonstrated similar results?', 'Grant Thornton is a leading global accounting and consulting firm.']

["Teacher: What were the findings of Grant Thornton's 2014 report on CSR in relation to companies' motives for adopting environmentally responsible practices?", 'Its 2014 report on CSR showed that the top reason companies cite for moving towards more environmentally responsible business practices is financial savings.']

["What were some of the other reasons that companies cited in Grant Thornton's report for adopting environmentally responsible practices?", 'Grant Thornton conducted more than 2,500 interviews with clients and business executives in approximately thirty-five countries to discover why companies are making a commitment to sustainable practices.']

["What percentage of companies cited cost management as the key reason for sustainability in Grant Thornton's study?", 'The study found that cost management was the key reason for sustainability (67%).32']

["Teacher: Can you provide me with a specific example of a company mentioned in the passage that demonstrates the Global 100's strategic worth in terms of sustainability?", 'A specific example is Dell Computers, headquartered outside Austin, Texas, and with operations all over the world.']

["Teacher: That's a great example! Can you also tell me what other environmental goals Dell has set in addition to reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 50 percent by 2020?", 'The “Dell Legacy of Good Plan” has set a goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from all facilities and operations by 50 percent by the year 2020, along with several other environmental goals.']

['What is one of the environmental goals set by Dell\'s "Dell Legacy of Good Plan" in addition to reducing greenhouse gas emissions?', 'As part of this overall plan, Dell created the Connected Workplace, a flex-work program allowing alternative arrangements such as variable work hours to avoid rush hour, full- or part-time work at home flexibility, and job sharing.']

['How does Dell\'s "Connected Workplace" sustainability initiative contribute to the company\'s environmental goals and financial benefit?', 'This sustainability initiative helps the company avoid about seven thousand metric tons of greenhouse gas emissions, and, directly related to the financial benefit of sustainability, it saves the company approximately $12 million per year.']
['What is the annual financial savings for Dell as a result of the "Connected Workplace" sustainability initiative?', '33']
['Teacher: What potential challenge is mentioned in the passage regarding adopting sustainability policies?', 'However, adopting sustainability policies may require a long-term outlook.']

['Teacher: How does the article in the Harvard Business Review support the notion that adopting sustainability policies may require a long-term outlook?', 'A recent article in the Harvard Business Review discussed the issue of sustainability and how it can create real cost savings.']

['Teacher: How does the Harvard Business Review article challenge the notion that sustainable production is more expensive for companies?', '“It’s hard for companies to recognize that sustainable production can be less expensive.']

['Teacher: How does the Harvard Business Review article explain the belief that initial investments in sustainable production can lead to greater savings in the future?', 'That’s in part because they have to fundamentally change the way they think about lowering costs, taking a leap of faith . . . that initial investments made in more-costly materials and methods will lead to greater savings down the road.']

['Teacher: How does the Harvard Business Review article suggest that companies can increase the efficiency of the system as a whole when adopting sustainability policies?', 'It may also require a willingness to buck conventional financial wisdom by focusing not on reducing the cost of each part but on increasing the efficiency of the system as a whole.']
['How does the Harvard Business Review article suggest that companies can effectively adopt sustainability policies while also meeting their financial goals?', '”34']

['Teacher: What is the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) and what is its role in the development of international business standards?', 'The International Organization for Standardization, or ISO, is an independent NGO and the world’s largest developer of voluntary international business standards.']

['Teacher: Can you give some examples of the areas covered by ISO standards?', 'More than twenty thousand ISO standards now cover matters such as sustainability, manufactured products, technology, food, agriculture, and even healthcare.']

['Teacher: How do ISO standards contribute to the creation of products and services that are clean, safe, reliable, and made by workers who enjoy some degree of protection from workplace hazards?', 'The adoption and use of these standards by companies is voluntary, but they are widely accepted, and following ISO certification guidelines results in the creation of products and services that are clean, safe, reliable, and made by workers who enjoy some degree of protection from workplace hazards.']

['Teacher: What is the main objective of the ISO 14000 series of standards in the environmental area?', 'In the environmental area, the ISO 14000 series of standards promotes effective environmental management systems in business organizations by providing cost-effective tools that make use of best practices for environmental management.']

['What are some examples of the areas covered by the ISO 14000 series of standards in the environmental area?', 'These standards were developed in the 1990s and updated in 2015; they cover everything from the eco-design (ISO 14006) of factories and buildings to environmental labels (ISO 14020) to limits on the release of greenhouse gasses (ISO 14064).']

['What are some potential benefits for companies that obtain ISO 14000 certification in terms of bidding on government contracts and private-sector opportunities?', 'While their adoption is still voluntary, a growing number of countries allow only ISO 14000-certified companies to bid on public government contracts, and the same is true of some private-sector companies.']

['Teacher: Can you explain another type of sustainability standard that businesses may elect to comply with?', 'Another type of sustainability standard with which businesses may elect to comply is LEED certification.']

["Teacher: How does the LEED certification evaluate a structure's environmental performance?", 'LEED stands for Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design, and it is a rating system devised by the U.S. Green Building Council to evaluate a structure’s environmental performance.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a building that has been awarded LEED certification and specify the level of certification it received?', 'The most famous example is the Empire State Building in New York City, which was awarded LEED Gold status (for existing buildings).']

['Teacher: What were some of the key efforts made during the multimillion-dollar rebuilding program of the Empire State Building to meet the requirements for LEED certification?', 'The LEED certification was the result of a multimillion-dollar rebuilding program to bring the building up to date, and the building is the tallest in the United States to receive it.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what the LEED certification signifies for a building in terms of its environmental sustainability?', 'There are dozens of other examples of large commercial buildings, such as the Wells Fargo Tower in Los Angeles, as well as thousands of smaller buildings and residential homes.']

['Teacher: How does the LEED certification contribute to market transformation towards sustainable design?', 'LEED certification is the driver behind the ongoing market transformation towards sustainable design in all types of structures, including buildings, houses, and factories.']

['Teacher: That\'s correct! Now, considering the projected increase in population, what is the potential impact of "The High Cost of Inaction" on Earth\'s resources and environment?', 'According to estimates from the EPA, by the year 2050, Earth’s population will be about ten billion people.']

['What are some reasons that explain why dramatic population growth has a negative impact on the planet?', 'Dramatic population growth has had a very significant and often negative human impact on the planet.']

['What are some examples of how the increase in population leads to a higher demand for natural resources?', 'Not only are there more people to feed, house, and care for, but new technologies allow businesses to harness natural resources in unprecedented amounts.']
['What are some potential consequences of the higher demand for natural resources caused by the increase in population?', 'NGOs and government agencies alike have taken notice.']

['What are some actions that NGOs and government agencies have taken in response to the higher demand for natural resources caused by the increase in population?', 'For years, the Department of State and the Department of Defense have considered climate change to be a potential threat to the long-term security of the United States.']

['What are some potential measures that the Department of State and the Department of Defense have taken to address the potential threat of climate change to the long-term security of the United States?', 'If unmanaged, climate change could pose a risk to both U.S. security and Department of Defense facilities and operations.']

['What are some examples of the potential measures that the Department of State and the Department of Defense have taken to address the potential threat of climate change to the long-term security of the United States?', '35']

['What are some examples of other respected organizations that are alerting the public to the risks of ignoring climate change?', 'Other respected organizations are also alerting the public to the risks of ignoring climate change.']

['Teacher: What does the Union of Concerned Scientists (UCS) report identify about the potential risks if the problem is not addressed in a substantial way?', 'The Union of Concerned Scientists (UCS) has released a detailed report identifying approximately twenty serious risks that will be faced if the problem is not addressed in a substantial way.']

['What are some of the risks identified by the Union of Concerned Scientists (UCS) if the problem is not addressed in a substantial way?', 'These risks include rising seas and increased coastal flooding, more intense and frequent heat waves, more destructive hurricanes, wildfires that last longer and produce more damage, and heavier precipitation in some areas and more severe droughts in other areas.']

['What are some other potential consequences of not addressing the problem in a substantial way, according to the Union of Concerned Scientists (UCS)?', 'In addition to extreme weather events, there would likely be widespread forest death in the Rocky Mountains and other mountain ranges, the destruction of coral reefs, and shifts in the ranges of plants and animals.']

['What would be at risk if the problem is not addressed in a substantial way, according to the Union of Concerned Scientists (UCS)?', 'Both military bases and national landmarks would be at risk, as would the electrical grid and food supply.']

["What is the basis for the Union of Concerned Scientists' projections about the potential risks if the problem is not addressed in a substantial way?", 'The UCS, with a membership consisting of the world’s most respected scientists, bases its projections on scientific research studies that have produced empirical evidence of climate change.']

['What is the official position of the Union of Concerned Scientists regarding the effects of global warming?', 'Its official position is that “global warming is already having significant and very costly effects on communities, public health, and our environment.']
['What are some examples of the significant and costly effects of global warming on communities, public health, and the environment, according to the Union of Concerned Scientists?', '”36']

['Teacher: What determines the varying degrees of support that environmental protection and climate change issues receive at the national level?', 'Environmental protection and climate change issues receive varying degrees of support at the national level, depending on the commitment different presidents make to them.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how private companies may take the lead in addressing climate change issues during periods of lower priority from the government?', 'During periods in which the administration in Washington demonstrates a lower priority for climate change issues, such as the Trump administration’s announced intention to withdraw from the Paris Climate Accord, private companies may take the lead on actions to reduce global warming emissions.']

['Teacher: How does Bill Gates plan to allocate $20 billion over the next five years according to the passage?', 'For example, Microsoft founder Bill Gates recently announced the creation of a private initiative to invest $20 billion on climate-related research and development over the next five years.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what is an example of government-funded early experimental research that a business may be able to convert into a commercially viable solution?', 'This is an example of government-funded early experimental research that a business may be able to turn into a commercially viable solution.']

['What role may private-sector companies have to take if the government steps back from funding sustainability initiatives?', 'If government steps back, private-sector companies concerned about long-term sustainability may have to take a leadership role.']

['Why is it important for public and private efforts to cooperate in addressing climate change according to the passage?', '37 Ultimately, it requires the cooperation of public and private efforts to address climate change; otherwise, the impacts will continue to intensify, growing more costly and more damaging.']
['What are some potential consequences of the impacts of climate change intensifying and growing more costly and damaging?', '”38']
['Teacher: What is necessary for sustainability that often requires the cooperation of the public and private sectors?', 'Sustainability often requires the public and private sectors to cooperate.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how inaction contributes to disasters like the devastation caused by Hurricane Harvey in Houston and Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico?', 'Inaction contributes to disasters like the 2017 devastation of Houston by Hurricane Harvey and of Puerto Rico by Hurricane Maria.']

['What is one example of tension that may arise when it comes to sustainability and the cooperation between developers and cities?', 'There is often tension between developers who want to build and cities that try to legislate for more green space.']

['What are some benefits of having green space in cities?', 'Green space not only offers a place for recreation and enjoyment of nature, but also provides essential natural drainage for rain and flood waters, reducing the likelihood that developed areas will end up underwater in a storm.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of U.S. government agencies that have identified challenges where sustainability can have a positive impact?', 'U.S. government agencies, such as the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, have identified many challenges in which sustainability can make a positive contribution.']

['What are some challenges that U.S. government agencies like NASA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration have identified where sustainability can make a positive contribution?', 'These include climate change, decreasing supplies of clean water, loss of ecological systems, degradation of the oceans, air pollution, an increase in the use and disposal of toxic substances, and the plight of endangered species.']

['What are some factors that contribute to progress towards solving these challenges identified by U.S. government agencies?', '41 Progress toward solving these challenges depends in part on deciding who should help pay for the protection of global environmental resources; this is an issue of both environmental and distributive justice.']

['Teacher: What is one way in which the issue of shared responsibility between corporations and society can be addressed, according to the passage?', 'One way to address the issue of shared responsibility between corporations and society is the implementation of a “cap and trade” system.']

['How does the "cap and trade" system help in addressing the issue of shared responsibility between corporations and society?', 'According to the Environmental Defense Fund, cap and trade is a viable approach to addressing climate change by curbing emissions that pollute the air:']

['How does the "cap" in the "cap and trade" system help in curbing emissions and promoting shared responsibility between corporations and society?', 'The “cap” is a limit on greenhouse gas emissions—if companies exceed their cap, they must pay penalties—whereas the “trade” allows companies to use the free market to buy and sell pollution allowances that permit them to emit a certain amount of pollution.']

['Teacher: What are some of the questions that arise when considering the allocation of responsibility and cost between governments, developed and developing nations, and the private sector in addressing the high cost of inaction?', 'At present, there are more questions than answers, including how much of the responsibility lies with governments, how this responsibility can be allocated between developed and developing nations, how much of the cost should the private sector bear, and how should these divisions of cost and responsibility be enforced.']

['What are some of the differing viewpoints on the form in which the private sector should bear the cost and responsibility regarding the high cost of inaction?', 'Private companies must bear part of the cost, and the business sector recognizes they have some responsibility, but many disagree on whether that should be in the form of after-the-fact fines, or before-the-fact fees and deposits paid to the government.']

['What is one potential consequence of not having international regulations in place to address the high cost of inaction?', 'Regulations may very well have to be international in scope, or companies from one country may abuse the environment in another.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of long-term environmental consequences that may occur as a result of inaction on issues of sustainability?', 'Inaction on issues of sustainability can lead to long-term environmental consequences that may not be reversible (the death of ocean coral, the melting of polar ice caps, deforestation).']

['Teacher: How can the difficulty in convincing companies and investors about the long-term nature of environmental sustainability be another obstacle in addressing issues of sustainability?', 'Another hurdle is that it is sometimes difficult to convince companies and their investors that quarterly or annual profits are short-term and transitory, whereas environmental sustainability is long-term and permanent.']

["Teacher: What do some politicians and business leaders in the United States believe is the main reason for the nation's prosperity over the past two hundred years and the key to its future success?", 'Some politicians and business leaders in the United States believe that the U.S. system of capitalism and free enterprise is the main reason for the nation’s prosperity over the past two hundred years and the key to its future success.']

['Teacher: How has the U.S. system of capitalism and free enterprise contributed to the economic development of the United States over the past two hundred years?', 'Free enterprise was very effective in facilitating the economic development of the United States, and many people benefited from it.']

["What role did the country's natural resources play in the economic development facilitated by the U.S. system of capitalism and free enterprise?", 'But it is equally true that this could not have happened without the country’s wealth of natural resources like oil, gas, timber, water, and many others.']

["Teacher: How does the consideration of the environment and the role of sustainability impact the belief in the U.S. system of capitalism and free enterprise as the main reason for the nation's prosperity and future success?", 'When we consider the environment and the role of sustainability, the question is not whether our system works well with an abundance of natural resources.']

['Teacher: What factors should be considered when evaluating the effectiveness of the U.S. system of capitalism and free enterprise in a world with limited natural resources?', 'Rather, we should ask how well it would work in a nation, indeed in a world, in which such resources were severely limited.']

['Teacher: Where did the Harvard Business Review conduct a debate on the topic of environmental economics and policy?', 'The Harvard Business Review recently conducted a debate on this topic on its opinion/editorial pages.']

['Teacher: Who is the author and consultant on environmental and social challenges that expressed the opinion that "business owes the world everything and nothing" in the Harvard Business Review debate on environmental economics and policy?', 'Business owes the world everything and nothing, according to Andrew Winston, author and consultant on environmental and social challenges.']

['Teacher: What does Andrew Winston argue about the responsibility of businesses in the debate on environmental economics and policy in the Harvard Business Review?', '“It’s an important question,” he wrote, “but one that implies business should do the socially responsible thing out of a sense of duty.']

['Teacher: How does Andrew Winston view the concept of businesses doing the socially responsible thing out of a sense of duty in the debate on environmental economics and policy in the Harvard Business Review?', 'This idea is a distraction.']

['Teacher: According to Andrew Winston, what is sustainability in business about in the debate on environmental economics and policy in the Harvard Business Review?', 'Sustainability in business is not about philanthropy, but about profitability, innovation, and growth.']

['How does Bart Victor characterize the influence and power of businesses in the debate on environmental economics and policy in the Harvard Business Review?', 'It’s just plain good business.”44 On the other hand, Bart Victor, professor at Vanderbilt University’s Owen Graduate School of Management, wrote, “Business is far more powerful and deeply influential than any competing ideological force, political force or environmental force . . . business now has to see itself and its responsibilities and obligations in a new way.']
['According to Bart Victor, how does he view the influence and power of businesses in the debate on environmental economics and policy in the Harvard Business Review?', '”45']

['Teacher: According to deontological or duty-based reasoning, what might be concluded about the debt owed by businesses to the environment?', 'Using deontological or duty-based reasoning, we might conclude that business does owe a debt to the environment.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how businesses might pay their debt to the environment according to deontological reasoning?', 'A basic moral imperative in a normative system of ethics is that someone who uses something must pay for it.']

['What is the key difference between deontological reasoning and utilitarian philosophy in terms of the debt owed by businesses to the environment?', 'In contrast, a more utilitarian philosophy might hold that corporations create jobs, make money for shareholders, pay taxes, and produce things that people want; thus, they have done their part and do not owe any other debt to the environment or society at large.']

['What is the main difference in perspective between utilitarianism and deontological reasoning when it comes to considering the impact of businesses on the environment and future generations?', 'However, utilitarianism is often regarded as a “here and now” philosophy, whereas deontology offers a longer-term approach, taking future generations into account and thus aligning more with sustainability.']

['Teacher: What is a recent example of a booming industry in West Texas related to oil and gas drilling that is mentioned in the passage?', 'Consider the example of fracking: West Texas has seen a recent boom in oil and gas drilling due to this relatively new process.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how fracking works and its role in the recent booming industry of oil and gas drilling in West Texas?', 'Fracking is short for hydraulic fracturing, which creates cracks in rocks beneath Earth’s surface to loosen oil and gas trapped there, thus allowing it to flow more easily to the surface.']

['Teacher: How has fracking contributed to the expansion of drilling efforts for oil and gas in the United States, particularly in formations that were previously considered unprofitable?', 'Fracking has led to a greatly expanded effort to drill horizontally for oil and gas in the United States, especially in formations previously thought to be unprofitable, because there was no feasible way to get the fossil fuels to the surface.']
['Teacher: What is the significant downside that comes with the expanded effort of fracking in the United States for oil and gas drilling?', 'However, it comes with a significant downside.']

['Teacher: What are some of the key resources and materials needed for fracking?', 'Fracking requires very heavy equipment and an enormous amount of sand, chemicals, and water, most of which must be trucked in.']

["Teacher: How has the increase in traffic due to fracking affected the infrastructure in Texas's small towns?", 'Traffic around Texas’s small towns has increased to ten times the normal amount, buckling the roads under the pressure of a never-ending stream of oil company trucks.']

["Teacher: What are some of the implications of driving on dangerous roads full of potholes for the residents of Texas's small towns?", 'The towns do not have the budget to repair them, and residents end up driving on dangerous roads full of potholes.']

["Why is it concerning that the oil company trucks are using the local road system in Texas's small towns?", 'The oil company trucks are using a public resource, the local road system, often built with a combination of state and local taxpayer funds.']

["Who should be responsible for repairing the damage caused by the oil company trucks in Texas's small towns?", 'They are obviously responsible for more of the damage than local residents driving four-door sedans to work.']

['Teacher: Why do many people believe it is unfair for small towns to bear the burden of road repair costs caused by the oil company trucks?', 'Many think it is unfair for small towns to have to burden their taxpayers, most of whom are not receiving any of the profits from oil and gas development, with the cost of road repair.']

["What is one proposed solution to address the issue of road repair costs caused by the oil company trucks in Texas's small towns?", 'An alternative might be to impose a Pigovian tax, which is a fee assessed against private businesses for engaging in a specific activity (proposed by British economist A. C. Pigou).']

['What is the purpose of a Pigovian tax in this context?', 'If set at the proper level, the tax is intended as a deterrent to activities that impose a net cost—what economists call “negative externalities”—on third parties such as local residents.']

['Teacher: How does this issue contribute to the ongoing environmental debates surrounding the fracking process?', 'This issue highlights one of many environmental debates sparked by the fracking process.']

['Teacher: Can you provide more examples of environmental risks or concerns associated with the fracking process?', 'Fracking also causes the overuse and pollution of fresh water, spills toxic chemicals into the ground water, and increases the potential for earthquakes due to the injection wells drilled for chemical disposal.']

['Teacher: How do the local residents both benefit and suffer from the business activity related to drilling in the context of environmental economics and policy?', 'Ultimately, as is often the case with issues stemming from natural resource extraction, local residents may receive a few short-term benefits from business activity related to drilling, but they end up suffering a disproportionate share of the long-term harm.']

['Teacher: What is one method that can be used to address the long-term harm caused by pollution, specifically pertaining to carbon emissions?', 'One method of dealing with the long-term harm caused by pollution is a carbon tax, that is, a “pay-to-pollute” system that charges a fee or tax to those who discharge carbon into the air.']

['Can you explain how a carbon tax can motivate users of fossil fuels to switch to cleaner energy sources?', 'A carbon tax serves to motivate users of fossil fuels, which release harmful carbon dioxide into the atmosphere at no cost, to switch to cleaner energy sources or, failing that, to at least pay for the climate damage they cause, based on the amount of greenhouse gas emissions generated from burning fossil fuels.']

['What is the purpose or goal of implementing a carbon tax system in the United States?', 'A proposal to implement a carbon tax system in the United States has been recommended by many organizations, including the conservative Climate Leadership Council (CLC).']

['Why have major oil companies and other large corporations expressed support for the carbon tax plan put forth by the Climate Leadership Council?', '46 Exxon Mobil, Shell, British Petroleum, and Total, along with other oil companies and a number of large corporations in other industries, recently announced their support for the plan to tax carbon emissions put forth by the CLC.47']

['Teacher: According to Michael Gerrard, what could accomplish a lot more for fighting climate change than liability lawsuits if imposed?', 'Michael Gerrard, the director of the Sabin Center for Climate Change Law at Columbia University Law School, said, “If a sufficiently high carbon tax were imposed, it could accomplish a lot more for fighting climate change than liability lawsuits.']

['Teacher: What is the estimated amount that companies would pay each year if a sufficiently high carbon tax was imposed?', '”48 Initial estimates are that if the program were implemented, companies would pay more than $200 billion a year, or $2 trillion in the first decade, an amount deemed sufficient to motivate the expanded use of renewable sources of energy and reduce the use of nonrenewable fossil fuels.']

['Teacher: Who are some of the environmental organizations and legislators in Washington, DC that are endorsing the plan?', 'Some environmental organizations, including the Nature Conservancy and the World Resources Institute, are also endorsing the plan, as are some legislators in Washington, DC.']
['Who is one legislator in Washington, DC who is endorsing the plan according to the passage?', '“The basic idea is simple,” Senator Sheldon Whitehouse (D-RI) said.']

['Which environmental organizations in Washington, DC are mentioned as endorsing the plan according to the passage?', '“You levy a price on a thing you don’t want—carbon pollution—and you use the revenue to help with things you do want.']

['What is the potential impact on U.S. carbon emissions of implementing a carbon tax or fee of $45 per metric ton, according to the passage?', '”49 According to the senator, a U.S. carbon tax or a fee of $45 per metric ton would reduce U.S. carbon emissions by more than 40 percent in the first decade.']
['What is the global status of implementing a carbon tax or fee, according to the passage?', 'This is an idea with global support, and it has already been tried.']

['What is the impact of implementing a carbon tax or fee in forty countries, according to the passage?', 'The World Bank has data indicating that forty countries, along with some major cities, have already enacted such programs, including all countries of the EU, as well as New Zealand and Japan.']

["Teacher: How long have businesses been profiting from using and selling the nation's natural resources?", 'For two centuries, businesses have profited from using and selling the nation’s natural resources.']

['What is the tradeoff in a free but regulated economic system such as that in the United States?', 'The tradeoff in a free but regulated economic system such as that in the United States is to allow the continued extraction of natural resources but to require a commitment to protection of the environment in return.']

['What are some examples of the interests that need to be balanced in order to achieve long-term sustainability?', 'This bargain promotes long-term sustainability by balancing the interests of the environment, state and local governments, and users of natural resources.']

['What are some criticisms or challenges associated with this public-private collaboration for achieving long-term sustainability?', 'However, this public-private collaboration is not without controversy.']

['Teacher: What are the key factors that we need to consider when discussing sustainability as a function of responsible and sustainable business conduct?', 'When discussing the topic of sustainability as a function of responsible and sustainable business conduct, we consider not only environmental health but also public health.']

['Teacher: How do inherently dangerous products like alcohol, tobacco, guns, and drugs relate to public health in the context of sustainable business conduct?', 'Polluting the environment is bad for public health, but so too are a wide variety of inherently dangerous products from alcohol to tobacco to guns to drugs.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some evidence or statistics that demonstrate the impact of alcohol on public health globally?', 'The World Health Organization estimates that alcohol is the cause of close to 7 percent of all deaths each year globally, or about 3.5 million people, and total global sales of alcohol are well over $1 trillion per year.']
['Teacher: What are some potential criticisms or concerns that people might have regarding the sales and consumption of alcohol, given its impact on public health?', '55']

['Teacher: How do you think the public health concerns surrounding alcohol sales and consumption might impact public opinion and policies regarding the marketing and profit of alcohol?', 'The question is whether society should allow businesses to market, sell, and profit from a product that causes so many deaths and creates a significant public health problem.']

['Teacher: What actions, if any, have governments taken to regulate the marketing and profit of alcohol and tobacco products, considering their impact on public health?', 'The same question can be asked about tobacco, on which businesses make over half a trillion dollars annually and which the United States has struggled to regulate for years.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a business that has taken proactive steps to regulate the sale or use of harmful products?', 'Some businesses are acting on their own to rein in the sale or use of harmful products.']

["Teacher: How did CVS's decision to stop selling tobacco products align with their corporate mission?", 'In 2014, CVS, a drugstore and health care giant, chose to stop selling tobacco products, because such sales do not support its corporate mission.']
["What impact did CVS's decision to stop selling tobacco products have on their overall profitability and market share?", '56']

['Teacher: What example does the passage provide to highlight the significance of gun violence in the United States?', 'Few issues are the source of as much public debate as guns, but it is clear that gun violence in the United States is a major public health challenge.']

['What statistics does the passage provide to emphasize the impact of gun violence in the United States?', 'There are about 35,000 deaths per year in the United States due to firearms, and another 75,000 nonfatal firearm injuries.']
['What point does the passage make about the economic aspect of gun sales?', 'However, thousands of businesses profit from gun sales.']

['What does the passage reveal about the financial implications of the gun industry?', 'Annual revenue in the gun and ammunition manufacturing industry is close to $14 billion, producing a profit of $1.5 billion, whereas the annual revenue of gun and ammunition stores is an additional $3 billion, resulting in a profit of $500 million.']
['What do these financial figures suggest about the overall economic impact of the gun industry?', '57']

['What actions did several companies take after the recent fatal mass shooting in Parkland, Florida?', 'On the corporate front, after the most recent fatal mass shooting at a high school in Parkland, Florida, several companies took action without waiting for the law to change.']

['What was the response of Dick’s Sporting Goods and Kroger (owner of Fred Meyer stores) following the fatal mass shooting in Parkland, Florida?', 'Dick’s Sporting Goods announced it will no longer sell semi-automatic assault rifles, such as the AR-15, as has Kroger, which owns Fred Meyer stores.']
['What policy change did Walmart announce following the fatal mass shooting in Parkland, Florida?', 'Walmart has announced it will no longer sell guns to anyone under twenty-one years of age.']
['Teacher: How does opioid abuse relate to the concept of sustainability and the public interest?', 'Another pressing social issue is opioid abuse.']

['Teacher: How does the high number of drug overdose deaths due to opioid abuse impact the public interest?', 'In 2016, there were approximately sixty thousand deaths due to drug overdoses, almost double the number of gun deaths.']

['Teacher: Considering the large profits and lobbying efforts of the pharmaceutical industry, how does their involvement in opioid sales impact the concept of sustainability and the public interest?', 'Profits from the sale of these drugs are in the tens of billions of dollars, and the pharmaceutical industry spends $100 million lobbying Congress not to regulate it more stringently.']

['Teacher: How do the actions of local government entities and private sector companies, such as suing opioid drug manufacturers and limiting the supply of opioid prescriptions, contribute to addressing the issue of opioid abuse in terms of sustainability and the public interest?', 'Some local government entities are suing opioid drug manufacturers,58 and, in the private sector, CVS recently announced it would now fill opioid prescriptions with supplies for only seven days.']

['Teacher: How does the issue of overprescription of opioids contribute to the challenge of achieving sustainability and promoting the public interest?', 'While opioids are legal and often legitimately prescribed for pain management, a large part of the problem is that they are also overprescribed.']

['Teacher: What is a related ethical issue that is close to the hearts of many citizens in addition to discussions on sustainability, human life, and public health?', 'Although sustainability discussions justifiably focus on the protection of human life and public health issues, a related ethical issue close to the hearts of many citizens is animal rights.']

['What was the significance of the Fortune article about the Yoox Net-a-Porter Group in relation to the discussion on animal rights?', 'Businesses have begun to take notice of public demands in this area, as evidenced by a 2017 Fortune article about the Yoox Net-a-Porter Group.60 Net-a-Porter is a large, online retailer (with $2 billion/year in sales) that markets top-line brands such as Prada, Gucci, and Michael Kors.']

['What role did customer demand play in the decision of the Yoox Net-a-Porter Group to ban the use of fur in its products?', 'After a survey of its customers showed that a significant majority want the company to forgo fur products, it decided to forbid the use of fur in its entire line.']

['What impact did the decision of the Yoox Net-a-Porter Group to ban fur have on other big-name brands in the industry?', 'Other big-name brands such as Armani, Hugo Boss, North Face, Nautica, and Timberland have followed Net-a-Porter’s lead and recently announced fur-free policies.']
['Teacher: Can you please provide an example of the related developments in the cosmetics and food industries?', 'Related developments are taking place in the cosmetics and food industries.']

['Teacher: Can you elaborate on some specific examples of cruelty-free product testing policies adopted by cosmetic companies in recent years for a range of products?', 'Many cosmetics companies have announced cruelty-free product testing policies for products ranging from makeup to hairspray.']

['Teacher: Can you provide any specific examples of sustainable farming practices adopted by food companies in recent years?', 'In the food industry, the U.S. Department of Agriculture recently reported that cage-free eggs account for approximately one-quarter of the wholesale shell egg market.']
['Teacher: What benefits do food industries expect to gain by adopting sustainable farming practices?', 'Sales and profits are the answer, along with sustainability.']

['Teacher: What specific actions can food companies take to improve their policies related to animal welfare in order to attract more customers?', 'According to research conducted by Walmart, over 75 percent of the retail giant’s customers said they would be more likely to shop at a store that improves its policies related to animal welfare.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of fast food chains that have announced the implementation of cage-free egg-buying policies?', 'Thus, not only Walmart but also supermarket chains such as Kroger have announced the gradual implementation of cage-free egg-buying policies, as have fast food giants such as McDonald’s and Burger King.62']

['What role do informed consumer stakeholders play in driving changes and improvements in food industry practices?', 'Such changes are often prompted, if not driven, by the influence of informed consumer stakeholders who are demanding the products they want to buy.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of the "revolving door" effect between business and government that you mentioned?', 'Sometimes, however, the relationship between business and government can become too close, as when executives from the private sector leave their jobs to work for government agencies, becoming the regulators rather than the regulated, and then return to industry in a kind of “revolving door” effect.']

['Teacher: How does the "revolving door" effect between business and government potentially influence the decisions made by government agencies?', 'For example, Goldman Sachs, one of the world’s largest financial services firms, has seen many of its executives take senior leadership positions in the presidential administrations of both Democrats and Republicans, including the present secretary of the treasury, Steven Mnuchin.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the "revolving door" effect between business and government can potentially impact the decision-making process at a global level?', 'The same trend is occurring on a global level; Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, was previously a vice chair and managing director of Goldman Sachs International, and Mark Carney, the governor of the Bank of England, worked for Goldman Sachs as well.']

['Teacher: Why do some critics warn of the "fox guarding the hen house" approach to regulation when it comes to the "revolving door" effect between business and government?', 'The large number of executives from one of the biggest investment banks in the world moving in and out of government service causes some critics to warn of the “fox guarding the hen house” approach to regulation.']

['Teacher: What point does the passage make about private-sector companies or industries working directly with the government?', 'Of course, it would be incorrect to assume, because multiple executives of a firm landed in government positions, that the firm is automatically guilty of wrongdoing.']

["Teacher: That's a valid point, but can you provide an example of how private-sector companies can work directly with the government to achieve positive outcomes?", 'Goldman Sachs has created several programs with ethical goals.']

["Teacher: That's great, but can you explain how these programs that Goldman Sachs has created with ethical goals align with the concept of public-private partnerships or P3s mentioned in the passage?", 'The company encourages clients to consider environmental and sustainability issues, and it backs green bonds, which are used to fund projects that have positive environmental and/or climate benefits.']

['Teacher: How does the involvement of private-sector companies like Goldman Sachs in creating programs with ethical goals align with the concept of public-private partnerships mentioned in the passage?', 'In truth, our government would find it difficult to function without the expertise from the private sector supplementing that of the public sector in public service positions.']

['Teacher: How does the research by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City highlight the importance of striking a balance between encouraging and discouraging private sector executives from serving in high-level government positions in regards to regulation and legislation in this area?', 'Research by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City demonstrates how regulation and legislation in this area must strike a balance between encouraging and discouraging executives from the private sector to serve in high-level government positions.']

['Teacher: What are some potential challenges or concerns that may arise if private sector executives are heavily involved in government positions related to regulation and legislation in this area?', 'Our system of government service does not want to run the risk of undermining “the ability of regulatory agencies to seek and retain top level talent, but at the same time we do not want to impair the independence of government policy-makers.']
['What are the benefits of public-private partnerships (P3s) in terms of solving problems and reducing budgets for federal, state, and local agencies?', '”']
['What are some examples of problems that can be solved or addressed through public-private partnerships (P3s)?', '63']
['Teacher: What do the figures you mentioned indicate about the problem at hand?', 'A quick look at some figures indicates the scope of the problem.']

['Teacher: How do these figures support the idea that private-sector companies have a strong relationship with the government in solving problems through public-private partnerships?', 'A 2008 General Accounting Office survey of fifty large defense contractors revealed that almost ninety thousand people who had left the Department of Defense in the preceding eight years were afterwards employed by private-sector companies doing business with the government as contractors.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a legal restriction that limits the revolving door effect specifically for direct government contracting?', '64 While legal restrictions exist to limit the revolving door effect, most relate only to direct government contracting.']

['Teacher: What is the importance of private-sector companies being aware of the statutory and regulatory restrictions and their associated penalties when hiring former employees of the federal government?', 'Private-sector companies seeking to acquire talent by hiring former employees of the federal government must be aware of the statutory and regulatory restrictions and their associated penalties.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of the rule that prohibits former senior government employees from making any communication with or appearance before their former agency with the intent to influence the agency after leaving service for one year?', 'One rule says former senior government employees may not make any communication with or appearance before their former agency, with the intent to influence the agency, for one year after leaving service.']

["Teacher: That's correct. Now, why do you think there is a rule in place that prohibits former senior government employees from communicating with or influencing their former agency for a certain period of time after leaving service?", 'The ban is extended to two years for certain “very senior” officials.65']

['Teacher: Why do you think the ban is extended to two years for certain "very senior" officials?', 'Penalties for violations can include fines of up to $50,000 per violation and/or twice the amount of compensation received.']

['Teacher: That\'s correct. Additionally, why do you think the penalties for violations of the rule are more severe for "very senior" officials?', 'On a company level, the penalty can be up to $500,000 per violation and/or twice the amount of the contract.']

["Teacher: That's correct. In addition to the penalties for violating the rule, what other consequences can individuals who intentionally violate the law face?", 'Moreover, individuals who intentionally violate the law may be subject to criminal penalties, which can include up to five years in jail.']

['Teacher: What action did President Obama take in 2009 regarding executive agency appointees?', 'In 2009, shortly after he took office, President Obama issued an executive order requiring all executive agency appointees to take an ethics pledge as a prerequisite for accepting appointment.']

["Teacher: Can you explain the significance of President Obama's executive order requiring executive agency appointees to take an ethics pledge?", 'The pledge included a lobbying ban and restrictions on appointees and lobbyists entering and leaving the government.']

["Teacher: How did President Obama's executive order impose restrictions on executive agency appointees and lobbyists entering and leaving the government?", 'For instance, appointees entering the government had to agree not to participate in any matter both “directly and substantially” related to their former employer or clients for two years.']

['Teacher: Why might the ethical restrictions on executive agency appointees and lobbyists entering and leaving the government vary from president to president?', '66 However, because these ethical restrictions were implemented by way of executive order, not federal statute, they may vary from president to president.']

['Teacher: What is one reason why ethical questions have been raised about conflict of interest concepts in the present administration?', 'Ethical questions have been raised about traditional conflict of interest concepts in the present administration, because people currently serving in it have retained ownership of private companies rather than selling them or placing them in blind trusts.']

['Teacher: How can expertise in a field be valuable to both government and business in a business-government partnership?', 'Of course, the relationship between government and business is an important one, and expertise in a field can be extremely valuable to both sides in a business-government partnership.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for the collaboration between government and business in a business-government partnership to be transparent and subject to public scrutiny?', 'However, this collaboration should be transparent and subject to public scrutiny, as noted by the Brookings Institution, one of the oldest nonprofit public policy think tanks.']

['Teacher: What potential conflicts of interest should be considered when industry executives move into government service in a business-government partnership?', 'In a report entitled “Amateur Government: When Political Appointees Manage the Federal Bureaucracy,” the Institution warns against the potential for conflicts of interest stemming from allowing too many industry executives to move into government service, set overtly pro-industry policies, and then go back to their higher-paying, private-sector jobs.']

['Teacher: What are some potential benefits of public-private partnerships in terms of solving problems and reducing budgets for government agencies?\nStudent: Public-private partnerships have the potential to bring in additional resources and expertise from the private sector, which can help government agencies solve problems more efficiently and effectively. Additionally, these partnerships can also help reduce the financial burden on government budgets.', 'The key is to seek a balance.']
['Teacher: How can public-private partnerships strike a balance between the interests of both the government and private sector?', '67']

['Teacher: What have many politicians campaigned on over the past decade in relation to government regulation?', 'Over the past decade, many politicians have run for office on a platform of reducing government regulation.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the two closely related positions on reducing federal government regulation that politicians have campaigned on?', 'There are at least two closely related positions on reducing federal government regulation.']

["Teacher: How does the states' rights position on reducing federal government regulation aim to limit the powers of the federal government?", 'The first is essentially a states’ rights position that seeks to limit the powers of the federal government to those very specifically enumerated in the Constitution.']

["Teacher: What is the second closely related position on reducing federal government regulation and how does it differ from the states' rights position?", 'It is based on principles embodied in the Tenth Amendment and on a narrow interpretation of the Commerce Clause.']

["Teacher: How does the second closely related position on reducing federal government regulation differ from the states' rights position in terms of legal principles it is based on?", 'The Tenth Amendment reserves to the states any right not specifically delegated to the federal government.']

['Teacher: How do the two closely related positions on reducing federal government regulation aim to limit the powers of the federal government?', 'The Commerce Clause is the part of the Constitution that gives the federal government the right to regulate commerce between states.']

['Teacher: What is the second view of government regulation and how does it compare to the first view?', 'The second, related view of government regulation holds that “less is better” at all levels, whether state or federal.']

['Teacher: Why do followers of the second view of government regulation advocate for reducing the size of government and regulation at every level?', 'Its followers simply seek to reduce the size of government and regulation at every level.']

['Teacher: What is the ideology commonly associated with the advocates of the second view of government regulation?', 'Some might attribute this position to a libertarian or “small government” philosophy.']

['Teacher: How would you describe the key difference between the two philosophies regarding government regulation mentioned in the passage?', 'These two philosophies might be characterized as less government regulation vs. no government regulation, other than military defense.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why some people in the business community prefer state regulation over federal regulation?', 'The preference for state regulation is often based on a belief in the business community that many states are softer on regulation that the federal government, or that states are closer to the problems businesses face and are more efficient at addressing them.']

['Teacher: What are some arguments that support the belief that states are more efficient at addressing business-related problems compared to the federal government?', 'However, there is little clear evidence that one branch of government is more efficient than another.']

['Teacher: What is the main challenge when it comes to regulating businesses according to the passage?', 'The real challenge is weighing the benefits of regulation against the costs, and finding the right balance between over- and under-regulation.']
['Teacher: What are the potential consequences of weak regulation for businesses?', 'Weak regulation can allow a business to cut corners.']

['Teacher: How can delayed implementation of regulations negatively impact the environment and public health?', 'For instance, auto emission regulations intended to go into effect by certain dates have been delayed multiple times during the 1980s and the early 2000s.']

['Teacher: How can the delay in implementing regulations impact the effectiveness of those regulations in addressing environmental and public health concerns?', 'The Obama administration announced plans to enforce tougher rules, but the current administration has said it plans to delay implementation.']

['Teacher: How do the constant changes and delays in implementing auto emission regulations affect the ability of businesses and states to effectively address environmental concerns?', 'Auto emission regulations have become politically charged, constantly changing depending on the party in power, and some states have responded with their own legislation instead of waiting for the federal stalemate to end.']

['Teacher: How does consistent enforcement of regulations contribute to achieving long-term goals, like cleaner air?', 'Regulation that is consistently enforced in the effort to achieve the long-term goal, such as cleaner air, is preferable to a moving target.']
['Teacher: What is the third position regarding government according to the passage?', 'A third position is that government is not necessarily a bad thing.']

['What are some possible benefits that a "federalist" philosophy might believe centralized government provides for citizens?', 'Such a “federalist” philosophy might assert that centralized government provides an array of benefits for citizens.']

['What is one of the arguments that Alexander Hamilton makes in the Federalist Papers to support the belief that a well-intentioned central government is not the enemy of liberty?', 'For example, in the Federalist Papers, Alexander Hamilton emphasized that a well-intentioned central government was not the enemy of liberty but rather the best means of securing the rights achieved through the passage of the Constitution.']

['What does Alexander Hamilton argue is one advantage of federal government over state government according to the passage?', 'He and others also pointed out an advantage of federal over state government—a large republic such as the United States would actually benefit from a larger electorate and a larger pool of qualified leaders, and competing state and regional interests would be more balanced under federal regulation.']

['Teacher: How can the acceptance of different philosophies influence the level of regulation implemented by an administration?', 'Acceptance of one or the other of these philosophies may lean an administration towards more or less regulation, as well as calibrating its response to aggressive lobbying by industries seeking to reduce regulation they view as burdensome.']

['How can aggressive lobbying efforts by industries impact government regulation and its consequences for the environment and public health?', 'The results for the environment and/or public health can sometimes be disastrous.']

['Teacher: What event triggered heightened sensitivity towards questions of regulation and political influence in recent years?', 'Questions of regulation and political influence have become even more sensitive in recent years, following the decision in Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission (2010).71']

['Teacher: How did the ruling in Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission impact laws regarding the use of general treasury funds for political advertising by corporations?', 'In Citizens United, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled 5–4 that laws preventing corporations from using general treasury funds for political advertising violated the First Amendment’s guarantee of freedom of speech.']

['Teacher: What constitutional right did the court determine was violated by laws restricting corporations from using general treasury funds for political advertising in Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission?', 'In other words, the government may not prevent corporations from spending money to support or oppose candidates in elections.']

['Teacher: How did the ruling in Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission impact campaign finance reform laws?', 'With this decision, the Court invalidated numerous campaign finance reform laws.']

['Teacher: What concerns have been raised by commentators regarding the impact of the Citizens United ruling on campaign finance?', 'Many commentators think the decision opened the floodgates for special-interest groups to spend without limit in U.S. elections.']

['Teacher: What is one consequence of the government regulation discussed in this passage that allows business entities to spend an unlimited amount of money on political ads?', 'Business entities may now seek to persuade the voting public by spending an unlimited amount of money on political ads, whether through social media or traditional print and broadcast media.']

['Teacher: How does the unlimited spending on political ads by business entities potentially impact the pressure on Congress to regulate or deregulate certain policies?', 'Businesses opposed to government regulation can spend without limit to help elect candidates whose position on reduced regulation is the same as theirs, thereby increasing the pressure on Congress to deregulate.']

['Teacher: In what way does the profusion of money in U.S. politics, caused by unlimited spending on political ads, contribute to the partisan divide in the government?', 'Many think the profusion of money in U.S. politics is one cause of the partisan divide that often paralyzes the legislative branch and unduly influences the executive branch.']

['Teacher: What is one regulation that Senator Paul Sarbanes is known for sponsoring?', 'One of the sponsors of the corporate governance law known as the Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX), Senator Paul Sarbanes (D-MD), is among those who would like to see financial limits on business lobbying groups and political action committees, several of which are attempting to repeal current regulations such as SOX, which is tough on business fraud.']

['What was the purpose of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act and what did it mandate?', 'Sarbanes-Oxley, passed in 2002 in response to several highly publicized corporate fraud cases that took down companies such as Enron and WorldCom, mandates reporting transparency in areas ranging from finance to accounting to supply chain activities.']

['What were some of the key provisions of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act that promote reporting transparency?', 'Essentially, it ensures that we now consider it both unethical and illegal to deceive shareholders, creditors, and the public at large.']
['Teacher: What is the focus of Sarbanes-Oxley and which entities does it apply to?', 'Sarbanes-Oxley applies to publicly traded companies and is enforced by the Securities and Exchange Commission.']

['What are some specific provisions of Sarbanes-Oxley that address the independence of corporate boards and outside accounting firms?', 'It covers multiple topics such as the independence of corporate boards and outside certified public accounting firms that audit corporations.']

['What are some potential benefits of making CEOs and CFOs personally responsible for errors in annual audits, as stated in Sarbanes-Oxley?', 'The law also makes the CEO and CFO personally responsible for errors in annual audits—thus making it harder to “cook the books.”']

['What is one specific provision of Sarbanes-Oxley that aims to prevent financial fraud and protect whistleblowers?', 'Finally, it prohibits company loans to executives and grants protection to whistleblowers.']
['Teacher: What are some concerns that critics had about compliance with SOX?', 'Some critics thought compliance with SOX might be too costly.']

['Teacher: Why do most people now view Sarbanes-Oxley as a necessary regulatory step, despite concerns about its cost?', 'However, after more than a decade of enforcement, it is now clear to most that Sarbanes-Oxley was, and is, a necessary regulatory step.']

['Teacher: What specific measures did Sarbanes-Oxley introduce to prevent unethical conduct and fraud similar to the Enron case?', 'It has allowed for significant progress to be made in slowing down the kind of unethical conduct that led to the Enron fraud.']

['Teacher: How has the impact of Sarbanes-Oxley extended beyond publicly traded companies?', 'Although SOX technically applies only to publicly traded companies, many private companies also adopt SOX-style internal controls and transparency, as do not-for-profits such as universities and hospitals.']

['Teacher: What concepts do we need to understand in order to grasp the influence of culture on business ethics?', 'To understand the influence of culture on business ethics, it is essential to understand the concepts of enculturation and acculturation.']
