['What factors contributed to the continued growth of revenue at Gravity despite the implementation of the $70,000 minimum wage?', 'Revenue continues to grow at Gravity, along with the customer base and the workforce.']
['What is the current retention rate at Gravity?', 'Currently, the firm has a retention rate of 91 percent.']
["What does Price believe should be measured on managers' scorecards in addition to profit?", '37 Yet Price says managers’ scorecards should measure purpose, impact, and service, as much as profit.']

['Teacher: What course does Professor Michael Wheeler teach at Harvard Business School?', 'Michael Wheeler, a professor at Harvard Business School who teaches a course called “Negotiation and The Moral Leader,” recently discussed the aftermath of Dan Price’s decision at Gravity.']

["Teacher: What did Professor Michael Wheeler do to explore the impact of Dan Price's decision on creative compensation at other companies?", 'He interviewed other entrepreneurs about their plans for creative compensation to help develop a happy and motivated workforce, and it appears that some other companies are taking notice of how successful Gravity has been since Price made the decision to pay his workers more.']
['What is the average wage increase that Dan Price implemented for his workers at Gravity?', '38']

['What was the percentage increase in starting base pay implemented by Megan Driscoll at Pharmalogics Recruiting?', 'One of these entrepreneurs was Megan Driscoll, the CEO of Pharmalogics Recruiting, who, after hearing Dan Price speak to a group of executives, was inspired to raise the starting base pay of her employees by 33 percent.']

['What was the revenue of Pharmalogics Recruiting when Megan Driscoll implemented the plan to raise the starting base pay by 33 percent?', 'When Driscoll put her plan to work, her business had forty-six employees and $6.7 million in revenue.']

['What was the percentage increase in revenue for Pharmalogics Recruiting one year after Megan Driscoll implemented the plan to raise the starting base pay by 33 percent?', 'A year later, staff and revenues had jumped to seventy-two and $15 million, respectively.']

['What evidence does Megan Driscoll provide to support the claim that her employees are working harder and smarter after the pay raise?', 'Driscoll points to data showing her people are working harder and smarter after the pay raise than before.']

['What are some specific indicators that show the positive impact of the pay raise on the performance of employees at Pharmalogics Recruiting?', 'There has been a 32 percent increase in clients, and the client retention rate doubled to 80 percent.']
['What was the percentage increase in profit for Pharmalogics Recruiting one year after Megan Driscoll implemented the plan to raise the starting base pay by 33 percent?', '39']

['Teacher: How did Stephan Aarstol, CEO of Tower Paddleboards, address the issue of not having enough cash to give his workers a raise?', 'Stephan Aarstol, CEO of Tower Paddleboards, wanted to give his workers a raise, but his company did not have the cash.']

['Teacher: What unconventional solution did Stephan Aarstol implement to address the issue of not having enough cash to give his workers a raise?', 'Instead, Aarstol boldly cut the work day to five hours from the ten hours most employees had been working.']

['What impact did the unconventional solution of cutting the work day have on employee focus and engagement, according to Stephan Aarstol?', 'Essentially that doubled their pay, and as a result, he says, employee focus and engagement have skyrocketed, as have company profits.']
['What percentage increase in pay did the employees experience as a result of cutting the work day to five hours?', '40']

['Teacher: What is one of the challenges that managers face when trying to ensure the long-term success of a company?', 'Managers must carefully balance the short term, such as quarterly profits, versus long-term sustainability as a successful company.']

['Teacher: How can managers recognize the value of work that each person contributes in order to ensure the long-term success of a company?', 'This requires recognizing the value of work that each person contributes and devising a fair, and sometimes creative, compensation plan.']

['Teacher: What aspect of American culture challenges the notion of employees joining a labor union?', 'Americans’ longstanding belief in individualism makes some managers wonder why employees would want or need to be represented by a labor union.']

['What are some examples or reasons why individuals in positions of power, such as CEOs or entertainers, choose to be represented by someone else during negotiations or contracts?', 'The answer is, for the same reasons a CEO wants to be represented by an attorney when negotiating an employment contract, or that an entertainer wants to be represented by an agent.']

['How do labor unions fulfill the role of an agent or lawyer for employees during collective bargaining?', 'Unions act as the agent/lawyer/negotiator for employees during collective bargaining, a negotiation process aimed at getting management’s agreement to a fair employment contract for members of the union.']

['What are some reasons why individuals might turn to professionals for assistance in important negotiations, such as collective bargaining?', 'Everyone wants to be successful in any important negotiation, and people often turn to professionals to help them in such a situation.']

['Teacher: What has the concept of worker organization been about, in addition to good representation, both in the United States and globally?', 'However, in the United States, as elsewhere around the globe, the concept of worker organization has been about more than simply good representation.']

['What are some of the broader issues that the concept of worker organization, such as unionization and worker rights, has often been linked to in debates about class economics, political power, and ethical values?', 'Unionization and worker rights have often been at the core of debates related to class economics, political power, and ethical values.']
['What are some of the arguments made by those who support unions in the debate about worker organization?', 'There are legitimate points on each side of the union debate.']
['Teacher: What is the topic of discussion that leads to significant disagreement?', 'The value of unions is a topic that produces significant disagreement.']

['What are some examples of improvements that unions have attained for workers in terms of wages and benefits, standardized employment practices, labor protections, workplace environment, and on-the-job safety?', 'Historically, unions have attained many improvements for workers in terms of wages and benefits, standardized employment practices, labor protections (e.g., child labor laws), workplace environment, and on-the-job safety.']

['What are some potential criticisms or drawbacks of unions in terms of their actions and priorities?', 'Nevertheless, sometimes unions have acted in their own interests to sustain their own existence, without primary concern for the workers they represent.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of the challenges faced by workers in the first half of the twentieth century, as mentioned in the video?', 'The history of the worker movement (summarized in the video in the following Link to Learning) reveals that in the first half of the twentieth century, wages were abysmally low, few workplace safety laws existed, and exploitive working conditions allowed businesses to use child labor.']

['What role did unions play in addressing the challenges faced by workers in the first half of the twentieth century?', 'Unions stepped in and played an important role in leveling the playing field by representing the interests of the workers.']

['Why did union membership reach a relatively high level in the 1950s?', 'Union membership grew to a relatively high level (33% of wage and salary workers) in the 1950s, and unions became a force in politics.']

['What caused the decline in union dominance in the 1960s?', 'However, their dominance was relatively short-lived, not least because in the 1960s, the federal government started to enact employment laws that codified many of the worker protections unions had championed.']

['What impact did the shift from a manufacturing-based economy to a service-based economy have on unions in the 1980s and 1990s?', 'In the 1980s and 1990s, the U.S. economy gradually evolved from manufacturing, where unions were strong, to services, where unions were not as prevalent.']

['What were some factors that made organizing unions in the service sector more difficult in the 1980s and 1990s?', 'The service sector is more difficult to organize, due to a variety of factors such as the historical absence of unions in the sector, workers’ widely differing work functions and schedules, challenging organizational status, and white-collar bias against unions.']

['Teacher: What are some factors that have contributed to the decline in unions and their membership in recent years?', 'These developments, along with the appearance of state right-to-work laws, have led to a decline in unions and their membership.']

['What are some consequences of the appearance of state right-to-work laws on union membership?', 'Right-to-work laws give workers the option of not joining the union, even at companies where the majority has voted to be represented by a union, resulting in lower membership.']

['What is the impact of right-to-work laws on the concept of a union shop or closed shop?', 'Right-to-work laws attempt to counter the concept of a union shop or closed shop, which requires that all new hires automatically be enrolled in the labor union appropriate to their job function and that union dues automatically be deducted from their pay.']

['Teacher: What is one concern that some individuals have regarding the fairness of right-to-work laws?', 'Some question the fairness of right-to-work laws, because they allow those who do not join the union to get the same pay and benefits as those who do join and who pay unions dues for their representation.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why some individuals view right-to-work laws as providing workers with the right of choice?', 'On the other hand, right-to-work laws provide workers the right of choice; those who do not want to join a union are not forced to do so.']

['Teacher: How might the presence of right-to-work laws impact the relationship between workers who choose not to join a union and those who do during a union-mandated strike?', 'Those who do not choose to join may end up having a strained relationship with union workers, however, when a union-mandated strike occurs.']

['Teacher: How might the decision of some workers to cross the picket line during a union-mandated strike affect the overall effectiveness of the strike?', 'Some non-union members, and even union members, elect to cross the picket line and continue to work.']

['Teacher: How does the retaliation towards workers who cross the picket line during a union-mandated strike impact the overall effectiveness of the strike?', 'Traditionally, these “scabs,” as they are derisively labeled by unions, have faced both overt and subtle retaliation at the hands of their coworkers, who prioritize loyalty to the union.']
['Teacher: Can you provide me with some information about the presence of right-to-work laws in the United States?', 'Twenty-eight states have right-to-work laws.']

['What is the significance of the presence of right-to-work laws in states where automobiles are manufactured and unions were once strong?', 'Notice that many right-to-work states, such as Michigan, Missouri, Indiana, Wisconsin, Kentucky, Tennessee, Alabama, and Mississippi, are among the top ten states where automobiles are manufactured and unions once were strong.']

['Teacher: What percentage of the U.S. workforce was unionized in 1980, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics?', 'According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, total union membership in the United States dropped to 20 percent of the workforce in 1980; by 2016, it was down to about half that.41 Public sector (government) workers have a relatively high union membership rate of 35 percent, more than five times that of private-sector workers, which is at an all-time low of 6.5 percent.']

['What is the current union membership rate for private-sector workers in the United States?', 'White-collar workers in education and training, as well as first responders such as police and firefighters now have some of the highest unionization rates, also 35 percent.']

['What are the states with the highest and lowest union membership rates in the United States currently?', 'Among states, New York continues to have the highest union membership rate at 23 percent, whereas South Carolina has the lowest, at slightly more than 1 percent.']

['Teacher: What is the definition and concept of codetermination in the context of organized labor?', 'Codetermination is a workplace concept that goes beyond unionization to embrace shared governance, in which management and workers cooperate in decision-making and workers have the right to participate on the board of directors of their company.']

['What is codetermination and how does it differ from traditional unionization in the context of organized labor?', 'Board-level representation by employees is widespread in European Union countries.']
['What is one characteristic of codetermination laws in relation to the size of companies they apply to?', 'Most codetermination laws apply to companies over a certain size.']
['What is one example of a country where codetermination laws apply to companies over a certain size?', 'For example, in Germany, they apply to companies with more than five hundred employees.']
['What is the minimum number of employees that a company in Germany must have in order for codetermination laws to apply?', '42']

['What is one reason why codetermination is not common in U.S. companies compared to European companies?', 'The labor union movement never has been quite as strong in the United States as in Europe—the trade-union movement began in Europe and remains more vibrant there even today—and codetermination is thus not common in U.S. companies.']
['Teacher: Can you give an example of a country where codetermination has been successful in facilitating organized labor?', 'Codetermination has worked relatively well in some countries.']

["Teacher: Can you explain why workers, managers, and the public in Germany support codetermination and how it has benefited workers' engagement in their workplaces?", 'For example, in Germany, workers, managers, and the public at large support the system, and it has often resulted in workers who are more engaged and have a real voice in their workplaces.']

['Teacher: How has codetermination in Germany led to higher productivity, fewer strikes, better pay, and safer working conditions?', 'Management and labor have cooperated, which, in turn, has led to higher productivity, fewer strikes, better pay, and safer working conditions for employees, which is a classic win-win for both sides.']

["Teacher: What is the common belief held by some managers, politicians, and even members of the general public regarding unions' impact on the competitiveness of U.S. companies in the global economy?", 'Some managers, politicians, and even members of the general public believe unions are a big part of the reason that U.S. companies have difficulty competing in the global economy.']

['What evidence supports the claim made by the Heritage Foundation study regarding the impact of unions on work process and productivity?', 'The conservative think tank Heritage Foundation conducted a study that concluded unions may be responsible, in part, for a slower work process and reduced productivity.']

['What do other studies indicate about the productivity of the United States despite the claims made by the Heritage Foundation study regarding unions?', '44 However, multiple other studies indicate that U.S. productivity is up.45']

['Teacher: According to the OECD, what was the percentage increase in productivity in the United States between 1973 and 2016?', 'Productivity in the United States increased 74 percent in the period 1973 to 2016, according to the OECD.']

['Teacher: According to the OECD, how does the United States rank in global productivity compared to other countries?', 'In global productivity rankings, most studies indicate the United States ranks quite high, among the top five or six countries in the world and number two on the list compiled by the OECD.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, how much did wages for U.S. workers increase from 1973 to 2016?', 'During the same period as the productivity gains discussed in the preceding paragraph, 1973 to 2016, wages for U.S. workers increased only 12 percent.']
['Teacher: How much did productivity grow compared to pay from 1973 to 2016, according to the passage?', 'In other words, productivity has grown six times more than pay.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, who should not be blamed for the competitive challenges faced by U.S. companies?', 'Taken together, these facts mean that American workers, union members or not, should not shoulder the blame for competitive challenges faced by U.S. companies.']
['Teacher: According to the passage, what do the facts discussed imply about the value of American workers for most companies?', 'Instead, they are a relative bargain for most companies.']

['Teacher: What does Figure 6.12 compare and what does it demonstrate based on the data collected by the Economic Policy Institute?', 'Figure 6.12 compares productivity and pay and demonstrates the growing disparity between the two, based on data collected by the Economic Policy Institute.']

['Teacher: Have you encountered any information regarding management compensation and how it compares to that of employees?', 'We gain yet another perspective on labor by looking at management compensation relative to that of employees.']

['Teacher: Why is it important to compare management compensation to that of employees?', 'Between 1978 and 2014, inflation-adjusted CEO pay increased by almost 1,000 percent in the United States, while worker pay rose 11 percent.']

["Teacher: What is one widely reported measure used to compare the fairness of a company's compensation system with that in other countries?", '47 A popular way to compare the fairness of a company’s compensation system with that in other countries is the widely reported pay ratio, which measures how many times greater CEO pay is than the wages for the average employee.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what exactly you mean by "the average multiplier effect"?', 'The average multiplier effect in the United States is in the range of three hundred.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of CEO compensation that supports the idea of the average multiplier effect being around three hundred in the United States?', 'This means that CEO pay is, on average, three hundred times as high as the pay of the average worker in the same company.']

['What are the average multiplier effects in the United Kingdom, France, and Germany, according to the passage?', 'In the United Kingdom, the multiplier is twenty-two; in France, it is fifteen; and in Germany, it is twelve.']

["What is one common form of executive compensation that is frequently included in the calculation of an executive's salary and benefits, according to the passage?", 'A large part of executive compensation is in the form of stock options, which frequently are included in the calculation of an executive’s salary and benefits, rather than direct salary.']

['How does the inclusion of stock options in executive compensation raise questions about the compensation of the general workforce?', 'However, this, in turn, raises the question of whether all or a portion of the general workforce should also share in some form of stock options.']
['Teacher: What is the central topic discussed in the passage?', 'Everyone wants to be paid fairly for their work.']

['Teacher: How does the passage highlight the importance of fair compensation for individuals from various job positions?', 'Whether CEO or administrative assistant, engineer or assembly-line worker, we naturally look out for our own best interest.']

['Teacher: What is one potential consequence that can arise from the resentment caused by management compensation disparities among organized workers?', 'Thus, management compensation is a topic that often causes resentment among the rank and file, especially when organized workers go on strike.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for management compensation to align with the wages of other employees?', 'From the employee viewpoint, the question is why management often wants to hold the line when it comes to everyone’s wages but their own.']

["Teacher: What are some examples of electronic monitoring devices that allow employers to observe employees' behavior at work?", 'Monitored workstations, cameras, microphones, and other electronic monitoring devices permit employers to oversee virtually every aspect of employees’ at-work behavior.']

["Teacher: How does technology enable employers to monitor employees' computer use?", 'Technology also allows employers to monitor every aspect of computer use by employees, such as downloads of software and documents, Internet use, images displayed, time a computer has been idle, number of keystrokes per hour, words typed, and the content of e-mails.']

["Teacher: What are some specific examples of information that employers can gather through electronic monitoring of employees' computer use?", 'According to a survey by the American Management Association, 48 percent of employers used a form of video monitoring in the workplace, and 67 percent monitored employee Internet use.']

["Teacher: How has electronic monitoring of employees' computer use impacted workplace termination rates in organizations?", 'In 30 percent of the organizations responding to the survey, this electronic monitoring had ultimately led to an employee’s termination.']
['Teacher: How does the use of electronic monitoring impact employee privacy in the workplace?', '49']

['Teacher: Can you please explain why the laws and regulations governing electronic monitoring are considered somewhat indirect and inconsistent?', 'The laws and regulations governing electronic monitoring are somewhat indirect and inconsistent.']

['Teacher: What is the reason behind the indirect and inconsistent nature of laws and regulations governing electronic monitoring in relation to workplace privacy issues?', 'Very few specific federal statutes directly regulate private employers when it comes to broad workplace privacy issues.']

['Teacher: How do state rules, statutory and common law, and federal and state constitutional provisions contribute to the regulation of electronic monitoring in the workplace?', 'However, monitoring is subject to various state rules under both statutory and common law, and sometimes federal and state constitutional provisions as well.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the two primary areas of the law related to workplace monitoring?', 'The two primary areas of the law related to workplace monitoring are a federal statute called the Electronic Communications Privacy Act of 1986 (ECPA) and various state common law protections against invasion of privacy.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of workplace monitoring that fall under the scope of the Electronic Communications Privacy Act of 1986 (ECPA) and state common law protections against invasion of privacy?', '50']

["Teacher: What are the two exceptions in the ECPA that weaken its protection of employees' rights regarding monitoring of their oral, wire, and electronic communications?", 'Although the ECPA may appear to prohibit an employer from monitoring its employees’ oral, wire, and electronic communications, it contains two big exceptions that weaken its protection of employees’ rights.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what is meant by the business purpose exception in the context of electronic monitoring?', 'One is the business purpose exception.']

["Teacher: Can you provide some examples of legitimate business purposes that employers might claim in order to justify monitoring their employees' electronic and oral communications under the business purpose exception?", 'This allows employers—on the basis of legitimate business purposes—to monitor electronic and oral communications, and employers generally assert a legitimate business purpose to be present.']

['Teacher: How does the consent exception under the ECPA allow employers to monitor employee communications?', 'The other widely used exception is the consent exception, which allows employers to monitor employee communications provided employees have given their consent.']

['Teacher: How does the ECPA define electronic communication in the context of monitoring employee communications?', 'According to the Society for Human Resource Management, the ECPA definition of electronic communication applies to the electronic transmission of communications but not to their electronic storage.']

['Teacher: In what situations do courts distinguish between monitoring electronic communications during transmission and viewing them in storage?', 'Therefore, courts have distinguished between monitoring electronic communications such as e-mail during transmission and viewing e-mails in storage.']

["Teacher: How do courts differentiate between monitoring electronic communications during transmission and viewing them in storage in terms of the ECPA's protection of employees' rights?", 'Viewing emails during transmission is broadly allowed, whereas viewing stored e-mail is considered similar to searching an employee’s private papers and thus is not routinely allowed under the ECPA unless certain circumstances apply (e.g., the e-mails are stored in the employer’s computer systems).']
['What circumstances must apply for viewing stored emails to be allowed under the ECPA?', '51']

['Teacher: What is the general legality when it comes to a company monitoring the use of its own property, such as computers, laptops, and cell phones?', 'In general, it is legal for a company to monitor the use of its own property, including but not limited to computers, laptops, and cell phones.']

['What specific law addresses the legality of a company monitoring the use of its own property, including computers, laptops, and cell phones?', 'According to the ECPA, an employer-provided computer system is the property of the employer, and when the employer provides employees with a laptop they can take home, it likely violates no laws when it monitors everything employees do with that computer, whether business-related or personal.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for an employer to give employees notice of a written policy regarding electronic monitoring of equipment supplied by the company?', 'The same is true of an employer-provided cell phone or tablet, and always true when an employer gives employees notice of a written policy regarding electronic monitoring of equipment supplied by the company.']

['What is the general legality when it comes to monitoring equipment owned by the employee, such as a personal cell phone?', 'Generally, the same is not true of equipment owned by the employee, such as a personal cell phone.']
['Teacher: What is the important distinction based on in regards to electronic monitoring?', 'However, an important distinction is based on the issue of consent.']

["Teacher: How does the consent provision in the ECPA impact a company's ability to monitor personal electronic communications?", 'The consent provision in the ECPA is not limited to business communications only; therefore, a company might be able to assert the right to monitor personal electronic communications if it can show employee consent (although this is very likely to worry employees, as discussed in the next section).']

["Teacher: What is another important consideration in determining a company's ability to monitor personal electronic communications, in addition to the issue of consent?", 'Another consideration is whose e-mail server is being used.']

['Teacher: Why does the ECPA and some state laws make it illegal for employers to intercept private e-mail by using an employee’s personal log-on/user ID/password information?', 'The ECPA and some state laws generally make it illegal for employers to intercept private e-mail by using an employee’s personal log-on/user ID/password information.']

['Act provide some level of protection for employees, there are still legal and ethical considerations surrounding electronic monitoring in the workplace.\n\nQuestion: What are some legal and ethical considerations regarding electronic monitoring in the workplace, despite the protection offered by the ECPA and National Labor Relations Act?', 'Although the ECPA and National Labor Relations']

['What are examples of state laws that impose greater limitations on electronic monitoring in the workplace despite the protection offered by the ECPA and National Labor Relations Act?', 'Act are both federal laws, individual states are free to pass laws that impose greater limitations, and several states have done so.']

['What are the ethical considerations surrounding electronic monitoring in the workplace, despite the protection offered by the ECPA and National Labor Relations Act?', 'Some require employers to provide employees advance written notice that specifies the types or methods of monitoring to which they will be subjected.']

['What are the specific provisions of the California and Pennsylvania laws that create protections for workers regarding electronic monitoring in the workplace?', 'Examples of state laws creating some degree of protection for workers include laws in California and Pennsylvania that require consent of both parties before any conversation can be monitored or recorded.']

['Teacher: What type of claims can employees bring to challenge employer monitoring according to common law privacy?', 'Employees can bring common law privacy claims to challenge employer monitoring.']

["Teacher: That's correct, common law privacy claims are based on prior court decisions. Can you provide an example of a common law privacy claim that employees could bring to challenge employer monitoring?", '(Common laws are those based on prior court decisions rather than on legislatively enacted statutes.)']

['What does the employee need to demonstrate in order to prevail on a common law claim of invasion of privacy in relation to employer monitoring?', 'To prevail on a common law claim of invasion of privacy, which is a tort, the employee must demonstrate a right to privacy with respect to the information being monitored.']

["Teacher: That's correct. In addition to state constitutions, what other legal sources might employees rely on to demonstrate a right to privacy in relation to employer monitoring?", 'Several state constitutions, such as those in Louisiana, Florida, South Carolina, and California, expressly provide citizens a right to privacy, which may protect employees with respect to monitoring of their personal electronic information and personal communication in the workplace.']

['Teacher: What is one additional regulatory consideration applicable to electronic monitoring that we should take into account?', 'One additional regulatory consideration applicable to electronic monitoring is whether the company’s workforce is unionized.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for companies to consider labor unions when implementing electronic monitoring in the workplace?', 'The National Labor Relations Board, the federal labor law agency, has ruled that the video surveillance of any portion of the workplace is a condition of employment subject to collective bargaining and must be agreed to by the union before implementation, so employees have notice.']

['Teacher: What is the difference in regulatory considerations for electronic monitoring in unionized workplaces versus non-unionized workplaces?', 'If a workplace is not unionized (the majority are not), then this federal regulation requiring notice does not apply, and as stated previously in this chapter, if there is any protection at all, it would have to be given by state regulation (which is rare in the private [nongovernmental] sector).']
['Teacher: What is one common reason why employees may not be familiar with the specific details of the law?', 'Many employees generally are not be familiar with the specific details of the law.']
['Teacher: What is one potential negative aspect of monitoring that employees may find offensive?', 'They may feel offended by monitoring, especially of their own equipment.']

['What are two potential consequences of implementing a monitoring policy that may impact the workplace environment and employee retention?', 'Companies must also consider the effect on workplace morale if everyone feels spied upon, and the risk that some high-performing employees may decide to look elsewhere for career opportunities.']
['Teacher: Why is it important for employers to develop a clear, specific, and reasonable monitoring policy?', 'Employers should develop a clear, specific, and reasonable monitoring policy.']

['Teacher: What is one important aspect that should be included in a clear, specific, and reasonable monitoring policy to ensure its fairness and effectiveness?', 'The policy should limit monitoring to that which is directly work related.']

['What is one potential consequence of not including a clear definition of what kind of monitoring is necessary in a reasonable monitoring policy?', 'For example, if a company is concerned about productivity and the goal of monitoring is to keep tabs on employee performance, then neither keystroke logging nor screenshot recording is necessary; software designed to show idle time or personal Internet use would be more helpful in identifying wasted time, which is the ultimate goal.']
['Teacher: What should employers keep in mind about their business goals when monitoring employees?', 'Employers should always remember their business goals when monitoring employees.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for employers to ensure that monitoring pertains only to business matters and does not unnecessarily intrude into the privacy of employees?', 'It is not only a matter of treating employees ethically; it also makes good business sense to ensure that monitoring pertains only to business matters and does not unnecessarily intrude into the privacy of employees.']

['Teacher: Why is it important to communicate the monitoring policy to the employees in the interest of fairness?', 'Perhaps most importantly, in the interest of fairness, the monitoring policy must be communicated to the employees.']

['Teacher: Who does the Connecticut policy mentioned in the passage apply to?', 'The Connecticut policy in the preceding Link to Learning applies to all employers (i.e., in state and in private sector workplaces).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a policy mentioned in the passage that applies specifically to government employees?', 'However, many states have policies that apply only to employees who work for the government.']

['Teacher: How does the special status of state employees affect their rights regarding due process, reasonable searches, and related legal doctrines?', 'State employees hold a special status that conveys certain state constitutional rights with regard to due process, reasonable searches, and related legal doctrines.']

['Teacher: How does the special status of federal government employees differ from state employees in terms of their rights regarding due process, reasonable searches, and related legal doctrines?', 'The same is true for federal government employees and the U.S. Constitution, which means the government has a duty of fairness in employee surveillance.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example from the passage that illustrates how the government can monitor its employees despite their rights to due process and reasonable searches?', 'It does not mean, however, that the government cannot monitor its employees at all, as demonstrated by an incident involving a California police officer.']

['What was the outcome of the Ontario v. Quon case mentioned in the passage?', 'In a unanimous decision in Ontario v. Quon,52 the U.S. Supreme Court in 2010 ruled in favor of a police chief in Ontario, California, who read nearly five hundred text messages sent by one of his sergeants on a police-issued pager.']
["What was the basis for the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling in the Ontario v. Quon case?", 'Many of the text messages were personal and some were sexually explicit.']
["What was the Court's reasoning behind allowing the police chief to read the text messages in the Ontario v. Quon case?", 'Only a few dozen were work related.']

['What amendment were the constitutional limits on unreasonable searches by public employers based on in the Ontario v. Quon case?', 'The justices agreed that constitutional limits on unreasonable searches by public employers (under the Fourth Amendment) were minimal given a work-related purpose.']

['Teacher: What does this decision create for more than 25 million employees of federal, state, and local governments?', 'This decision creates precedent for more than 25 million employees of federal, state, and local governments and limits their expectation of privacy when using employer-issued tools.']

['Teacher: According to Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, why was the search by the police chief considered reasonable?', '“Because the search [by the police chief] was motivated by a legitimate work-related purpose and because it was not excessive in scope, the search was reasonable,” said Justice Anthony M. Kennedy.']

['Teacher: What is the key difference between the private sector and government settings when it comes to employee monitoring?', 'In the private sector, where employees are not working for the government and the constitutional prohibition on unreasonable searches and seizures has very little applicability, if any, employers have even more latitude in terms of employee monitoring than in a government setting.']

['What is the key factor that allows private-sector employers to have more latitude in employee monitoring compared to government settings?', 'The Ontario v. Quon case in all likelihood would never even make it to court if the employer were a private-sector company, because the issue of whether getting the text message was a reasonable search and seizure under the Fourth Amendment does not apply in a nongovernment employment setting.']

['Teacher: What is the role of the Constitution in restricting employee monitoring in government settings compared to private-sector companies?', 'The Constitution acts to limit government intrusions but does not generally restrict private companies in this type of situation.']

['What are some reasons why private-sector employers may choose to have more latitude in employee monitoring compared to government settings, despite ethical considerations?', 'However, ethical considerations may encourage private-sector employers to treat their workers respectfully, even if not required by law.']

['Teacher: What is the initial consideration for an employer when deciding to implement a drug testing or monitoring program in the workplace?', 'Key issues that arise about a drug testing or monitoring program begin with whether an employer wants or needs to do it.']

['Teacher: How does federal law impact the decision-making process for employers regarding drug testing in the workplace?', 'With the exception of employers in industries regulated by the federal government, such as airlines, trucking companies, rail lines, and national security-related firms, federal law is not controlling on the issue of drug testing in the workplace; it is largely a state issue.']

['Teacher: How does the Department of Transportation influence drug testing for workers in industries such as airlines and railway?', 'At the federal level, the Department of Transportation does mandate drug testing for workers such as airline crews and railway conductors and has a specific procedure that must be followed.']

['Teacher: What is the role of the Department of Transportation in drug testing for workers in industries regulated by the federal government, such as airlines and railways?', 'However, for the most part, drug testing is not mandatory and depends on whether the employer wants to do it.']

['Teacher: How does the variability in state regulations impact drug testing in the workplace?', 'Multiple states do regulate drug testing, but to varying degrees, and there is no common standard to be followed.']
['Teacher: What is the most common form of drug testing in the workplace?', 'Testing of job applicants is the most common form of drug testing.']

['In what ways do state laws regulate drug testing of job applicants in the workplace?', 'State laws typically allow it, but the employer must follow state rules, if they exist, about providing notice and following standard procedures intended to prevent inaccurate samples.']

['Teacher: Why is drug testing of current employees less common in the workplace compared to job applicants?', 'Testing current employees is much less common, primarily due to cost; however, companies that do use drug testing include some in the pharmaceutical and financial services industries.']
['Teacher: What are some legal constraints that some states place on drug testing of private-sector employees?', 'Some states put legal constraints on drug testing of private-sector employees.']
['Teacher: What are some examples of legal constraints that some states put on drug testing of private-sector employees?', 'For example, in a few states.']

['What are the criteria that some states require in order to legally conduct drug testing of private-sector employees?', 'the job must include the possibility of property damage or injury to others, or the employer must believe the employee is using drugs.']
['Teacher: Why is it challenging to dispute the results of a drug test in the workplace?', 'Challenging a drug test is difficult because tests are considered highly accurate.']

['Why might an applicant or employee be hesitant to refuse a drug test in the workplace?', 'An applicant or employee can refuse to take the test, but that often means not being hired or losing the job, assuming the worker is an employee at will.']

['Why is the concept of employment at will significant in the context of drug testing in the workplace?', 'The concept of employment at will affirms that either the employee or the employer may dissolve an employment arrangement at will (i.e., without cause and at any time unless an employment contract is in effect that stipulates differently).']

['What does it mean for an employee to be considered an employee at will in the context of drug testing in the workplace?', 'Most workers are considered employees at will because neither the employer nor employee is obligated to the other; the worker can quit or be fired at any time for any reason because there is no contractual obligation.']

['What are the potential consequences for an employee in certain states if they refuse to take a drug test in the workplace?', 'In some states, the employee risks not only job loss but also the denial of unemployment benefits if fired for refusing to take a drug test.']

['What percentage of employees in the private sector are considered employees at will?', 'Thus, the key concept that makes drug testing possible is employment at will, which covers approximately 85 percent of the employees in the private sector (unionized workers and top executives have contracts and thus are not at will, nor are government employees who have due process rights).']

['What criteria must be met for a drug testing procedure in some states?', 'The only legal limitation is that, in some states, the drug testing procedure must be fair, accurate, and designed to minimize errors and false-positive results.']
['Teacher: What are some of the privacy issues that are raised by the drug testing process in the workplace?', 'The drug testing process, however, raises some difficult privacy issues.']

['Teacher: How are employers addressing privacy concerns related to specimen tampering during the drug testing process in the workplace?', 'Employers want and are allowed to protect against specimen tampering by taking such steps as requiring subjects to wear a hospital gown.']

['What are some measures that employers take to prevent specimen tampering during the drug testing process in the workplace?', 'Some employers use test monitors who check the temperature of the urine and/or listen as a urine sample is collected.']

['What is the legal stance on monitoring employees during the drug testing process in restrooms in different states?', 'According to the Cornell University Law School Legal Information Institute, some state courts (e.g., Georgia, Louisiana, Hawaii) have found it an unreasonable invasion of privacy for the monitor to watch an employee in the restroom; however, in other states (e.g., Texas, Nevada), this is allowed.']
['What states allow employers to monitor employees during the drug testing process in restrooms?', '53']
['Teacher: Can you provide me with an example of a challenge based on privacy concerns related to drug testing in the workplace?', 'Case examples abound of challenges based on privacy concerns.']

["Teacher: What was the purpose of Mark Rothstein's article in the Harvard Journal of Law and Technology regarding drug testing in the workplace?", 'In an article in the Harvard Journal of Law and Technology, University of Houston Law School professor Mark Rothstein, who is director of the Health Law and Policy Institute, summarized examples of legal challenges.']
['Teacher: How many different legal challenges related to drug testing did Mark Rothstein summarize in his article?', '54']

['How did the court rule in the case where the employer engaged in unlawful retaliation as defined by the Mine Safety and Health Act?', 'In one case, the court ruled that an employer engaged in unlawful retaliation as defined by the Mine Safety and Health Act.']

["Did the court find the employer's actions regarding the two employees' dismissal to be discriminatory based on the privacy concerns related to drug testing?", 'The employer dismissed two employees who were required to urinate in the presence of others but found themselves unable to do so.']

['Did the court find the employer liable for invasion of privacy and negligent infliction of emotional distress in the case where the worker was forced to submit a urine sample while being directly observed?', 'In a different case, $125,000 in tort damages was awarded to a worker for invasion of privacy and negligent infliction of emotional distress as a consequence of his being forced to submit a urine sample as he was being directly observed.']
['Teacher: What are some obligations that we likely owe to an employer?', 'Hard work and our best effort likely make sense as obligations we owe an employer.']

['Teacher: Why is loyalty considered to be more abstract and less easily defined compared to obligations like hard work and best effort?', 'However, loyalty is more abstract and less easily defined.']

['Teacher: What are some factors that contribute to the difficulty in defining loyalty in the employer-employee relationship?', 'Most workers do not have employment contracts, so there may not be a specific agreement between the two parties detailing their mutual responsibilities.']

['Teacher: What role does the common law of agency play in governing the employer-employee relationship?', 'Instead, the common law (case law) of agency in each state is often the source of the rules governing an employment relationship.']

["Teacher: How does the duty of loyalty typically require an employee to act in relation to their employer's interest?", 'The usual depiction of duty in common law is the duty of loyalty, which, in all fifty states, requires that an employee refrain from acting in a manner contrary to the employer’s interest.']

["Teacher: What are some examples of actions that would be considered contrary to the employer's interest and would violate the duty of loyalty?", 'This duty creates some basic rules employees must follow on the job and provides employers with enforceable rights against employees who violate them.']

["Teacher: What does the duty of loyalty mean in terms of an employee's obligations to their employer?", 'In general terms, the duty of loyalty means an employee is obligated to render “loyal and faithful” service to the employer, to act with “good faith,” and not to compete with but rather to advance the employer’s interests.']
["What are some specific examples of actions that demonstrate an employee's loyalty and faithfulness to their employer?", '1']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of a situation where an employee's actions could potentially create a conflict of interest with their employer?", 'The employee must not act in a way that benefits him- or herself (or any other third party), especially when doing so would create a conflict of interest with the employer.']
["Teacher: How can an employee advance their employer's interests without competing against them?", '2']

['Teacher: What is the general rule regarding an employee holding a second job that could potentially compete or conflict with their first job?', 'The common law of most states holds as a general rule that, without asking for and receiving the employer’s consent, an employee cannot hold a second job if it would compete or conflict with the first job.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of a situation where an employee would need to seek their employer's consent before taking on a second job?", 'Thus, although the precise boundaries of this aspect of the duty of loyalty are unclear, an employee who works in the graphic design department of a large advertising agency in all likelihood cannot moonlight on the weekend for a friend’s small web design business.']

['Teacher: What are some factors that employers consider when deciding whether or not to grant permission for an employee to take on a second job?', 'However, employers often grant permission for employees to work in positions that do not compete or interfere with their principal jobs.']

['Teacher: What are some factors that employers consider when deciding whether or not to grant permission for an employee to take on a second job that may compete or interfere with their principal job?', 'The graphic designer might work for a friend’s catering business, for example, or perhaps as a wedding photographer or editor of a blog for a public interest community group.']

['Teacher: What is wrong for employees to do when making work decisions, according to the passage?', 'What is clear is that it is wrong for employees to make work decisions primarily for their own personal gain, rather than doing what is in the employer’s best interest.']

['Teacher: Good job summarizing the passage! According to the passage, what is an example of a work decision an employee might have the authority to make?', 'An employee might have the authority to decide which other companies the employer will do business with, for example, such as service vendors that maintain the copiers or clean the offices.']

["Teacher: Why is it considered a breach of loyalty for an employee to prioritize their personal gain over the employer's best interest when deciding which companies to do business with?", 'That gives him or her an incentive to encourage doing business with that particular company, whether it would be best for the employer or not.']

['Teacher: What is the relationship between the degree of responsibility or trust an employer places in an employee and the existence of the duty of loyalty?', 'The degree to which the duty of loyalty exists is usually related to the degree of responsibility or trust an employer places in an employee.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how the degree of trust an employer places in an employee affects the strength of the duty of loyalty?', 'More trust equals a stronger duty.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a situation where the duty of loyalty reaches its highest level, known as a fiduciary duty, due to the extent of authority or access to confidential information given to an employee?', 'For example, when an employee has very extensive authority or access to confidential information, the duty can rise to its highest level, called a fiduciary duty, which is discussed in an earlier chapter.']

["Teacher: What is the level of consensus when it comes to defining an employee's duty of loyalty to their employer?", 'There is no generally agreed-upon definition of an employee’s duty of loyalty to his or her employer.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example that supports the idea that the concept of loyalty in the workplace is evolving?', 'One indicator that our understanding of the term is changing is that millennials are three times more likely than older generations to change jobs, according to a Forbes Human Resources Council survey.3']

['Teacher: How does the changing concept of loyalty in the workplace affect the expectations of millennials regarding job tenure?', 'About nine in ten millennials (91 percent) say they do not expect to stay with their current job longer than three years, compared with older workers who often anticipated spending ten years or even an entire career with one employer, relying on an implicit social contract between employer and employee that rewarded lifetime employment.']

['Teacher: How does the Loyalty Research Center define loyal employees?', 'The Loyalty Research Center, a consulting firm, defines loyal employees as “being committed to the success of the organization.']

['Teacher: According to the Loyalty Research Center, what are the qualities of loyal employees?', 'They believe that working for this organization is their best option . . . and loyal employees do not actively search for alternative employment and are not responsive to offers.”4 Likewise, Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania, professor Matthew Bidwell says there are two halves to the term: “One piece is having the employer’s best interests at heart.']
['What are the two halves of the term "loyal employees" according to Matthew Bidwell?', 'The other piece is remaining with the same employer rather than moving on.”']

['What does Matthew Bidwell say about the current sense of loyalty towards organizations?', 'Bidwell goes on to acknowledge, “There is less a sense that your organization is going to look after you in the way that it used to, which would lead [us] to expect a reduction in loyalty.”']
['What does Bidwell expect to happen to loyalty towards organizations based on the current sense of loyalty?', '5']

['Teacher: Can you explain why loyalty is considered a two-way street?', 'One reason is that loyalty is a two-way street, a feeling developed through the enactment of mutual obligations and responsibilities.']

['Teacher: What is one reason why employers often prefer to have workers be "employees at will" without long-term employment contracts?', 'However, most employers do not want to be obligated to their workers in a legal sense; they usually require that almost all workers are employees “at will,” that is, without any long-term employment contract.']

['Why is the concept of "employees at will" seen as contradictory to the notion of loyalty in the workplace?', 'Neither state nor federal law mandates an employment contract, so when a company says an employee is employed at will, it is sending a message that management is not making a long-term commitment to the employee.']

['What impact does the concept of "employees at will" have on the loyalty felt by employees towards their organization?', 'Employees may naturally feel less loyalty to an organization from which they believe they can be let go at any time and for any legal reason (which is essentially what at-will employment means).']

['How does the concept of at-will employment affect the level of loyalty employers can expect from their employees?', 'Of course, at-will employment also means the employee can also quit at any time.']

["What are some factors that may limit an employee's freedom to move to other job opportunities?", 'However, freedom to move is a benefit only if the employee has mobility and a skill set he or she can sell to the highest bidder.']

['What are the potential disadvantages for employees in terms of job mobility when they are in an "employees-at-will" arrangement?', 'Otherwise, for most workers, at-will employment usually works to the employer’s advantage, not the employee’s.']

['Teacher: How does the important role of money in career decisions impact the concept of loyalty to an organization at all levels?', 'Another reason the concept of loyalty to an organization seems to be changing at all levels is the important role money plays in career decisions.']

['What example is provided in the text to illustrate the impact of money on the concept of loyalty in organizations?', 'When they see chief executive officers (CEOs) and other managers leaving to work for the highest bidder, subordinates quickly conclude that they, too, ought to look out for themselves, just as their bosses do, rather than trying to build up seniority with the company.']
["What effect can switching jobs to improve salaries have on employees' loyalty to their current organization?", 'Switching jobs can often be a way for employees to improve their salaries.']
["How does the concept of loyalty in professional sports illustrate the impact of job switching on employees' loyalty to their current organization?", 'Consider professional sports.']

["Why did professional athletes' loyalty to one team change over the years?", 'For decades professional athletes were tied to one team and could not sell their services to the highest bidder, meaning that their salaries were effectively capped.']

['How has the ability of professional athletes to switch employers impacted their loyalty to one team?', 'Finally, after several court decisions (including the Curt Flood reserve clause case involving the St. Louis Cardinals and Major League Baseball),6 players achieved some degree of freedom and can now switch employers frequently in an effort to maximize their earning potential.']
['Teacher: Can you provide examples of how the concept of loyalty evolved in the entertainment industry?', 'The same evolution occurred in the entertainment industry.']

['Teacher: How did these contracts in the early movie industry affect the loyalty of actors towards their studios?', 'In the early years of the movie business, actors were tied to studios by contracts that prevented them from making movies for any other studio, effectively limiting their earning power.']

['Teacher: What impact did the newfound freedom of actors to sell their services have on the concept of loyalty in the entertainment industry?', 'Then the entertainment industry changed as actors gained the freedom to sell their services to the highest bidder, becoming much more highly compensated in the process.']

["Teacher: How does the ability to change jobs and seek higher compensation impact an employee's loyalty towards their current employer?", 'Employees in any industry, not just sports and entertainment, benefit from being able to change jobs if their salary at their current job stagnates or falls below the market rate.']

['Teacher: How did the switch from defined-benefit to defined-contribution retirement plans impact loyalty in the private sector?', 'Another economic phenomenon affecting loyalty in the private sector was the switch from defined-benefit to defined-contribution retirement plans.']

['Teacher: What were the key differences between defined-benefit and defined-contribution retirement plans in terms of employee benefits and sponsorship?', 'In the former, often called a pension, employee benefits are usually sponsored (paid) fully by the employer and calculated using a formula based on length of employment, salary history, and other factors.']

['Teacher: How does the transition from a defined-benefit to a defined-contribution retirement plan shift the responsibility of managing the investment risk?', 'The employer administers the plan and manages the investment risk, promising the employee a set payout upon retirement.']

['Teacher: How does the defined-contribution retirement plan differ from the defined-benefit plan in terms of employee contributions and employer involvement?', 'In the defined-contribution plan, however, the employee invests a certain percentage of his or her salary in a retirement fund, often a 401(k) or 403(b) plan, where it is sometimes matched (partially or wholly) by the employer.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of the letter/number combinations, such as 401(k) or 403(b), used to designate retirement savings plans in the U.S. Internal Revenue Code?', '(These savings plans with their seemingly strange designations are part of the U.S. Internal Revenue Code, and the letter/number combinations indicate subsections of the Code.']

['Teacher: What are the differences between 401(k) and 403(b) retirement plans in terms of the types of employment settings they are typically featured in?', '401(k) Plans typically are featured in for-profit employment settings and 403(b) plans in nonprofit environments.)']

['What are the contrasting criteria by which defined-benefit and defined-contribution retirement plans reward employees?', 'Defined-benefit plans reward longevity in the firm, whereas defined-contribution plans reward high earnings over seniority.']

['Teacher: What are some potential implications of the shift from defined-benefit to defined-contribution retirement plans on employee loyalty in the private sector?', 'Thus, with the growth of defined-contribution plans, some reasons for staying with the same employer over time are no longer applicable.']
['report, what percentage of companies have a formal loyalty program in place?', 'According to PayScale’s Compensation Best Practices']

["Teacher: What did PayScale's Compensation Best Practices report reveal about the leading motivators for people who leave their jobs?", 'Report, the two leading motivators people give for leaving their job are first, higher pay, and second, personal reasons (e.g., family, health, marriage, spousal relocation).']
['Teacher: What does the number 7 represent in relation to the passage you just mentioned?', '7']

['Teacher: What concept or idea does the number 7 represent in the passage you just mentioned?', 'Of course, beyond money, workers seek meaning in their work, and it is largely true that money alone does not motivate employees to higher performance.']

["Teacher: Based on the passage, what is the role of money in employees' job satisfaction?", 'However, it is a mistake for managers to think money is not a central factor influencing employees’ job satisfaction.']

["Teacher: Why is it a mistake for managers to think that money is not a central factor influencing employees' job satisfaction?", 'Money matters because if employees are not making enough money to meet their financial obligations or goals, they will likely be looking to for a higher-paying job.']

["Teacher: In what way can increasing salary or other benefits demonstrate a company's loyalty to its employees and its belief in their best interests?", 'And, of course, increasing salary or other benefits can be a way of demonstrating both the company’s loyalty to its employees and the role it believes employees’ best interests play in its mission—navigating the aforementioned two-way street.']

["Teacher: How can employees' loyalty be sparked, according to the passage?", 'For some employees, simply being acknowledged and thanked for their service and good work can go a long way toward sparking their loyalty; for others, more concrete rewards may be necessary.']
['Teacher: What is one of the ways in which many people participate in the new "gig" economy?', 'Finally, many people work for themselves as freelance or contract workers in the new “gig” economy.']

['Teacher: How does the concept of loyalty differ for freelance or contract workers in the "gig" economy compared to traditional employees?', 'They may take assignments from one or more companies at a time and are not employees in the traditional sense of the word.']

['Teacher: How does the approach to work for freelance or contract workers in the "gig" economy differ from that of traditional employees in terms of their loyalty towards their clients or companies?', 'Therefore, it seems more reasonable that they would approach work in the same way a certified public accountant or attorney would—as completing a professional job for a client, after which they move on the next client, always keeping their independent status.']

['Teacher: Why is it not expected for gig workers to demonstrate employer loyalty in the "gig" economy?', 'We would not expect gig workers to demonstrate employer loyalty when they are not employees.']

['Teacher: What is the expectation employers have regarding the information encountered by employees in their day-to-day work?', 'In the competitive world of business, many employees encounter information in their day-to-day work that their employers reasonably expect they will keep confidential.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of the types of information that employers expect their employees to keep confidential?', 'Proprietary (private) information, the details of patents and copyrights, employee records and salary histories, and customer-related data are valued company assets that must remain in-house, not in the hands of competitors, trade publications, or the news media.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for employers to expect their employees to keep proprietary information confidential?', 'Employers are well within their rights to expect employees to honor their duty of confidentiality and maintain the secrecy of such proprietary material.']

['Teacher: What are some situations in which the duty of confidentiality originates specifically from an employment contract?', 'Sometimes the duty of confidentiality originates specifically from an employment contract, if there is one, and if not, the duty still exists in most situations under the common law of agency.']

['Teacher: Why do most companies adopt employment agreements or contracts with employees regarding confidentiality?', 'Most companies do not consider U.S. common law on confidentiality sufficient protection, so they often adopt employment agreements or contracts with employees that set forth the conditions of confidentiality.']

['Why do employment agreements or contracts regarding confidentiality typically have a one-way obligation from the employee to the employer?', '(Note that such contracts define a one-way obligation, from the employee to the employer, so they do not protect the at-will employee from being terminated without cause.)']
['What are some examples of the requirements listed in an employment agreement regarding confidentiality?', 'Typically, an employment agreement will list a variety of requirements.']

['What is the purpose of including a clause in an employment agreement that states the company owns copyrightable works created by employees?', 'For example, although in most situations the law would already hold that the employer owns copyrightable works created by employees within the scope of their employment (known as works for hire), a contract usually also contains a specific clause stating that the company owns any and all such works and assigning ownership of them to the company.']

['What is the purpose of including a patent assignment provision in an employment agreement regarding confidentiality?', 'The agreement will also contain a patent assignment provision, stating that all inventions created within the scope of employment are owned by or assigned to the company.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe information that has economic value, is not known to the public, and is protected by reasonable means?', 'Employers also want to protect their trade secrets, that is, information that has economic value because it is not generally known to the public and is kept secret by reasonable means.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of information that could be considered trade secrets?', 'Trade secrets might include technical or design information, advertising and marketing plans, and research and development data that would be useful to competitors.']

['Teacher: How are trade secrets typically protected against theft, especially when they are not covered by federal intellectual property law?', 'Often nondisclosure agreements are used to protect against the theft of all such information, most of which is normally protected only by the company’s requirement of secrecy, not by federal intellectual property law.']

['Teacher: How do federal intellectual property laws typically protect trademarks, copyrights, and patents?', 'Federal law generally protects registered trademarks (commercial identifications such as words, designs, logos, slogans, symbols, and trade dress, which is product appearance or packaging) and grants creators copyrights (to protect original literary and artistic expressions such as books, paintings, music, records, plays, movies, and software) and patents (to protect new and useful inventions and configurations of useful articles).']

['Teacher: How do non-compete agreements contribute to maintaining confidentiality within U.S. companies?', 'U.S. companies have long used non-compete agreements as a way to provide another layer of confidentiality, ensuring that employees with access to sensitive information will not compete with the company during or for some period after their employment there.']

['Why do U.S. companies use non-compete agreements as a means to maintain confidentiality?', 'The stated purpose of such agreements is to protect the company’s intellectual property, which is the manifestation of original ideas protected by legal means such as patent, copyright, or trademark.']

['What factors are typically imposed as limitations on non-compete agreements in order to be enforceable?', 'To be enforceable, non-compete agreements are usually limited by time and distance (i.e., they are in effect for a certain number of months or years and within a certain radius of the employer’s operations).']

['What is the potential drawback or concern with requiring non-compete agreements from mid- and lower-level workers who have no access to any confidential intellectual property?', 'However, some companies have begun requiring these agreements even from mid- and lower-level workers in an attempt to prevent them from changing jobs, including those who have no access to any confidential intellectual property.']

['What is the percentage of the U.S. private-sector workforce that is currently covered by non-compete agreements?', 'About 20 percent of the U.S. private-sector workforce, and about one in six people in jobs earning less than $40,000 a year, are now covered by non-compete agreements.']
['What is the approximate percentage of the U.S. private-sector workforce that is covered by non-compete agreements earning less than $40,000 a year?', '11']

['What is one consequence of the increased use of non-compete agreements in the U.S. private-sector workforce?', 'The increased use of such agreements has left many employees feeling trapped by their limited mobility.']

['Teacher: What is the ethical question that arises in relation to the practice mentioned in the passage?', 'An ethical question arises regarding whether this practice is in the best interests of society and its workers, and some states are responding.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how one state, specifically California, has addressed the ethical question mentioned in the passage?', 'California enacted a law in 2017 saying that most non-compete agreements are void, holding that although an employee may owe the employer a responsibility not to compete while employed, that duty ceases upon termination of employment.']
["Teacher: How does California's law regarding non-compete agreements align with the ethical question raised in the passage?", '12']

['Teacher: Why is it important that an employee does not "belong" to a company forever, in the context of the ethical question raised in the passage?', 'In other words, an employee does not “belong” to a company forever.']

['Teacher: How does California\'s law regarding non-compete agreements reflect the belief that an employee should not "belong" to a company forever, in the context of the ethical question raised in the passage?', 'In California, therefore, a non-compete arrangement that limits employment after leaving the employer is now unenforceable.']

['Teacher: How does California\'s law regarding moonlighting align with the belief that an employee should not "belong" to a company forever, in the context of the ethical question raised in the passage?', 'A California company may still legally prohibit its employees from moonlighting during the term of their employment, particularly for a competitor.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of a nonsolicitation clause in terms of confidentiality?', 'Employers may also insert a nonsolicitation clause, which protects a business from an employee who leaves for another job and then attempts to lure customers or former colleagues into following.']

["Teacher: Can you explain the limitations of nonsolicitation clauses in terms of protecting an employer's interest in retaining employees and customers?", 'Though these clauses have limitations, they can be effective tools to protect an employer’s interest in retaining its employees and customers.']

['Teacher: Why are nonsolicitation clauses particularly difficult for employees to comply with in relatively closed markets?', 'However, they are particularly difficult for employees to comply with in relatively closed markets.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why nonsolicitation clauses are more challenging for employees to comply with in relatively closed markets?', 'Sample language for all the clauses we have discussed is found in Figure 7.4.']

['Teacher: Why do companies put time, effort, and money into developing a brand?', 'Every company puts time, effort, and money into developing a brand, that is, a product or service marketed by a particular company under a particular name.']

['What are some examples of companies that understand the importance of branding?', 'As Apple, Coca-Cola, Amazon, BMW, McDonald’s, and creators of other coveted brands know, branding—creating, differentiating, and maintaining a brand’s image or reputation—is an important way to build company value, sell products and services, and expand corporate goodwill.']

['What are some components that can be considered as part of a brand?', 'In the sense discussed here, the term “brand” encompasses an image, reputation, logo, tagline, or specific color scheme that is trademarked, meaning the company owns it and must give permission to others who would legally use it (such as Tiffany’s unique shade of blue).']
['Teacher: What do companies want and expect employees to do in regards to their branding endeavors?', 'Companies want and expect employees to help in their branding endeavors.']

["Teacher: How does the head of training at American Express view the relationship between employees and the company's brand?", 'For example, according to the head of training at American Express, the company’s brand is its product, and its mantra has always been, “Happy employees make happy customers.']

['What is the reason American Express places significant emphasis on employee satisfaction?', '”15 American Express places significant emphasis on employee satisfaction because it is convinced this strategy helps protect and advance its brand.']

["What is the purpose of Cisco's branding program on social media that reaches out to employees?", 'One company that uses positive employee involvement in branding is the technology conglomerate Cisco, which started a branding program on social media that reaches out to employees.']
["What is the role of employees in Cisco's branding program on social media?", 'Employees are encouraged to be creative in their brand-boosting posts in the program.']

["What are the benefits of Cisco's branding program on social media for both prospective job candidates and current employees?", 'The benefit is that prospective job candidates get a peek into Cisco life, and current employees feel the company trusts and values their ideas.']
["What is the impact of employee involvement in a company's branding endeavors?", '16']

['Teacher: What are some of the challenges companies face in protecting their brand today?', 'However, protecting the brand can be a special challenge today, thanks to the ease with which customers and even employees can post negative information about the brand on the Internet and social media.']

['Teacher: Can you provide any specific examples or instances in the fast-food industry where negative information about a brand has been posted on the Internet or social media?', 'Consider these examples in the fast-food industry.']

['Teacher: How can posting negative information about a brand on the Internet and social media impact the reputation of fast-food companies?', 'A photo posted on Taco Bell’s Facebook page showed an employee licking a row of tacos.']

["Teacher: How do incidents like the ones you just mentioned involving Taco Bell and Domino's Pizza impact the reputation and trustworthiness of these fast-food companies?", 'A Domino’s Pizza employee can be seen in a YouTube video spitting on food, putting cheese into his nose and then putting that cheese into a sandwich, and rubbing a sponge used for dishwashing on his groin area.']

["Teacher: In what ways can incidents like the ones you just mentioned, such as the Taco Bell employee licking tacos and the Domino's Pizza employee spitting on food, affect consumer perceptions of fast-food companies?", '17 On Twitter, a Burger King employee in Japan posted a photo of himself lying on hamburger buns while on duty.']
['Teacher: How did the companies respond to the situation?', 'The companies all responded swiftly.']
["Teacher: What was Taco Bell's response to the situation regarding the viral photo?", 'A Taco Bell spokesperson said the food was not served to customers and the employee in the photo was fired.']

["How did Domino's respond to the situation regarding the viral videos?", 'The two Domino’s employees behind the videos were fired and faced felony charges and a civil lawsuit; Domino’s said the tainted food was never delivered.']

["What was Burger King's response to the situation regarding the viral photo of the buns?", 'According to a Burger King news release, the buns in the photo were waste material because of an ordering mistake and were promptly discarded after the photo was taken; the employee in the photo was fired.']
