['Teacher: How do the examples in the passage illustrate the potential impact of disloyal or disgruntled employees on social media?', 'These examples demonstrate how much damage disloyal or disgruntled employees can create, especially on social media.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some specific details about the financial and goodwill losses that the companies mentioned in the passage experienced due to the actions of disloyal or disgruntled employees on social media?', 'All three companies experienced financial and goodwill losses after the incidents and struggled to restore public trust in their products.']

['What is the importance of investing in developing brand loyalty among employees, according to the passage?', 'The immediate and long-term costs of such incidents are the reason companies invest in developing brand loyalty among their employees.']

['Teacher: Why does Colin Mitchell emphasize the importance of considering employees in the marketing of a brand according to the Harvard Business Review interview?', 'According to a Harvard Business Review interview with Colin Mitchell, global vice president, McDonald’s Brand, McDonald’s, good branding requires that a business think of marketing not just to its customers but also to its employees, because they are the “very people who can make the brand come alive for your customers”.']

['What is the term used to describe the process of getting employees to believe in the product and commit to the idea that the company is selling something worth buying?', '18 The process of getting employees to believe in the product, to commit to the idea that the company is selling something worth buying, and even to think about buying it, is called internal marketing.']

['What are some potential challenges or concerns that employees may have with being the equivalent of a company spokesperson?', 'Of course, some employees may not want to be the equivalent of a company spokesperson.']
['What is one potential incentive that could encourage employees to become company spokespersons?', 'Suppose employers offer employees substantial discounts on their products or services.']

['Teacher: Why is internal marketing considered an important part of the solution to the problem of employees who act as if they do not care about the company?', 'Internal marketing is an important part of the solution to the problem of employees who act as if they do not care about the company.']

['Why does internal marketing help employees make a personal connection to the products and services the business sells?', 'It helps employees make a personal connection to the products and services the business sells, without which they might be more likely to undermine the company’s expectations, as in the three fast-food examples cited in this section.']

['What are some of the negative consequences for a company when employees do not believe in the brand and feel hostile toward the company?', 'In those cases, it is clear the employees did not believe in the brand and felt hostile toward the company.']
['What is the most common problem that arises when employees do not believe in the brand and feel hostile toward the company?', 'The most common problem is usually not as extreme.']
['What is a common manifestation of employees not believing in the brand and feeling hostile toward the company?', 'More often it is a lack of effort or “slacking” on the job.']

['Why is it important for employees to develop a sense of brand loyalty?', 'Employees are more likely to develop some degree of brand loyalty when they share a common sense of purpose and identity with the company.']

['Teacher: What role do employees play in forming a positive relationship with customers?', 'As the public’s first point of contact with a company, employees are obliged to assist the firm in forming a positive relationship with customers.']

["What are the implications of employees' performance in forming a positive relationship with customers?", 'How well or poorly they do so contributes a great deal to customers’ impression of the company.']

["Teacher: How can employees' obligations to assist in forming a positive relationship with customers affect the success of the company and its employees?", 'And customers’ perceptions affect not only the company but all the employees who depend on its success for their livelihood.']

['What is the importance of treating customers with respect in an ethical manner?', 'Thus, the ethical obligations of an employee also extend to interactions with customers, whom they should treat with respect.']

['How can employers empower employees to use their best judgment when working with customers?', 'Employers can encourage positive behavior toward customers by empowering employees to use their best judgment when working with them.']

["Teacher: How can a single negative customer interaction impact brand loyalty, regardless of the company's efforts in building it?", 'It may take only one bad customer interaction with a less-than-engaged or committed employee to sour brand loyalty, no matter how hard a company has worked to build it.']

['How does a single positive customer interaction contribute to the development of brand goodwill, despite any previous negative experiences?', 'In the same way, just one good experience can build up good will.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, how are employees who treat customers well regarded by the company?', 'Employees who treat customers well are assets to the company and deserve to be treated as such.']

['Teacher: How does the passage suggest that employees should handle customers who are rude or disrespectful?', 'Sometimes, however, customers are rude or disrespectful, creating a challenge for an employee who wants to do a good job.']

['Teacher: What are some potential solutions that the passage suggests for handling customers who are rude or disrespectful?', 'This problem is best addressed by management and the employee working together.']

['What does the Pizza Hut case that follows in the passage illustrate about the challenges employees may face with customers?', 'In the Pizza Hut case that follows, an employee was placed in a bad situation by customers.']
['Teacher: Why is it important for an employee to get along with coworkers in terms of company performance?', 'An employee who gets along with coworkers can help the company perform better.']
['Teacher: What is one suggested action for getting along with coworkers?', 'One thing you can do is to keep an open mind.']

['What might be a potential concern for someone who did not get along with coworkers at their current job and is looking for a new job?', 'Or, if you did not get along with the people there and were looking for a change, you might fear things will be the same at the new job.']
['What advice can you give to someone who wants to avoid making prejudgments about their coworkers at a new job?', 'Do not make any prejudgments.']
['What can help you establish a positive relationship with your coworkers at a new job?', 'Get to know a bit about your new coworkers.']

['How can participating in office social events and activities contribute to establishing a positive relationship with coworkers at a new job?', 'Accept, or extend, lunch invitations, join weekend activities and office social events, and perhaps join those office traditions that bind long-serving employees and newcomers together in a collaborative spirit.']
['Teacher: What is another thing you can do to improve your relationship with your coworkers?', 'Another thing you can do it to remember to be kind.']

['Teacher: How can performing a random act of kindness for a coworker on a bad day improve your relationship with them?', 'Everyone has a bad day every now and then, and if you spot a coworker having one, performing a random act of kindness may make that person’s day better.']
['Teacher: Can you give an example of a random act of kindness that you can perform for a coworker on a bad day?', 'You do not need to be extravagant.']

['Teacher: What are some simple acts of kindness that you can perform for a coworker on a bad day?', 'Offer to stay late to help the person meet a tight deadline, or bring coffee or a healthy snack to someone working on particularly difficult tasks.']

['Teacher: How does remembering the adage, "It\'s nice to be important, but it\'s more important to be nice," relate to improving your relationship with your coworkers?', 'Remember the adage, “It’s nice to be important, but it’s more important to be nice.”']

['Teacher: What is the key factor in ensuring a successful relationship between coworkers, according to the passage?', 'For any relationship to succeed, including the relationship between coworkers, the parties must respect each other—and show it.']
['What is one specific action or behavior mentioned in the passage that can help coworkers show respect for each other?', 'Avoid doing things that might offend others.']
["Why should coworkers avoid taking credit for someone else's work, according to the passage?", 'For example, do not take credit for someone else’s work.']

['Why is it important for coworkers to be willing to listen and tolerate differing points of view, according to the passage?', 'Do not be narrow minded; when someone brings up a topic such as politics or religion, be willing to listen and tolerate differing points of view.']

['Teacher: What is one related directive mentioned in the passage that you should follow to get along with coworkers?', 'A related directive is to avoid sexual jokes, stories, anecdotes, and innuendos.']
['Why is it important to avoid sexual jokes, stories, anecdotes, and innuendos in the workplace?', 'You might think it is okay to talk about anything and everything at work, but it is not.']

['What are the consequences of making sexual jokes, stories, anecdotes, and innuendos in the workplace?', 'Others may not find the topic funny and feel offended, and you may make yourself vulnerable to action by management if such behavior is reported.']

["Why is it important to consider your coworkers' comfort levels when discussing sensitive topics like sex in the workplace?", 'Your coworkers might be a captive audience, but you should never place them in an awkward position.']
['Teacher: Why is it important to make an effort to get along with everyone, even difficult people?', 'Make an effort to get along with everyone, even difficult people.']

["Teacher: According to the student's response, why is it necessary to make an effort to get along with everyone, even difficult people?", 'But professionalism requires that we attempt to establish the best working relationships we can on the job, no matter the opinions we might have about our colleagues.']

['Teacher: How does professionalism influence our approach towards establishing working relationships with our colleagues?', 'Normally, we might like some of them very much, be neutral about some others, and genuinely dislike still others.']

['What expectation does professionalism place on our behavior towards our coworkers, regardless of our personal feelings towards them?', 'Yet our responsibility in the workplace is to respect and act at least civilly toward all of them.']

['What are the potential outcomes of respecting and acting civilly towards all coworkers, regardless of personal feelings, as professionals?', 'We likely will feel better about ourselves as professionals and also live up to our commitments to our companies.']
['Teacher: Why is it important to not use social media to gossip when getting along with coworkers?', 'Finally, do no use social media to gossip.']

['Why can gossiping on social media about coworkers cause problems at work and what is the best way to handle this urge?', 'Gossiping at work can cause problems anywhere, perhaps especially on social media, so resist the urge to vent online about your coworkers.']

['Why is it important to maintain a positive and professional image when interacting with coworkers on social media?', 'It makes you appear petty, small, and untrustworthy, and colleagues may stop communicating with you.']

["What are the potential consequences of not following your employer's social media policy when interacting with coworkers?", 'You may also run afoul of your employer’s social media policy and risk disciplinary action or dismissal.']

['Teacher: Why is it important to understand the various personalities at work?', 'Understanding the various personalities at work can be a complex task, but it is a vital one for developing a sense of collegiality.']

['Teacher: How can developing your emotional intelligence contribute to understanding the various personalities at work?', 'One technique that may be helpful is to develop your own emotional intelligence, which is the capacity to recognize other people’s emotions and also to know and manage your own.']
['Teacher: What is one way to demonstrate emotional intelligence?', 'One aspect of using emotional intelligence is showing empathy, the willingness to step into someone else’s shoes.']

['Teacher: Can you elaborate on how workplace personalities reflect our thoughts and actions in our job?', 'All of us have different workplace personalities, which express the way we think and act on the job.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of different workplace personalities and how they influence our thoughts and actions in a job?', 'There are many such personalities, and none is superior or inferior to another, but they are a way in which we exhibit our uniqueness on the job.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how individuals who lead with logic and reason may approach their work differently compared to those with different workplace personalities?', 'Some of us lead with our brains and emphasize logic and reason.']

['What are some characteristics and behaviors exhibited by individuals who lead with their hearts and emphasize mercy over justice in their relationships with others in the workplace?', 'Others lead with our hearts, always emphasizing mercy over justice in our relationships with others.']
['Teacher: What does the passage discuss in relation to employees?', 'Employees can also have very different work styles, the way in which we are most comfortable accomplishing our tasks at work.']
['Teacher: What is one characteristic of work styles that employees can have, according to the passage?', 'Some of us gravitate toward independence and jobs or tasks we can accomplish alone.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what are some examples of work styles that employees can gravitate towards?', 'Others prefer team or project work, bringing us into touch with different personalities.']
['Teacher: According to the passage, what is one thing that some employees seek in their work environments?', 'Still others seek a mix of these environments.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what are the two different values that employees have when it comes to their work environments?', 'Some prioritize getting the job done as efficiently as possible, whereas others value the journey of working on the project with others and the shared experiences it brings.']

["According to the passage, why is it beneficial for workers to know their work preferences and understand their colleagues' work personalities?", 'There is no right or wrong style, but it benefits any worker to know his or her preferences and something about the work personalities of colleagues.']

['Why is it important for workers to appreciate what motivates their greatest success and happiness on the job, according to the passage?', 'When in the office, the point for any of us individually is to appreciate what motivates our greatest success and happiness on the job.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a recent incident that highlights the issue of workplace violence?', 'As recent incidents have shown—for example, the April 2018 shooting at YouTube headquarters in San Bruno, California21—workplace violence is a reality, and all employees play a role in helping make work a safe, as well as harmonious place.']

['How can employees contribute to making their workplace safe and harmonious?', 'Employees, in fact, have a legal and ethical duty not to be violent at work, and managers have a duty to prevent or stop violence.']

['What are the four categories of workplace violence according to the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health?', 'The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health reports that violence at work usually fits into one of four categories: traditional criminal intent, violence by one worker against another, violence stemming from a personal relationship, and violence by a customer.']
['What are some measures that employers can take to prevent workplace violence?', '22']

['Teacher: What is the defining characteristic of violence based on traditional criminal intent in the workplace?', 'In violence based on traditional criminal intent, the perpetrator has no legitimate relationship to the business or its employees, and often the violence is part of a crime such as robbery or shoplifting.']

['What are some examples of violence based on traditional criminal intent in the workplace?', 'Violence between coworkers occurs when a current or former employee attacks another employee in the workplace.']
['What percentage of workplace homicides are attributed to worker-on-worker deaths?', 'Worker-on-worker deaths account for approximately 15 percent of all workplace homicides.']

['What are some contributing factors to workplace violence based on traditional criminal intent?', 'All companies are at risk for this type of violence, and contributing factors include failure to conduct a criminal background check as part of the hiring process.']

['Teacher: What is the common characteristic of the perpetrator in workplace violence resulting from personal relationship issues?', 'When the violence arises from problems in a personal relationship, the perpetrator often has a direct relationship not with the business but with the victim, who is an employee.']

['Teacher: What percentage of workplace homicides does violence resulting from personal relationship issues account for?', 'This category of violence accounts for slightly less than 10 percent of all workplace homicides.']

['What group of individuals tends to be the primary victims of workplace violence resulting from personal relationship issues?', 'Women are at higher risk of being victims of this type of violence than men.']

['What is an example of a scenario in which workplace violence resulting from personal relationship issues involves someone who has a legitimate relationship with the business?', 'In the fourth scenario, the violent person has a legitimate relationship with the business, perhaps as a customer or patient, and becomes violent while on the premises.']

['What are some specific industries where workplace violence resulting from personal relationship issues most often occurs?', 'A large portion of customer incidents occur in the nightclub, restaurant, and health care industries.']

['What is the approximate percentage of workplace homicides that result from workplace violence resulting from personal relationship issues in 2014?', 'In 2014, about one-fifth of all workplace homicides resulted from this type of violence.']
['What is the annual percentage increase in workplace homicides resulting from personal relationship issues from 2014 to 2018?', '23']

['Teacher: What are companies entitled to demand from their employees, including managers, in terms of decision-making?', 'Companies have a right to insist that their employees, including managers, engage in ethical decision-making.']

['What purpose do written codes of ethics or codes of conduct serve in businesses?', 'To help achieve this goal, most businesses provide a written code of ethics or code of conduct for all employees to follow.']

['What topics do codes of conduct in businesses typically cover?', 'These cover a wide variety of topics, from workplace romance and sexual harassment to hiring and termination policies, client and customer entertainment, bribery and gifts, personal trading of company shares in any way that hints of acting on insider knowledge of the company’s fortunes, outside employment, and dozens of others.']

['What are some examples of standard clauses that are typically included in a code of conduct?', 'A typical code of conduct, regardless of the company or the industry, will also contain a variety of standard clauses, often blending legal compliance and ethical considerations.']
['Teacher: What are two specific areas that deserve special mention in regards to Codes of Conduct?', 'Two areas that deserve special mention are cybersecurity and harassment.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how employees and managers can indirectly contribute to cybersecurity breaches in the context of Codes of Conduct?', 'Recent news stories have highlighted the hacking of electronic tools such as computers and databases, and employees and managers can indirectly contribute to such data breaches through unauthorized web surfing, sloppy e-mail usage, and other careless actions.']

['Teacher: How have some large companies suffered as a result of cybersecurity breaches?', 'Large companies such as Equifax, LinkedIn, Sony, Facebook, and JP Morgan Chase have suffered the theft of customer information, leading to loss of consumer confidence; sometimes large fines have been levied on companies.']

['Teacher: How can employees contribute to preventing cybersecurity breaches in the context of Codes of Conduct?', 'Employees play a part in preventing such breaches by strictly following company guidelines about data privacy and confidentiality, the use and storage of passwords, and other safeguards that limit access to only authorized users.']

['Teacher: How has the #MeToo movement impacted public awareness about harassment in the workplace?', 'We are also witnessing an increased level of public awareness about harassment in the workplace, particularly because of the #MeToo movement that followed revelations in 2017 and 2018 of years of sexual predation by powerful men in Hollywood and Washington, DC, as well as across workplaces of all kinds, including in sports and the arts.']

['Can you provide an example of how the #MeToo movement has raised awareness about harassment in workplaces outside of Hollywood and Washington, DC?', 'A victim of sexual harassment can be a man or a woman, and/or the same sex as the harasser.']

['What are some possible roles of a harasser in the workplace according to the passage?', 'The harasser can be a supervisor, coworker, other employee, officer/director, intern, consultant, or nonemployee.']

['According to the passage, what are some potential consequences of harassing and threatening behavior in the workplace?', 'Whatever the situation, harassing and threatening behavior is wrong (and sometimes criminal) and should always be reported.']

["Teacher: What is the term used to describe the act of trading securities based on nonpublic information that could impact the security's price?", 'The buying or selling of stocks, bonds, or other investments based on nonpublic information that is likely to affect the price of the security being traded is called insider trading.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a situation where insider trading may occur?', 'For example, someone who is privy to information that a company is about to be taken over, which will cause its stock price to rise when the information becomes public, may buy the stock before it goes up in order to sell it later for an enhanced profit.']

['Teacher: How can individuals who engage in insider trading benefit from their actions?', 'Likewise, someone with inside information about a coming drop in share price may sell all his or her holdings at the current price before the information is announced, avoiding the loss other shareholders will suffer when the price falls.']
['Teacher: Why is insider trading considered cheating?', 'Although insider trading can be difficult to prove, it is essentially cheating.']

['Teacher: Why does insider trading often injure other investors and undermine public confidence in the stock market?', 'It is illegal, unethical, and unfair, and it often injures other investors, as well as undermining public confidence in the stock market.']
['Teacher: Can you explain why insider trading laws are considered complex?', 'Insider trading laws are somewhat complex.']

['Teacher: What are some of the factors that contribute to the complexity of insider trading laws?', 'They have developed through federal court interpretations of Section 10(b)5 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as well as through actions by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).']
['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of the violations identified by insider trading laws?', 'The laws identify several kinds of violations.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the difference between trading by an insider and trading by someone outside of the company in terms of violations identified by insider trading laws?', 'These include trading by an insider (generally someone who performs work for the company) who possesses significant confidential information relevant to the valuation of the company’s stock, and trading by someone outside of the company who is given this sort of information by an insider or who obtains it inappropriately.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how being the messenger of material nonpublic information can be considered a violation of insider trading laws?', 'Even being the messenger (the one communicating material nonpublic information to others on behalf of someone else) can be a legal violation.']

['Teacher: Who falls under the category of an "insider" in the context of companies issuing securities?', 'The concept of an “insider” is broad and includes officers, directors, and employees of a company issuing securities.']

['Who falls under the category of a "temporary insider" and what kind of relationship do they have with a company?', 'A person can even constitute what is called a “temporary insider” if he or she temporarily assumes a unique confidential relationship with a firm and, in doing so, acquires confidential information centered on the firm’s financial and operational affairs.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of professionals who could be considered "temporary insiders"?', 'Temporary insiders can be investment bankers, brokers, attorneys, accountants, or other professionals typically thought of as outsiders, such as newspaper and television reporters.']

['Teacher: How did the famous case of insider trading, Securities and Exchange Commission v. Texas Gulf Sulphur Co. (1968), start and who was implicated in the case?', 'A famous case of insider trading, Securities and Exchange Commission v. Texas Gulf Sulphur Co. (1968), began with the discovery of the Kidd Mine and implicated the employees of Texas mining company.']
['Who discovered the Kidd Mine in the famous insider trading case of Securities and Exchange Commission v. Texas Gulf Sulphur Co. (1968) and who was implicated in the case?', '25']

['What action did the mine employees take after being notified of the discovery of the Kidd Mine in the famous insider trading case of Securities and Exchange Commission v. Texas Gulf Sulphur Co. (1968)?', 'When first notified of the discovery of a large and very valuable copper deposit, mine employees bought stock in the company while keeping the information secret.']

['What was the outcome for the mine employees after they sold their stock in the famous insider trading case of Securities and Exchange Commission v. Texas Gulf Sulphur Co. (1968)?', 'When the information was released to the public, the price of the stock went up and the employees sold their stock, making a significant amount of money.']

['What were the consequences faced by the employees involved in the famous insider trading case of Securities and Exchange Commission v. Texas Gulf Sulphur Co. (1968)?', 'The SEC and the Department of Justice prosecuted the employees for insider trading and won a conviction; the employees had to give back all the money they had made on their trades.']

['What is one reason why insider trading cases are often highly publicized, especially when charges are brought against high-profile figures?', 'Insider trading cases are often highly publicized, especially when charges are brought against high-profile figures.']
['Teacher: What is another temptation that may present itself to employees?', 'Another temptation that may present itself to employees is the offer of a bribe.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an act that an employee might be tempted to perform in exchange for a bribe?', 'A bribe is a payment in some material form (cash or noncash) for an act that runs counter to the legal or ethical culture of the work environment.']

['Teacher: What is the name of the federal law that prohibits bribery in international transactions?', 'Bribery constitutes a violation of the law in all fifty U.S. states, as well as of a federal law that prohibits bribery in international transactions, the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.']

['Teacher: How does bribery harm competitors, the government, and the free-market system?', 'Bribery generally injures not only individuals but also competitors, the government, and the free-market system as a whole.']

['Teacher: What are some potential consequences of bribery on individuals, competitors, the government, and the free-market system?', 'Of course, often the bribe is somewhat less obvious than an envelope full of money.']
['Teacher: What does the understanding of what constitutes a bribe allow individuals and organizations to do?', 'It is important, therefore, to understand what constitutes a bribe.']

['Teacher: What are some factors that help determine the ethics and legality of gift giving and receiving?', 'Numerous factors help establish the ethics (and legality) of gift giving and receiving: the value of the gift, its purpose, the circumstances under which it is given, the position of the person receiving it, company policy, and the law.']

["Teacher: How does an employee's decision-making authority affect their responsibility to act in the best interest of the company?", 'Assuming an employee has decision-making authority, the company wants and has the right to expect him or her to make choices in its best interest, not the employee’s own self-interest.']

["Teacher: How might the employee's decision-making authority be influenced by factors such as bribery and corruption?", 'For example, assume an employee has the authority to buy a copy machine for the company.']

["Teacher: How might bribery and corruption influence the employee's decision-making process when purchasing a copy machine for the company?", 'The employer wants to get the best copy machine for the best price, taking into account quality, service, warranties, and other factors.']

["Teacher: How would accepting a valuable gift card from a vendor influence the employee's decision-making process when purchasing a copy machine for the company?", 'But what if the employee accepts a valuable gift card from a vendor who sells a copy machine with higher operating and maintenance charges, and then places the order with that vendor.']
['Teacher: How does the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) address the issue of bribery and corruption in situations like this?', 'This is clearly not in the best interests of the employer.']

['Teacher: What are some potential consequences or penalties that an employee may face if they violate the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA)?', 'It constitutes a failure on the part of the employee to follow ethical and legal rules, and, in all likelihood, company policy as well.']

['What are some ways that a company can establish clear policies and procedures to ensure employees know the rules and consequences for violating them?', 'If a company wants its employees always to do the right thing, it must have policies and procedures that ensure the employees know what the rules are and the consequences for breaking them.']

['Teacher: What is the potential for violating company rules and the law when accepting a gift?', 'A gift may be only a well-intentioned token of appreciation, but the potential for violating company rules (and the law) is still present.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for companies to have a clear and well-communicated gift policy in place?', 'A well-written and effectively communicated gift policy provides guidance to company employees about what is and is not appropriate to accept from a customer or vendor and when.']

["Teacher: In addition to providing guidance on what is appropriate to accept, what other important information should a company's gift policy address?", 'This policy should clearly state whether employees are allowed to accept gifts on or outside the work premises and who may give or accept them.']

["Teacher: Why is it necessary for a company's gift policy to define the acceptable value and type of gifts?\nStudent: The value and type of gifts can vary greatly, so defining what is acceptable ensures that employees understand the boundaries and prevents potential conflicts of interest or bribery.", 'If gifts are allowed, the gift policy should define the acceptable value and type, and the circumstances under which an employee may accept a gift.']

['Teacher: Who should employees consult with if they are unsure about whether a gift is too valuable for them to accept?', 'When in doubt about whether the size or value of a gift renders it impossible for an employee to accept it, workers should be advised to check with the appropriate officer or department within their company.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of the resources that companies offer to employees for guidance on determining the acceptability of gifts?', 'Be it an “ethics hotline” or simply the human resources department, wise firms provide an easy protocol for employees to follow in determining what falls within and without the protocols for accepting gifts.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a gift policy that demonstrates strict rules and regulations, such as those implemented by the federal government?', 'As an example of a gift policy, consider the federal government’s strict rules.']

['What are the restrictions imposed by the federal government on federal employees regarding giving or accepting gifts?', '27 A federal employee may not give or solicit a contribution for a gift to an official superior and may not accept a gift from an employee receiving less pay if that employee is a subordinate.']

['What is the maximum value of a gift that a federal employee can give to their superior on annual occasions like birthdays and holidays?', 'On annual occasions when gifts are traditionally given, such as birthdays and holidays, an employee may give a superior a gift valued at less than $10.']

['What are some examples of prohibited sources from which a federal employee may not accept gifts?', 'An employee may not solicit or accept a gift given because of his or her official position, or from a prohibited source, including anyone who has or seeks official action or business with the agency.']

['What are the conditions under which a federal employee can accept gifts of less than $20?', 'In special circumstances such as holidays, and unless the frequency of the gifts would appear to be improper, an employee generally may accept gifts of less than $20.']

["What types of gifts are considered to be restricted in terms of entertainment, according to the federal government's gift policy?", 'Gifts of entertainment, such as expensive restaurant meals, are also restricted.']

["What is the requirement for reporting gifts according to the federal government's gift policy?", 'Finally, gifts must be reported when their total value from one source exceeds $390 in a calendar year.']
["What are some examples of private sector companies that have similar rules to the federal government's gift policy?", 'Some companies in the private sector follow similar rules.']

['Teacher: What is the specific ethical challenge that bribery poses for employees in the international business arenas?', 'Bribery presents a particular ethical challenge for employees in the international business arenas.']

['Teacher: How does bribery conflict with the expectations that companies have for their employees in the international business arenas?', 'Although every company wants to land lucrative contracts around the world, most expect their employees to follow both the law and company policy when attempting to consummate such deals.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) in relation to bribery in international business dealings?', 'The U.S. law prohibiting bribery in international business dealings is the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA), which is an amendment to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, one of the most important laws promoting transparency in corporate governance.']
['Teacher: When was the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) first introduced?', 'The FCPA dates to 1977 and was amended in 1988 and 1998.']

['What are some of the limitations or consequences of violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA)?', 'Its main purpose is to make it illegal for companies and their managers to influence or bribe foreign officials with monetary payments or rewards of any kind in an attempt to get or keep business opportunities outside the United States.']

['Teacher: How is the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) enforced in order to prevent and address bribery in international business dealings?', 'The FCPA is enforced through the joint efforts of the SEC and the Department of Justice.']
['Teacher: How many different countries have signed the United Nations Convention Against Corruption, which also promotes anti-bribery measures in international business?', '28']

['How does the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) define the scope of its application?', 'It applies to any act by U.S. businesses, their representatives, foreign corporations whose stock is traded in U.S. markets, and all U.S. citizens, nationals, or residents acting in furtherance of a foreign corrupt practice, whether they are physically present in the United States or not (this is called the nationality principle).']

['Teacher: Why is anti-bribery law a serious issue for companies with overseas business and cross-border sales?', 'Antibribery law is a serious issue for companies with overseas business and cross-border sales.']

['Teacher: What are the potential consequences for companies and individuals convicted of bribery in international business dealings?', 'Any companies or individuals convicted of these activities may pay significant fines, and individuals can face prison time.']

['Teacher: What does the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act prohibit regarding bribery and foreign government officials?', 'The FCPA prohibits an agent of any company incorporated in the United States from extending a bribe to a foreign government official to achieve a business advantage in that country, but it does not specifically prohibit the extension of a bribe to a private officer of a nongovernmental company in a foreign country.']

['What is the scope of the definition of a foreign government official according to the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act?', 'The definition of a foreign government official can be expansive; it includes not only those working directly for the government but also company officials if the company is owned or operated by the government.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what "facilitating or grease payments" are and how they are treated under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act?', 'An exception is made for “facilitating or grease payments,” small amounts of money paid to low-level government workers in an effort to speed routine tasks like processing paperwork or turning on electricity, but not to influence the granting of a contract.']

['Teacher: What examples can you provide to illustrate that illegal payments do not need to be in the form of cash?', 'Illegal payments need not be cash; they can include anything of value such as gifts and trips.']

['Teacher: Can you give me another example of an illegal payment that is not in the form of cash?', 'For example, BHP Billiton, a U.S. energy company, and GlaxoSmithKline, a U.K. pharmaceutical company, were each fined $25 million for buying foreign officials tickets to the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing, China.29']

['Teacher: What are some consequences that companies may face if they are found guilty of making illegal payments in forms other than cash?', 'Fines for violations like these can be large and can include civil penalties as well as forfeited profits.']

['Teacher: Can you provide any other examples of companies facing consequences for illegal payments in forms other than cash?', 'For example, Telia, a Swedish telecommunications provider whose shares are traded on Nasdaq, recently agreed to pay nearly a billion dollars ($965 million) in a settlement to resolve FCPA violations that consisted of using bribery to win business in Uzbekistan.']
['Teacher: How do companies that are found guilty of illegal payments in forms other than cash typically resolve their violations?', '30']

['Teacher: How is the potential effect of laws like the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) on employees and the companies they work for often discussed?', 'The potential effect of laws such as the FCPA that impose ethical duties on employees and the companies they work for is often debated.']

['Teacher: What are some arguments against the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) and how does it affect U.S. firms competing in foreign markets?', 'Although some believe the FCPA disadvantages U.S. firms competing in foreign markets, others say it is the backbone of an ethical free enterprise system.']

['Teacher: What are some reasons that managers in the field argue against strong enforcement of the FCPA and believe that illegal or unethical conduct is sometimes necessary for success?', 'The argument against strong enforcement of the FCPA has some merit according to managers in the field, and there is a general sense that illegal or unethical conduct is sometimes necessary for success.']

["Teacher: How do some executives, like the attorney for Cinergy, criticize the Justice Department's view on the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA)?", 'An attorney for energy-related company Cinergy summed up the feelings of many executives: “Shame on the Justice Department’s myopic view and inability to understand the realities of the world.']

['Why do some nations consider business bribery to be culturally acceptable and ignore such activities?', '”31 Some nations consider business bribery to be culturally acceptable and turn a blind eye to such activities.']

['Teacher: What is one of the arguments in favor of enforcing the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA)?', 'The argument in favor of FCPA enforcement has its supporters as well, who assert that the law not only covers the activities of U.S. companies but also levels the playing field because of its broad jurisdiction over foreign enterprises and their officials.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how other nations have responded to the United States passing the FCPA?', 'The fact is that since the United States passed the FCPA, other nations have followed suit.']

["Teacher: Why is the 1997 OECD Anti-Bribery Convention significant in the context of other nations following the United States' lead in passing the FCPA?", 'The 1997 Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) Anti-Bribery Convention has been instrumental in getting its signatories (the United Kingdom and most European Union nations) to enact stricter antibribery laws.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of the stricter antibribery laws enacted by European Union nations in response to the 1997 OECD Anti-Bribery Convention?', 'The United Kingdom adopted the Bribery Act in 2010, Canada adopted the Corruption of Foreign Officials Act of 1999, and European Union nations have done the same.']

['Teacher: How many signatories does the OECD Convention on Combating Bribery of Foreign Public Officials in International Business Transactions have?', 'There is also the OECD Convention on Combating Bribery of Foreign Public Officials in International Business Transactions, which has forty-three signatories, including all thirty-five OECD countries and eight other countries.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for companies and employees engaging in transactions in foreign markets to put ethics policies in place and enforce them?', 'Companies and employees engaging in transactions in foreign markets face an increased level of regulatory scrutiny and are well served if they put ethics policies in place and enforce them.']

['Teacher: How can companies ensure that employees at all levels follow compliance guidelines and rules when engaging in transactions in foreign markets?', 'Companies must train employees at all levels to follow compliance guidelines and rules, rather than engaging in illegal conduct such as “under the table” and “off the books” payments.']

['Teacher: What is an example of an ethical dilemma that an employee might face in the workplace besides bribery?', 'Of course, bribery is just one of many ethical dilemmas an employee might face in the workplace.']

['What are some examples of ethical dilemmas in the workplace that may not be as clearly defined as acts like bribery?', 'Not all such dilemmas are governed by the clear-cut rules generally laid out for illegal acts such as bribery.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a situation where an employee may be asked to do something legally acceptable but ethically questionable?', 'Employees may find themselves being asked to do something that is legal but not considered ethical.']

["What potential ethical issues might arise if an employee decides to use the confidential proprietary knowledge about another firm for their own firm's advantage?", 'For example, an employee might receive confidential proprietary knowledge about another firm that would give his or her firm an unfair competitive advantage.']
["Teacher: What are some common expectations that companies have regarding their employees' behavior?", 'Most companies say they want all employees to obey the law and make ethical decisions.']

['Teacher: How can companies provide the necessary guidance, training, and leadership to ensure employees make ethical decisions in the complex business environment?', 'But employees typically should not be expected to make ethical decisions based just on gut instinct; they need guidance, training, and leadership to help them navigate the maze of grey areas that present themselves daily in business.']

['Teacher: What are some ways in which companies can establish standard setting and ethical codes of conduct to provide employees with the necessary guidance in making ethical decisions in the business environment?', 'This guidance can be provided by the company through standard setting and the development of ethical codes of conduct and policies.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for senior managers to model ethical behavior and lead by direct example in a company?', 'Senior managers modeling ethical behavior and so leading by direct example also provide significant direction.']

['Teacher: What was the long-standing policy that most U.S. companies had in place regarding employees discussing their salaries?', 'For decades, most U.S. companies enforced pay secrecy, a policy that prohibits employees from disclosing or discussing salaries among themselves.']

['Teacher: Why did most U.S. companies enforce pay secrecy, prohibiting employees from discussing their salaries among themselves?', 'The reason was obvious: Companies did not want to be scrutinized for their salary decisions.']

['Teacher: How did pay secrecy prevent workers from questioning inequities in salary decisions?', 'They knew that if workers were aware of what each was paid, they would question the inequities that pay secrecy kept hidden from them.']
['Teacher: How would you describe the recent changes in the situation?', 'Recently, the situation has begun to change.']

['Teacher: Which ten states have recently enacted laws banning pay secrecy rules?', 'Ten states have enacted new laws banning employers from imposing pay secrecy rules: California, Colorado, Illinois, Louisiana, Maine, Michigan, Minnesota, New Hampshire, New Jersey, and Vermont.']
['Teacher: How many states have enacted laws banning pay secrecy rules in total?', '32']

['Teacher: What was the significant development regarding pay secrecy policies in 2012?', 'The real game changer came in 2012, when multiple decisions by the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) and various federal courts made it clear that most pay secrecy policies are unenforceable and violate federal labor law (National Labor Relations Act, 29 U.S.C. § 157-158).33']

['Teacher: Why are most pay secrecy policies unenforceable and considered a violation of federal labor law?', 'Generally speaking, labor law lends employees the right to engage in collective activities, including that of discussing with each other the specifics of their individual employment arrangements, which includes how much they are paid.']

['Teacher: How does the National Labor Relations Act protect both union and non-union employees in terms of discussing their individual employment arrangements?', 'Moreover, the applicable sections of the 1935 National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) apply to union and non-union employees, so there is no exception made for companies whose employees are non-unionized, meaning the law protects all workers.']

["Teacher: What was the purpose of President Barack Obama's executive order in 2014 regarding salary discussions among employees of federal contracting companies?", 'In 2014, President Barack Obama issued an executive order banning companies that engaged in federal contracting from prohibiting such salary discussions.']
['Teacher: How many states have enacted laws banning pay secrecy rules since 2012?', '34']

['Teacher: Why is opening up the discussion of pay important in acknowledging the desires of employees?', 'Opening up the discussion of pay acknowledges the growing desire of employees to be well informed and to have the freedom to question or criticize their company.']

['What is one potential factor that has contributed to the growing desire of employees to be well informed and have the freedom to question or criticize their company?', 'Social media can be a likely answer.']

["What protections are in place to support employees' rights to discuss their salaries on social media platforms?", 'Protections generally extend to salary discussions on Facebook or Twitter or Instagram; Section 7 of the NRLA protects two or more employees who act together or discuss improving their terms and conditions of employment in person or online, just as it does in other settings.']
['Teacher: Do you feel comfortable expressing your opinions on social media?', 'Generally, no.']
["Teacher: Why do you think you don't feel comfortable expressing your opinions on social media?", 'That answer may surprise those who believe that the First Amendment protects all speech.']

["Teacher: What is the student's view on the role of the First Amendment in protecting speech on social media?", 'The Bill of Rights was created to protect citizens from an overreaching government, not from their employer.']
['Teacher: How does the student believe the First Amendment applies to protection of speech on social media in relation to employers?', 'The First Amendment reads as follows:']

['Teacher: What do the key words "Congress shall make no law" in the passage imply about the control of speech by the government and politicians?', 'The key words are “Congress shall make no law,” meaning the content of speech is something the government and politicians cannot control with laws or policies.']

['Teacher: How does the right to free speech, as stated in the passage, differ between the government and private sector workplace?', 'However, this right of free speech is generally not applicable to the private sector workplace and does not cover criticism of your employer.']
['Teacher: Are there any circumstances in which you should not speak out on social media?', 'Yes, under most circumstances.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a situation where speaking out on social media could lead to negative consequences?', 'Therefore, if someone posts a message on social media that says, “My boss is a jerk” or “My company is a terrible place to work,” the likelihood is that the person can be fired without any recourse, assuming he or she is an employee at will (see the discussion of at-will employment earlier in this chapter).']

["Teacher: What is the potential consequence of speaking out on social media about one's employer or workplace?", 'Unless the act of firing constitutes a violation under federal law, such as Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the speech is not protected speech, and thus the speaker (the employee) is not protected.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what is the recommended approach for handling disputes or grievances with our companies or supervisors on social media?', 'At some point, all of us may get angry with our companies or supervisors, but we still have a duty to keep our disputes in-house and not make public any situations we are attempting to resolve internally.']

['Teacher: Why should employees keep their disputes with their companies or supervisors in-house instead of making them public on social media?', 'Employers typically are prohibited from discussing human resource matters relating to any specific employees.']

['Teacher: What is the significance of employees keeping their complaints confidential unless and until crimes are charged or civil suits are filed?', 'Employees, too, should keep complaints confidential unless and until crimes are charged or civil suits are filed.']

['Teacher: What is the current status of the rules related to social media and their applicability to criticizing an employer?', 'The rules related to social media are evolving, but applicable laws do not generally distinguish between sites or locations in which someone might criticize an employer, so criticism of the boss remains largely unprotected speech.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of the type of speech that is protected by federal statute when criticizing an employer on social media?', 'As discussed earlier, employees can go online and post information about wages, hours, and working conditions, and that speech is protected by federal statute.']

['Teacher: How does the NLRA protect employees when it comes to speech that concerns terms and conditions of employment?', 'So, although some general complaints against employers are not protected under the First Amendment, they may be protected under the NLRA (because arguably they may be related to terms and conditions of employment).']

['Teacher: Can you explain why statements personally critical of the boss or the company, unrelated to wages and working conditions, are not protected under the NLRA or the First Amendment?', 'However, most courts agree that statements personally critical of the boss or the company on a basis other than wages and working conditions are not protected.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for employees to refrain from posting false or misleading information about their employer on social media?', 'Obviously, there is no protection when employees post false or misleading information on social media in an attempt to harm the company’s reputation or that of management.']

['Teacher: How is the act of whistleblowing different from everyday criticism?', 'The act of whistleblowing—going to an official government agency and disclosing an employer’s violation of the law—is different from everyday criticism.']
['Teacher: Why is whistleblowing largely viewed as a public service?', 'In fact, whistleblowing is largely viewed as a public service because it helps society reduce bad workplace behavior.']

['Teacher: What are some potential challenges that individuals may face when taking on the role of a whistleblower?', 'Being a whistleblower is not easy, however, and someone inclined to act as one should expect many hurdles.']
['What is one of the potential consequences for a whistleblower if their identity becomes known?', 'If a whistleblower’s identity becomes known, his or her revelations may amount to career suicide.']

["Teacher: How can the fear of retaliation impact a whistleblower's decision to come forward with information?", 'Even if they keep their job, whistleblowers often are not promoted, and they may face resentment not only from management but also from rank-and-file workers who fear the loss of their own jobs.']

['What are some potential rewards for individuals who choose to become whistleblowers?', 'Whistleblowers may also be blacklisted, making it difficult for them to get a job at a different firm, and all as a result of doing what is ethical.']

['Teacher: What is an important factor to consider before making the decision to blow the whistle on your employer?', 'Blowing the whistle on your employer is thus a big decision with significant ramifications.']

['Teacher: What are some reasons why employees would not want to cover up unethical or illegal conduct?', 'However, most employees do not want to cover up unethical or illegal conduct, nor should they.']

['Teacher: What are the recommended motives for blowing the whistle on unethical or illegal conduct, according to ethicists?', 'Ethicists say it should be done with an appropriate motive—to get the company to comply with the law or to protect potential victims—and not to get revenge on a boss at whom you are angry.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for employees to report wrongdoing even if they have a personal revenge motive?', 'Of course, even if an employee has a personal revenge motive, if the company actively is breaking the law, it is still important that the wrongdoing be reported.']

['Why do employees find it challenging to know when and how to blow the whistle on their employer?', 'In any case, knowing when and how to blow the whistle is a challenge for an employee wanting to do the right thing.']

['Teacher: What is the recommended initial step for an employee who wants to blow the whistle on a problem within their organization?', 'The employee should usually try internal reporting channels first, to disclose the problem to management before going public.']

['Teacher: Why do you think it is important for employees to try internal reporting channels before going public with a whistleblower complaint?', 'Sometimes workers mistakenly identify something as wrongdoing that was not wrongdoing after all.']

['Teacher: What are some potential benefits of allowing management to investigate and address the issue before going public with a whistleblower complaint?', 'Internal reporting gives management a chance to start an investigation and attempt to rectify the situation.']

['Teacher: Why should an employee have hard evidence and a serious violation before going to the government with a whistleblower complaint?', 'The employee who goes to the government should also have some kind of hard evidence that wrongful actions have occurred; the violation should be serious, and blowing the whistle should have some likelihood of stopping the wrongful act.']

['Teacher: What are some measures provided by federal laws to protect workers who report injuries, concerns, or other protected activity from employer retaliation?', 'Under many federal laws, an employer cannot retaliate by firing, demoting, or taking any other adverse action against workers who report injuries, concerns, or other protected activity.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a federal law that includes whistleblower protection provisions?', 'One of the first laws with a specific whistleblower protection provision was the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of the topics covered by the whistleblower protection provisions in the expanded federal laws?', 'Since passage of that law, Congress has expanded whistleblower authority to protect workers who report violations of more than twenty different federal laws across various topics.']

['Teacher: What is the significance of whistleblowing protections being granted by individual statutes rather than having an all-purpose whistleblower protection?', '(There is no all-purpose whistleblower protection; it must be granted by individual statutes.)']

['Teacher: In what area can a sample of specific laws that protect whistleblowing employees be found?', 'A sample of the specific laws under which whistleblowing employees are protected can be found in the environmental area, where it is in the public interest for employees to report violations of the law to the authorities, which, in turn, helps the average citizen concerned about clean air and water.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a specific law that protects whistleblowing employees in the environmental area?', 'The Clean Air Act protects any employee reporting air emission violations from area, stationary, and mobile sources from any retaliation for such reporting.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why it is in the public interest for employees to report violations of the law to the authorities in the environmental area?', 'Act similarly protects from retaliation any employee who reports alleged violations relating to discharge of pollutants into water.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for government regulators to have the assistance of employees who witness violations occurring?', 'Without the help of employees who are “on the ground” and see the violations occur, it could be difficult for government regulators to always find the source of pollution.']

["Teacher: Why do whistleblowers' revelations, even when not completely altruistic, still deserve public attention?", 'Even when whistleblowers are not acting completely altruistically, their revelations may still be true and worthy of being brought to the public’s attention.']

['Teacher: How can whistleblowers be considered stewards of the public interest?', 'Thus, in such situations, the responsible employee becomes a steward of the public interest, and we all should want whistleblowers to come forward.']

['Teacher: How should the society view whistleblowers who expose wrongdoing but might have other motives besides pure altruism?', 'Yet not all whistleblowers are white knights, and not all their firms are evil dragons worthy of being slain.']

['Teacher: What are some potential benefits, both monetary and non-monetary, an employee can gain from blowing the whistle?', 'Blowing the whistle may bring the employee more than just intrinsic ethical rewards; it may also result in cash.']

['Teacher: Can you explain more about the False Claims Act and how it provides monetary benefits to whistleblowers?', 'The most lucrative law under which employees can blow the whistle is the False Claims Act (FCA), 31 U.S.C. §§ 3729–3733.']

['Teacher: Why did Congress pass the False Claims Act during the American Civil War?', 'This legislation was enacted in 1863, during the American Civil War, because Congress was worried that suppliers of goods to the Union Army might cheat the government.']

['Teacher: How has the False Claims Act evolved over time since its enactment during the American Civil War?', 'The FCA has been amended many times since then, and today it serves as a leading example of a statutory law that remains important after more than 150 years.']

['Teacher: What are the potential consequences for individuals who knowingly submit false claims to the government under the False Claims Act?', 'The FCA provides that any person who knowingly submits false claims to the government must pay a civil penalty for each false claim, plus triple the amount of the government’s damages.']

['Teacher: How does the False Claims Act determine the amount of the civil penalty for individuals who knowingly submit false claims to the government?', 'The amount of this basic civil penalty is regularly adjusted by the cost of living, and the current penalty range is from $5500 to $11,000.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of the qui tam provision in the law regarding whistleblowing?', 'More importantly for our discussion, the qui tam provision of the law allows private persons (called relators) to file lawsuits for violations of the FCA on behalf of the government and to receive part of any penalty imposed.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the qui tam provision allows private individuals to participate in whistleblowing cases?', 'The person bringing the action is a type of a whistleblower, but one who initiates legal action on his or her own rather than simply reporting it to a government agency.']

['Teacher: What is the potential financial reward for a relator (whistleblower) if the government decides to intervene in a qui tam lawsuit?', 'If the government believes it is a worthwhile case and intervenes in the lawsuit, then the relator (whistleblower) is entitled to receive between 15 and 25 percent of the amount the government recovers.']

['Teacher: What factors determine whether the government decides to intervene in a qui tam lawsuit or not?', 'If the government thinks winning is a long shot and declines to intervene in the lawsuit, the relator’s share increases to 25 to 30 percent.']

['Teacher: What can you tell me about the financial outcomes for some whistleblowers mentioned in the passage?', 'A few whistleblowers have become rich (and famous, thanks to an ABC News story), with awards ranging in the neighborhood of $100 million.']
['Teacher: How much money did whistleblowers mentioned in the passage receive as awards for their actions?', '38']

['Where does Bradley Birkenfeld work and how much money was he awarded?', 'In 2012, a single whistleblower, Bradley Birkenfeld, a former UBS employee, was awarded $104 million by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), making him the most highly rewarded whistleblower in history.']

["What was Bradley Birkenfeld's role in the tax fraud he reported, and what were the consequences he faced as a result?", 'Birkenfeld also spent time in prison for participating in the tax fraud he reported.']
['What did the ten former Pfizer employees receive $102 million for?', 'In 2009, ten former Pfizer employees were awarded $102 million for exposing an illegal promotion of prescription medications.']

['What were the financial outcomes for John Kopchinski and the other whistleblowers involved in the illegal promotion of prescription medications at Pfizer?', 'John Kopchinski, the original whistleblower and one of the ten, received $50 million.']

['What company was involved in the case of Medicare fraud and how much money did the two whistleblowers receive as a result?', 'In another case involving the health care company HCA, two employees who blew the whistle on Medicare fraud ended up receiving a combined total of $100 million.']

['Teacher: What are the factors that should capture your attention when considering the rewards of whistleblowing in addition to the size of the reward?', 'It is not just the size of the reward that should get your attention but also the amount of money these employees saved taxpayers and/or shareholders.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of the ways in which whistleblowing can impact taxpayers, government revenues, and private health insurance?', 'They turned in companies that were cheating the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (affecting taxpayers), the IRS (affecting government revenues), and private health insurance (affecting premiums).']
["Teacher: How does the impact of whistleblowing on the public's savings compare to the rewards received by whistleblowers?", 'The public saved far more than the reward paid to the whistleblowers.']

["Teacher: What is the role of Birkenfeld's and Eckard's rewards in relation to the U.S. government's whistleblower programs according to Stephen Kohn?", 'Incredibly high rewards such as the aforementioned are somewhat unusual, but according to National Whistleblower Center director Stephen Kohn, “Birkenfeld’s and Eckard’s rewards act like advertisements for the U.S. government’s whistleblower programs, which make hundreds of rewards every year.']

['What are the four laws under which whistleblowers can receive a reward, as mentioned in the passage?', '”39 The FCA is one of four laws under which whistleblowers can receive a reward; the others are administered by the IRS, the SEC, and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.']

['What is the process for whistleblowers to receive their rewards, as explained in the passage?', 'Most whistleblowers do not get paid until the lawsuit and all appeals have concluded and the full amount of any monetary penalty has been paid to the government.']

['What is the potential downside for whistleblowers in terms of receiving their rewards, as mentioned in the passage?', 'Many complex cases of business fraud can go on for several years before a verdict is rendered and appealed (or a settlement is reached).']

['What is the potential risk for whistleblowers in terms of their reputation, as discussed in the passage?', 'An employee whose identity has been disclosed and who has been unofficially blacklisted may not see any reward money for several years.']

['Teacher: What is one alternative option employees may consider before deciding to become a whistleblower?', 'Sometimes employees, including managers, face an ethical dilemma that they seek to address from within rather than becoming a whistleblower.']

['Teacher: Why would it be beneficial for companies to encourage employees to report wrongdoing to their superiors rather than becoming a whistleblower?', 'However, companies should want and expect employees to step forward and report wrongdoing to their superiors, and they should support that decision, not punish it.']

['Teacher: What is an example of a financial industry executive who was not considered a whistleblower?', 'Sallie Krawcheck, a financial industry executive, was not a whistleblower in either the classical or the legal sense.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for employees to have legal protection under whistleblower statutes if they choose to report wrongdoing to their superiors instead of becoming a whistleblower?', 'She went to her boss with her discovery of wrongdoing at work, which means she had no legal protection under whistleblower statutes.']
["Teacher: What can we learn about Sallie Krawcheck's situation from reading the story in the following box?", 'Read her story in the following box.']

['Teacher: What is one notable difference in workplace diversity between the twenty-first century and previous generations?', 'The twenty-first century workplace features much greater diversity than was common even a couple of generations ago.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of the specific types of diversity that are now more commonly seen in the twenty-first century workplace?', 'Individuals who might once have faced employment challenges because of religious beliefs, ability differences, or sexual orientation now regularly join their peers in interview pools and on the job.']

["Teacher: How does the increased diversity in the workplace impact employees' perspectives and knowledge?", 'Each may bring a new outlook and different information to the table; employees can no longer take for granted that their coworkers think the same way they do.']

['Teacher: How can the diversity in the workplace lead to a more innovative and creative work environment?', 'This pushes them to question their own assumptions, expand their understanding, and appreciate alternate viewpoints.']
['How does having a more creative work environment benefit the company as a whole?', 'The result is more creative ideas, approaches, and solutions.']
['Why is it important for companies to have diverse perspectives in their decision-making processes?', 'Thus, diversity may also enhance corporate decision-making.']

['Teacher: According to David Rock, director of the Neuro-Leadership Institute in New York City, what is the outcome of communicating with those who differ from us in the workplace?', 'Communicating with those who differ from us may require us to make an extra effort and even change our viewpoint, but it leads to better collaboration and more favorable outcomes overall, according to David Rock, director of the Neuro-Leadership Institute in New York City, who says diverse coworkers “challenge their own and others’ thinking.']

['What does the concept of workplace diversity encompass according to the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM)?', '”2 According to the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM), organizational diversity now includes more than just racial, gender, and religious differences.']

['What are some factors that are encompassed by the concept of workplace diversity, according to the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM)?', 'It also encompasses different thinking styles and personality types, as well as other factors such as physical and cognitive abilities and sexual orientation, all of which influence the way people perceive the world.']

["According to an SHRM article, what are some key business goals for today's leaders in relation to workplace diversity?", '“Finding the right mix of individuals to work on teams, and creating the conditions in which they can excel, are key business goals for today’s leaders, given that collaboration has become a paradigm of the twenty-first century workplace,” according to an SHRM article.']
["What are some key business goals for today's leaders in relation to workplace diversity, according to an SHRM article?", '3']

['Teacher: Why is attracting workers who are not all alike an important first step in the process of achieving greater diversity?', 'Attracting workers who are not all alike is an important first step in the process of achieving greater diversity.']
['Teacher: What are some reasons why attracting workers who are not all alike is an important first step in the process of achieving greater diversity?', 'However, managers cannot stop there.']

['Teacher: What is another important aspect of achieving greater diversity that managers need to consider in addition to attracting workers who are not all alike?', 'Their goals must also encompass inclusion, or the engagement of all employees in the corporate culture.']

['What is the challenge that managers need to address in order to achieve diversity once workers are hired?', '“The far bigger challenge is how people interact with each other once they’re on the job,” says Howard J. Ross, founder and chief learning officer at Cook Ross, a consulting firm specializing in diversity.']
['How does Howard J. Ross define diversity and inclusion in the workplace?', '“Diversity is being invited to the party; inclusion is being asked to dance.']
['What does Howard J. Ross suggest is the difference between diversity and inclusion in the workplace?', 'Diversity is about the ingredients, the mix of people and perspectives.']

['What analogy does Howard J. Ross use to differentiate between diversity and inclusion in the workplace?', 'Inclusion is about the container—the place that allows employees to feel they belong, to feel both accepted and different.”']
['What is the primary focus of inclusion in the workplace, according to Howard J. Ross?', '4']

['Teacher: When did the origins of workplace diversity start?', 'Workplace diversity is not a new policy idea; its origins date back to at least the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (CRA) or before.']

['Teacher: What was the percentage of women in the civilian workforce when Title VII of the Civil Rights Act was passed?', 'Census figures show that women made up less than 29 percent of the civilian workforce when Congress passed Title VII of the CRA prohibiting workplace discrimination.']
['What was the purpose of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act in relation to workplace diversity?', 'After passage of the law, gender diversity in the workplace expanded significantly.']

['Teacher: How did the percentage of women in the labor force change from 1977 to 1999, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS)?', 'According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), the percentage of women in the labor force increased from 48 percent in 1977 to a peak of 60 percent in 1999.']

['What has been the trend in the percentage of women in the labor force in the past five years, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS)?', 'Over the last five years, the percentage has held relatively steady at 57 percent.']

['What has been the change in the total number of women in the labor force over the past forty years, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS)?', 'Over the past forty years, the total number of women in the labor force has risen from 41 million in 1977 to 71 million in 2017.5']

['What does the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) project about the number of women in the U.S. labor force in 2050?', 'The BLS projects that the number of women in the U.S. labor force will reach 92 million in 2050 (an increase that far outstrips population growth).']

['Teacher: How does the statistical data reveal the trend for African American, Asian American, and Hispanic workers?', 'The statistical data show a similar trend for African American, Asian American, and Hispanic workers.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some specifics about the percentages of minorities in the workforce prior to the passage of the CRA in 1964?', 'Just before passage of the CRA in 1964, the percentages of minorities in the official on-the-books workforce were relatively small compared with their representation in the total population.']

['Teacher: What do the statistics reveal about the representation of African Americans, Asian Americans, and Hispanic workers in the workforce in the 1960s?', 'In 1966, Asians accounted for just 0.5 percent of private-sector employment, with Hispanics at 2.5 percent and African Americans at 8.2 percent.6']

['Teacher: How have the employment numbers for Hispanic workers changed since the passage of the CRA in 1964?', 'However, Hispanic employment numbers have significantly increased since the CRA became law; they are expected to more than double from 15 percent in 2010 to 30 percent of the labor force in 2050.']

['What percentage of the labor force are Hispanic workers projected to make up in 2050, compared to their representation in 2010?', 'Similarly, Asian Americans are projected to increase their share from 5 to 8 percent between 2010 and 2050.']
["Teacher: What is the student's opinion regarding workplace diversity progress?", 'Much more progress remains to be made, however.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the student believes there is still progress to be made in workplace diversity, despite the perception of open-mindedness in the technology sector?', 'For example, many people think of the technology sector as the workplace of open-minded millennials.']
