['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of environmental justice and how it relates to the movement seeking legal recognition for chimpanzees?', 'This is analogous to the effort called environmental justice, an attempt to do the same for the environment (discussed in the section on Environmental Justice in Three Special Stakeholders: Society, the Environment, and Government).']

['Teacher: What is the name of the nonprofit organization in Florida that is advocating for the legal recognition and rights of chimpanzees?', 'A nonprofit organization in Florida, the Nonhuman Rights Project, is an animal advocacy group that has hired attorneys to present a theory in court that two chimpanzees (Tommy and Kiko) have the legal standing and right to be freed from cages to live in an outdoor sanctuary.']

['Teacher: What legal right are the attorneys from the Nonhuman Rights Project seeking for the chimpanzees Tommy and Kiko?', 'In this case, the attorneys have been trying for years to get courts to grant the chimps habeas corpus (Latin for “you shall have the body”), a right people have under the U.S. Constitution when held against their will.']
["What is the current status of the attorneys' efforts to obtain habeas corpus rights for the chimpanzees Tommy and Kiko?", 'To date, this effort has been unsuccessful.']
['Teacher: Can you explain why the effort to obtain habeas corpus rights for the chimpanzees Tommy and Kiko has been unsuccessful so far?', '45']

['What argument do the courts make to justify extending certain constitutional rights to corporations?', 'The courts have extended certain constitutional rights to corporations, such as the First Amendment right to free speech (in the 2010 Citizens United case).']

['What logical extension can be made from the concept of extending constitutional rights to corporations to the idea of animals and the environment having rights?', 'Therefore, some reason, a logical extension of that concept would hold that animals and the environment have rights as well.']

['Teacher: What is the difference in approach between the United States and about forty other nations with regards to laws protecting animals in cosmetic testing?', 'In cosmetic testing, the United States has relatively few laws protecting animals, whereas about forty other nations have taken more direct action.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a direct action taken by one of the forty other nations to protect animals in cosmetic testing?', 'In 2013, the European Union banned animal testing for cosmetics and the marketing and sale of cosmetics tested on animals.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how the United States differs from Norway and Switzerland in terms of laws protecting animals in cosmetic testing?', 'Norway and Switzerland passed similar laws.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a country outside of Europe that has passed laws to ban or limit cosmetic animal testing?', 'Outside Europe, a variety of other nations, including Guatemala, India, Israel, New Zealand, South Korea, Taiwan, and Turkey, have also passed laws to ban or limit cosmetic animal testing.']

['Teacher: What would be the consequence for U.S. cosmetic companies if they do not change their practices regarding animal testing in the countries mentioned?', 'U.S. cosmetic companies will not be able to sell their products in any of these countries unless they change their practices.']
['What is the name of the organization that certifies cosmetic companies as cruelty-free and ensures they do not conduct animal testing?', 'The Humane Cosmetics']
['What does the Humane Cosmetics Act seek to accomplish in terms of animal testing by cosmetic companies?', 'Act has been introduced but not yet passed by Congress.']

['What impact would the passing of the Humane Cosmetics Act have on animal testing in the United States?', 'If enacted, it would end cosmetics testing on animals in the United States and ban the import of animal-tested cosmetics.']

['What would be the possible impact on animal testing in the United States if the Humane Cosmetics Act is not passed by Congress?', '46 However, in the current antiregulatory environment, passage seems unlikely.']

['Teacher: What does the Humane Society of the United States propose as an alternative approach to conducting animal research and testing?', 'According to the Humane Society of the United States, a more realistic alternative approach is to develop nonanimal tests that could provide more human safety data, including information about cancer and birth defects related to new products.']
['What impact can consumer pressure have on the regulation of animal research and testing?', 'Consumer pressure can also influence change.']

["How can consumer preferences for cruelty-free cosmetics and opposition to animal testing influence businesses' practices?", 'If consumer purchases demonstrate a preference for cruelty-free cosmetics and support ending cosmetics animal testing, businesses will get the message.']

['What are some examples of companies that have stopped testing cosmetics on animals?', 'Almost one hundred companies have already ceased testing cosmetics on animals, including The Body Shop, Burt’s Bees, E.L.F.']
['What are some other companies that have stopped testing cosmetics on animals?', 'Cosmetics, Lush, and Tom’s of Maine.']

['Which organizations maintain lists of companies that have stopped testing cosmetics on animals?', 'Lists of such firms are maintained by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals and similar organizations.']
['How many companies have stopped testing cosmetics on animals?', '50']

['Teacher: How might companies benefit from adapting to the increasing level of public awareness and consumer expectations in regards to the use of animals in research and testing, especially considering the incorporation of pets in almost every aspect of life within U.S. culture?', 'Companies will be wise to adapt to the increasing level of public awareness and consumer expectations, not least because U.S. culture now incorporates pets in almost every aspect of life.']

["How can the incorporation of pets in almost every aspect of life in U.S. culture contribute to companies' need to adapt to increasing public awareness and consumer expectations regarding animal research and testing?", 'Dogs, cats, and other animals function as therapy pets for patients and those experiencing stress; an Uber-style dog service will bring dogs to work or school for a few minutes of companionship.']

['In what ways do the presence of therapy pets, service animals, and pets in public places like restaurants, campuses, and workplaces contribute to the need for companies to adapt to increasing public awareness and consumer expectations regarding animal research and testing?', 'Pets visit hospitals and act as service animals, appearing in restaurants, campuses, and workplaces where they would have been prohibited as recently as ten years ago.']

["What is one significant statistic that reflects the increasing presence of pets in U.S. households and the subsequent impact on companies' need to adapt to public awareness and consumer expectations regarding animal research and testing?", 'According to the American Pet Products Association (APPA), a trade group, two-thirds of U.S. households own a pet, and pet industry sales have tripled in the past fifteen years.']

['What is the projected annual spending on pets in the U.S. by 2018, according to the American Pet Products Association (APPA)?', '51 The APPA estimates U.S. spending on pets will reach almost $70 billion a year by 2018.']
['Teacher: According to the passage, what is the general sentiment towards pets?', '“People are fascinated by pets.']

['Teacher: How are pets often treated and regarded by their owners, as mentioned in the passage?', 'We act and spend on them as if they were our children,” says New York University sociology professor Colin Jerolmack, who studies animals in society.']
['Teacher: According to the passage, what percentage of households in the United States own pets?', '52']

['According to the passage, what are some examples of industries that have emerged as people increasingly want to include pets in all aspects of life?', 'As people increasingly want to include pets in all aspects of life, new and different industries have emerged and will continue to do so, such as tourism centered on the presence of pets and retail opportunities such as health insurance for animals, upscale stores, and new products specifically tailored for pets.']

['According to the passage, why do businesses need to pay attention to the trend of increased interest in pets?', 'With interest in pets at an all-time high, businesses cannot ignore the trend, either in terms of revenue to be earned or in terms of the ethical treatment of their fellow animals in laboratories.']

['Teacher: What does the passage suggest about the portrayal of entrepreneurship in the media?', 'Although the risk of failure associated with starting a business is real and even high, we hear much in the media about success stories and little about those entrepreneurs who crash and burn.']

["What does the student suggest is the reason behind the media's focus on success stories in entrepreneurship rather than failures?", 'Perhaps the allure of entrepreneurship inevitably outshines any mention of the downside.']
['What does the passage suggest about the level of risk associated with start-ups?', 'Still, start-ups impose a higher than normal degree of risk, and we turn to the evidence for this now.']

['Teacher: According to business consultant Patrick Henry, what percentage of venture-backed startups fail?', 'Different studies yield different results, but business consultant Patrick Henry reported that “75 percent of venture-backed startups fail.”']

['Teacher: Can you provide more information about the study by Shikhar Ghosh that Patrick Henry mentioned?', 'Henry added that “this statistic is based on a Harvard Business School study by Shikhar Ghosh.']

['Teacher: What were the failure rates for U.S. companies after five years and ten years, according to the study by Statistical Brain?', 'In a study by Statistical Brain, ‘Startup Business Failure Rate by Industry,’ the failure rate of all U.S. companies after five years was over 50 percent, and over 70 percent after ten years.”']
['What do these statistics about the failure rates of venture-backed startups and U.S. companies indicate about the risks of entrepreneurship?', '1']

["Teacher: What might the figure mentioned in the passage do to the enthusiasm of a would-be entrepreneur who solely relies on an exciting or novel concept for their company's success?", 'This figure might be enough to chill the enthusiasm of any would-be entrepreneur who believes an exciting or novel concept is enough to support a successful company with a minimal amount of time and effort and a great deal of other people’s money.']

["Teacher: Considering the expansion of start-ups in the United States, how does this information relate to the potential risks for entrepreneurs relying solely on an exciting or novel concept for their company's success?", 'Still, the ranks of start-ups expand prodigiously each month in the United States.']

['Teacher: What kind of pitfall should even financially successful start-ups be watchful for?', 'Even start-ups that beat the odds financially need to be watchful for a different sort of pitfall, an ethical failure that can be nourished by the very strengths that allow a company to get off the ground.']

['Teacher: What is the potential pitfall that financially successful start-ups should be cautious of, which can arise from the strengths that helped them establish their company?', 'That pitfall is the hubris or excessive pride that may characterize some entrepreneurs, particularly after they have had some initial success.']

['What is an example of a start-up that became a victim of hubris after achieving initial success?', 'Uber, an application-based, ride-hailing service, was founded in San Francisco by Travis Kalanick and Garrett Camp in 2009.']
['What were the founders of Uber able to successfully match with their idea?', 'If ever an idea matched the success potential of smartphones, it was this one.']

["What factors contributed to the success and widespread adoption of Uber's service?", 'Offering a cheaper and more convenient service than hailing a cab on city streets, Uber was valued at $70 billion in 2017 and operated, with varying degrees of success, in seventy countries at that point.']

["What aspect of Uber's corporate culture became a cause for concern in early 2017, according to an engineer's blog post?", 'However, the corporate culture, especially at headquarters, left many observers aghast in early 2017 after an Uber engineer, Susan Fowler, blogged about her experiences there.']

["What were some of the concerning elements of Uber's corporate culture that were revealed by other employees?", 'Other employees substantiated much of her account, revealing an atmosphere rife with misogyny, homophobia, and sexual harassment.']

["Teacher: How would you describe the workplace culture under Kalanick's leadership, as mentioned in the passage?", 'This culture was permitted—even fostered—by Kalanick, who reigned unchecked for several years over what the New York Times labeled an “aggressive, unrestrained workplace culture.”']
['What kind of workplace culture did Kalanick foster during his time as a leader?', '2']

["What effect did the lack of attention to the muted grumblings within the company have on Kalanick's reputation as a leader?", 'Muted grumblings from quarters within the company never received much attention outside the firm, allowing Kalanick to become a high-flying role model for would-be entrepreneurs who wished to emulate his success.']

["How did the lack of attention to the muted grumblings affect Kalanick's leadership position?", 'A reckoning finally arrived when Uber’s board of directors asked him to resign his position as chief executive officer in June 2017.']
['Teacher: Can you explain the similar workplace culture prevalent during his time at Uber?', 'Yet the workplace culture that prevailed during his years at the company was not unique to Uber.']
['Teacher: Can you provide examples of other firms that have also experienced a similar workplace culture?', 'Many firms have experienced it.']

['Teacher: What is one specific ethical challenge that many successful businesses, especially hard-riding start-ups, face when it comes to workplace culture?', 'Holding destructive egos in check is an ethical challenge at many successful businesses, particularly at hard-riding start-ups.']

['How can the attitudes and visible treatment of employees, customers, and clients by founders and their start-up teams shape the company they are building?', 'Founders and their start-up teams need to be aware of how deeply their attitudes toward others; their visible treatment of employees, customers, and clients; and their display of fairness will come to shape the company they are building.']

['What is the importance of establishing the right protocols and ethical practices from the beginning, rather than waiting until the company is financially stable?', 'It is not enough for the founders to hypothesize, “we’ll get around to establishing the right protocols after we’re solvent.”']

['Why is it important for founders to prioritize the establishment of the right protocols and ethical practices from the beginning, rather than relying on financial stability or assuming that standards of courteous business practice will naturally emerge?', 'Nor is it adequate to insist that standards of courteous business practice will naturally emerge on their own.']

['What impact can the establishment of an initial culture of ethics or its absence have on a start-up from its first day of business?', 'An initial culture either of ethics or its absence will set a tone from the first day of business.']

['What can happen if founders have the belief that they do not need to adhere to ethical practices due to their own intelligence or self-assurance?', 'If the founders believe these niceties are not required of them owing to their genius or confidence, such arrogance will displace ethics as a best practice.']
['What is the consequence of founders deceiving themselves into thinking that ethical practices are not necessary for their start-up?', 'To believe otherwise is self-deception.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a start-up that is still highly regarded and admired by many individuals today?', 'A legendary example of a start-up that still inspires many today is the Hewlett-Packard Corporation (HP).']

['Teacher: How did Bill Hewlett and David Packard contribute to the founding of Hewlett-Packard Corporation?', 'Its origins lie in the efforts of Bill Hewlett and David Packard, two Stanford University classmates in the 1930s.']

['Teacher: How has Hewlett-Packard Corporation evolved from its humble beginnings in a garage to where it is today?', 'Much like members of a garage band, they started their company in a real garage, and the firm has outgrown its humble beginnings many times over.']
["Teacher: That's great to hear! Can you explain why start-ups are often seen as exciting?", 'Start-ups are exciting.']

['Teacher: What are some factors that contribute to start-ups being seen as exciting, such as the late Steve Jobs of Apple and their profitability?', 'Many of their founders, like the late Steve Jobs of Apple, attain near-rock star status, and the companies can generate enormous profit.']

["Teacher: That's a very insightful point you made about the hard work and failures involved in start-ups. Can you provide an example of a successful entrepreneur who experienced failures before achieving success?", 'Yet we often overlook the fact that even some of the most successful entrepreneurs experience many failures before they succeed, and long hours of hard work are typically required even for these failures.']

['Can you elaborate on why it is important for entrepreneurs to learn from their failures, even though the process can be painful and time-consuming?', 'Smart entrepreneurs learn from their failures, but each lesson can be painful, frustrating, and time consuming.']

['Teacher: What kind of personality is required to weather the stresses and strains of a start-up and pursue the goal of success for the firm, even at the cost of personal or collective sacrifices?', 'A unique personality is required to weather the stresses and strains of a start-up, and it is a personality that tolerates much personal deprivation as it pursues the perceived highest goal of all, success for the firm, no matter what personal or collective costs might be entailed.']

['What are some of the personal and collective sacrifices that individuals may have to make while pursuing success for a start-up?', 'The culture of entrepreneurialism allows for many business leaders and their staffs to be deprived of a portion of their humanity along the way to success.']

['What is the preeminent ethical consideration when considering the personal and collective sacrifices involved in pursuing success for a start-up?', 'Thus, a preeminent ethical consideration is whether the result justifies this cost.']

['How important is it for entrepreneurs to be aware of the potential sacrifices they may have to make while pursuing success for a start-up?', 'At the very least, determined entrepreneurs must be advised of these possible sacrifices.']

['What is the impact of personal and collective sacrifices on the individuals involved in pursuing success for a start-up?', 'They constitute the collateral damage of entrepreneurial dreams that any ambitious start-up founder should contemplate.']

['Teacher: Why is it inevitable for a start-up to change as it grows, acquires new locations, and hires more employees?', 'Even if a start-up becomes what its founders wish it to be—astronomically successful—inevitably it will change as it grows, acquires new locations, and hires more employees.']

['Teacher: What are some potential consequences of a start-up becoming successful and experiencing growth, acquiring new locations, and hiring more employees?', 'These changes may eventually produce an organization with added layers—essentially, a hardened bureaucracy that slows down and complicates the management process.']

['Teacher: What are some potential repercussions of the company losing its ability to make essential decisions quickly and efficiently?', 'The company may no longer make essential decisions with the speed and nimbleness that once were possible.']

['What are some potential challenges that a start-up may face as it transitions from being a nimble and flexible organization to a more traditional business structure?', 'In short, success for a start-up is often accompanied by the risk of becoming, over time, exactly the traditional business structure its founders once rejected.']

['What are some strategies that start-up founders and their successors can employ to prevent radical changes that alter the original spirit of innovation and the free and rapid flow of information as the company grows?', 'So the founders of an entrepreneurial shop, and their successors, must guard against change that radically alters the original spirit of innovation and the free and rapid flow of information, even as the company grows.']

['How can a start-up maintain the original spirit of innovation and the free and rapid flow of information while experiencing growth and avoiding radical changes?', 'No business leader seeks bureaucracy, but it typically accompanies growth within any organization.']

['Teacher: What are some specific issues that occur due to bureaucratization as start-ups grow?', 'Particular problems that arise out of bureaucratization are additional layers of management, more codified procedures, and internal obstructions that surface as a business attempts to capitalize on its initial success.']

["What can happen to a start-up's sense of common purpose as more employees are added and the company grows?", 'As more employees are added to the mix, the original team’s sense of common purpose can become diluted.']

['Teacher: Who is the German academic, economist, and sociologist that appreciated the consequences of bureaucracy years ago?', 'Max Weber (1864–1920), the German academic, economist, and sociologist, appreciated the consequences of bureaucracy years ago.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what Max Weber highlighted regarding the emergence of bureaucracy in the private economy?', 'In Wirtschaft und Gesellschaft [Economy and Society], published posthumously in 1925, he pointed out, “in the private economy, [bureaucracy emerges] only in the most advanced institutions of capitalism.”']
['Teacher: What did Max Weber mean by "the most advanced institutions of capitalism" when referring to the emergence of bureaucracy in the private economy?', '3']

['Teacher: How did Max Weber explain the relationship between the development of the money economy and the emergence of bureaucracy in the private economy?', 'Weber cemented the link between bureaucracy and capitalism further: “The development of the money economy [emphasis is Weber’s] . . . is a presupposition of bureaucracy.']
['Teacher: According to Max Weber, what is the current status of bureaucracy in the private economy?', 'Today it not only prevails but is predominant.”']
['What is the prevailing status of bureaucracy in the private economy according to Max Weber?', '4']

['Teacher: According to the passage, why did Weber anticipate that successful start-ups would be prone to bureaucratization as they expand and mature?', 'Because start-ups constitute an “advanced” feature of capitalism, and because bureaucracy presupposes a “money economy,” Weber prophesied that agile start-ups would be ripe for bureaucratization as they grow and age.']

["Teacher: What does the passage suggest about the relationship between successful start-ups and bureaucratization according to Weber's viewpoint?", 'Finally, he included this acknowledgement of the permanence of bureaucracy: “Once it is firmly established, bureaucracy is among those social structures which are the hardest to destroy.”']
['What is one reason why Weber believed that successful start-ups would be susceptible to bureaucratization as they expand and mature?', '5']

['Teacher: According to Michael A. Lutzker, what is the distinctive character of bureaucracy in the modern era?', 'More recently, Michael A. Lutzker confirmed Weber’s testimony on the inevitability of bureaucracy: “The administrative function has of course been a pervasive element of all societies, ancient, medieval, and modern, but Weber was among the first to recognize the distinctive character of bureaucracy in the modern era.”']
['What did Michael A. Lutzker recognize about the distinctive character of bureaucracy in the modern era?', '6']

['Teacher: What is one consequence of the success of a start-up that can ultimately affect its original dynamic and decision-making process?', 'Simply put, the very same success that permits a start-up to flourish often produces bureaucratic structures that chip away at the free-flowing camaraderie that allowed a handful of founders to act instantly and with one mind.']

["Teacher: How does the expansion of a start-up's staff and the establishment of titles and hierarchies affect the recognition of individual achievements within the company?", 'As the staff expands, employees’ ranks become more defined, titles and hierarchies appear, and individual achievements become harder to spot.']

['Teacher: How does the success of a start-up contribute to the transformation of its original congenial atmosphere?', 'This is what changes within a successful start-up, and it moves the company away from the more congenial atmosphere that characterized it at its outset.']

['What are some of the attributes or characteristics that a successful start-up might take on as it grows into a larger corporate entity?', 'An original small partnership often becomes a corporate behemoth, and it takes on many of the attributes of those cubicle workplaces that frequently inspired its founders to strike out on their own in the first place.']

["Teacher: What are some potential benefits that can emerge through a company's trial-and-error experience at the outset?", 'All the better, then, if ethical practices that permit coworkers to bond as colleagues with a sense of commitment to each other and to their customers or clients emerge through a company’s trial-and-error experience at the outset.']

["Teacher: How can a company's emphasis on ethical practices during its trial-and-error experience benefit the firm in the long run?", 'Only if the founders and initial staff emphasize treating all stakeholders with honesty, courtesy, and respect will the new firm stand a chance of indelibly cementing ethics into its operating matrix.']

['Teacher: What is a fairly common characteristic of successful start-ups, as mentioned in the passage?', 'A fairly common characteristic of successful start-ups is charismatic, driven founders with take-no-prisoner competitive mentalities, as was illustrated earlier in this chapter in the example of Kalanick and the leadership values at Uber.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, why is it important for start-up leaders to have a thick skin and powerful ego?', 'After all, it takes a thick skin and powerful ego to get through the inevitable disappointments that confront a start-up leader.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, why do start-up leaders with self-assured personalities often remain difficult for others to abide?', 'Often, however, even when these self-assured personalities evade the most egregious behavior of a Kalanick, they still remain very difficult for others to abide.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what is one reason why many companies require a different leadership ethos as they grow?', 'Many companies discover that a different leadership ethos is necessary as they grow.']
['Why is it a difficult problem for many firms to develop a different leadership ethos as they grow, according to the passage?', 'It is a difficult problem with which many firms wrestle.']

['Why might dedicated employees be put off by demanding leaders who give little back to loyal workers, according to the passage?', 'Dedicated employees may be put off by demanding leaders who are harsh, giving little back to loyal workers even after achieving success.']
['How can the working climate of a company impact new employees, according to the passage?', 'New employees may decide the working climate is less congenial than they anticipated and simply leave.']

['Why might a high turnover rate be seen as a judgment of repugnant leadership, according to the passage?', 'This turnstile effect of workers voting on management with their feet constitutes an ethical judgment of repugnant leadership at the top.']
['Teacher: What do these observations identify in regards to entrepreneurial culture?', 'These observations identify what may be unique to entrepreneurial culture.']

['Teacher: How does the combination of personality and management style contribute to the formation of entrepreneurial culture?', 'This is a combination of personality and management style often identified with those business leaders who strike out on their own, bring a start-up to life, and shape its initial business practices and culture on the job.']

['What happens to the principles and philosophy of the founder if the enterprise is successful?', 'If the enterprise is successful, the principles and philosophy of the founder become enshrined in the lore of the company, so that long after his or her departure, succeeding leaders find themselves beholden to the management philosophy exemplified from the early days of the firm.']
["What impact does the long-lasting influence of the founder's principles and philosophy have on the entrepreneurial culture of a successful enterprise?", '7']

['What is the importance of considering the preferred leadership style as a potential boss in relation to shaping the entrepreneurial culture of a successful enterprise?', 'As you seek the right leadership style to implement on the job, begin by asking precisely what kind of leader you would prefer to work for if you were not the boss.']

['What can be learned from considering the leadership style you would prefer as a potential boss in relation to shaping the entrepreneurial culture of a successful enterprise?', 'The answer you provide may very well be the best model to follow as you develop your own leadership personality, whether it is at a start-up or a more established company.']

['Teacher: What is the significance or importance that the first employees of a start-up understand as the company ventures into new entrepreneurial territory?', 'The first employees of a start-up realize what is at stake as the company tiptoes into new entrepreneurial waters.']

['Teacher: How does the collaborative spirit among the first employees of a start-up contribute to the success of the venture?', 'The founder may be the boss, but those associated with him or her sense a collaborative spirit that directly joins them to the founder as well as each other.']

['Teacher: How does the sense of fraternity among the first employees of a start-up foster a positive work environment and contribute to the overall success of the company?', 'There can be a genuine fraternity among those who have been with the firm since day 1 or shortly thereafter.']

['Teacher: How do the ownership stakes offered to founding members of an entrepreneurial business contribute to their willingness to undergo the strains and rigors attached to a start-up?', 'Founding members of an entrepreneurial business are also often willing to undergo the strains and rigors attached to a start-up in return for an ownership stake in the company that allows them to profit handsomely from its later growth and success.']
['Teacher: What is one potential challenge that newer staff may face in relation to the entrepreneurial culture described in the passage?', 'Newer staff, however, may not share this mindset.']

['Why might newer staff be more interested in secure positions with growing businesses rather than risky start-ups?', 'They may simply be seeking a secure position with a growing business rather than a chance to get in on the ground floor of a risky start-up.']

['What are some potential factors that may contribute to newer staff lacking tolerance for demanding hours, chaos, and abrasive personalities in the early days of an enterprise?', 'They will not necessarily have the tolerance for the demanding hours, chaos, and abrasive personalities that can characterize the early days of an enterprise.']

['Teacher: What else should entrepreneurs and employees consider in addition to the entrepreneurial culture when it comes to their ethical practices?', 'Consider also the ethical practices of an entrepreneur and the ethical expectations of employees.']

['Teacher: How does the respect extended to customers or clients contribute to the ethical practices of entrepreneurs and the ethical expectations of employees in a start-up?', 'Suppose that one of the distinguishing features woven into the fabric of the start-up is the respect extended to customers or clients.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for entrepreneurs to promise to always hold customers in the highest regard, never lie to them, and serve them well in terms of ethical practices?', 'An entrepreneur typically promises always to hold customers in the highest regard, never lie to them, and serve them well.']

['Teacher: How does the entrepreneur successfully instilling the ethos of holding customers in the highest regard and serving them well contribute to the overall ethical practices of the start-up?', 'Furthermore, suppose this entrepreneur successfully instills this same ethos among all employees from the outset.']

["How does the entrepreneur's commitment to not cheating a client or misrepresenting the company's services contribute to the overall ethical practices of the start-up?", 'Respect for customers is intended to become a distinguishing feature of the business; even if it causes monetary loss to the company, this entrepreneur will not cheat a client or misrepresent the company’s services.']

['What impact does embedding this ethos into the culture of the company during start-up mode have on the overall ethical practices of the start-up?', 'Finally, presume that this ethos is embedded into the culture of the company while it is still in start-up mode.']

['Teacher: What do you think would happen if, despite facing significant challenges, the company manages to achieve success?', 'Now, and literally against the odds, suppose the company becomes successful.']
['Teacher: Why do you think becoming successful could be the hardest time for the entrepreneur?', 'This may signal the hardest time of all for the entrepreneur.']

["Teacher: How might the growth of a successful company impact the entrepreneur's role and responsibilities?", 'Growth often accompanies success, and growth means, among other things, more employees.']

["Teacher: How could the increased number of employees in a successful company potentially impact the entrepreneur's ability to maintain customer responsibility?", 'Not all these new hires will be as committed to the same degree of responsibility for customers.']

['Teacher: How might the entrepreneur address the challenge of ensuring that all employees maintain the same level of customer responsibility as the founder?', 'They will not necessarily set out to cheat clients, but they might lack the founder’s enthusiasm for the most honorable treatment of customers.']

['Teacher: How can the entrepreneur motivate and inspire the employees to prioritize the honorable treatment of customers without simply giving orders?', 'He or she cannot simply order it to happen—human nature usually does not respond so easily.']

['Teacher: What strategies or approaches can entrepreneurs use to effectively pass along their version of customer service and ensure that new employees prioritize respect for clients?', 'So entrepreneurs must do their best to ensure that their version of customer service, one that prioritizes respect for clients, is passed along to new employees.']

['How can entrepreneurs nurture their version of customer service to make it equally significant for both long-serving employees and new hires?', 'It may be ingrained in the longest-serving employees, but it must be nurtured to the point where it has the same significance for the newest hires.']

['How can entrepreneurs effectively demonstrate their leadership mettle in ensuring the consistent prioritization of customer service across all employees, regardless of their tenure?', 'This is where leadership mettle is tested to the severest degree.']

['Teacher: How does the emergence and dominance of social media relate to the discussion on the influence and ethics of advertising?', 'Relevant to any discussion of the influence and ethics of advertising is the emergence and dominance of social media, which now serve as the format within which many people most often encounter ads.']

['What is the role of social media in shaping our culture and perception of communication, according to Kelly Jensen, a digital-marketing consultant?', 'Kelly Jensen, a digital-marketing consultant, observed that we inhabit a “Digital Era” in which “the internet is arguably the single most influential factor of our culture—transforming the way we view communication, relationships, and even ourselves.']

['What does Kelly Jensen mean when she says that social media platforms have evolved to symbolize the status of both individuals and businesses alike?', 'Social media platforms have evolved to symbolize the status of both individuals and businesses alike.']
['What are some examples of how social media platforms symbolize the status of individuals and businesses?', '. .']

['How has the use of social media evolved from being optional to being necessary for businesses today in terms of creating brand awareness, driving revenue, engaging customers, and attracting new ones?', 'Today, using social media to create brand awareness, drive revenue, engage current customers, and attract new ones isn’t optional anymore.']
["How has the transition of social media from being optional to being necessary impacted businesses' marketing strategies and overall success?", 'Now it is an absolute ‘must.’”11']

['Teacher: How does Jensen argue that social media platforms are able to reach consumers that cannot be captured by conventional advertising schemes?', 'These are bold claims—as are the claims of some advertising—but Jensen argues convincingly that social media platforms reach many consumers, especially younger ones, who simply cannot be captured by conventional advertising schemes.']

['Teacher: According to Jensen, who are the consumers that social media platforms are able to reach that conventional advertising schemes cannot capture?', 'For those who derive most of the significant information that shapes their lives solely through electronic sources, nothing other than social media–based appeals stands much chance of influencing their purchasing decisions.']
['Teacher: How has the rise of social media impacted the content of advertisements?', 'This upending of conventional modes of advertising has begun to change the content of ads dramatically.']

['What are some examples of how the content of advertisements has changed dramatically with the rise of social media?', 'It certainly presents a new stage on which people as young as their teens increasingly rely for help in choosing what to buy.']

['How does the rise of social media influence the way marketers spread the word about their products and services?', 'Many marketers have come to appreciate that if they are not spreading the word about their products and services via an electronic source, many millennials will ignore it.']
['How has the rise of social media affected the target audience that marketers are trying to reach?', '12']

['Teacher: How would you describe the impact of a digital environment on business, considering its ability to advertise, sell, and deliver products and services?', 'Undeniably, a digital environment for advertising, selling, and delivering products and services functions as a two-edged sword for business.']

['Teacher: What are the advantages and disadvantages of a digital environment in terms of advertising, selling, and delivering products and services for business?', 'It provides lightning-quick access to potential customers, but it also opens pathways for sensitive corporate and consumer data to be hacked on an alarming scale.']

['What are some of the benefits and drawbacks of a digital environment for businesses in terms of branding and public perception?', 'It offers astute companies nearly unlimited capacity to brand themselves positively in the minds of purchasers, but it simultaneously offers a platform for disgruntled stakeholders to assail companies for both legitimate and self-serving reasons.']

['Teacher: Who is the individual that has extensively studied the dilemma of social media and business communication?', 'Paul A. Argenti, who has taught business communication for many years at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth University, has studied this dilemma.']
['Teacher: According to Paul A. Argenti, what has created a new playground for cyber-thieves?', 'As he put it, “mobile apps have created a new playground for cyber-thieves.']

['What are some challenges faced by corporations as a result of technology being used to rally together and escalate a crisis, according to Paul A. Argenti?', '”13 And consumer advocates and purchasers alike “now use technology to rally together and fuel or escalate a crisis—posing additional challenges for the corporation” in the crosshairs of criticism.']

['What is the impact of the proliferation of online blogs and social networking sites on the visibility and reach of current events, according to Paul A. Argenti?', 'Finally, “the proliferation of online blogs and social networking sites has greatly increased the visibility and reach of all current events, not excluding large corporate”14 bungling.']

['Teacher: How does the willingness of consumers to purchase goods or services they may not necessarily need complicate the potential threat that advertising of unnecessary or harmful products may pose to our autonomy?', 'Regardless of the delivery platform, however, any threat that the advertising of unnecessary or harmful products may pose to our autonomy as consumers is complicated by the fact that sometimes we willingly choose to buy goods or services we may not necessarily require.']

['What is one example of a product that consumers sometimes willingly purchase, even if it has been proven to be harmful?', 'Sometimes we even buy things that have been proven to be harmful to us, such as cigarettes and sugary drinks.']

['Teacher: What is the primary goal of advertising in relation to consumers and their purchasing decisions?', 'By definition, advertising aims to persuade consumers to buy goods and services, many of which are nonessential.']

['Teacher: What is the potential consequence of advertisers not reining in the exaggerated claims of their marketing pitches?', 'Although consumers have long been encouraged to heed the warning caveat emptor (let the buyer beware), it is a valid question whether advertisers have any ethical obligation to rein in the oft-exaggerated claims of their marketing pitches.']
['Teacher: How does the concept of caveat emptor relate to the potential ethical obligation of advertisers to rein in exaggerated claims?', 'Most consumers emphatically would agree that they do.']

['Teacher: Who is the author of The Affluent Society?', 'The award-winning Harvard University economist John Kenneth Galbraith directly addressed this issue in The Affluent Society, first published in 1958.']

['Teacher: What did John Kenneth Galbraith address in his book The Affluent Society?', 'In what he depicted as the “the dependence effect,” Galbraith bemoaned the power of corporations to harness wide-ranging advertising strategies, marketing efforts, and sales pitches to influence consumer purchasing decisions.']
['What concept did Galbraith introduce in his book The Affluent Society?', '15']

['What did Galbraith question in relation to advertising campaigns and product benefits in The Affluent Society?', 'He asked whether it is possible for a sophisticated advertising campaign to create a demand for a product whose benefits are frivolous at best.']

['What is the importance of prioritizing truthful content over inducing wasteful consumption in ethical advertising campaigns according to the passage?', 'These questions remain fundamental to the manager’s task of creating ethical advertising campaigns in which truthful content is prioritized over inducing wasteful consumption.']
['Teacher: What forms the basis of the most successful ads?', 'Psychological appeals form the basis of the most successful ads.']

['Teacher: Can you give an example of how psychological appeals are used in advertising to target our self-esteem?', 'Going beyond the standard ad pitch about the product’s advantages, psychological appeals try to reach our self-esteem and persuade us that we will feel better about ourselves if we use certain products.']

['What are some examples of psychological appeals used in advertising to target our self-esteem?', 'If advertising frames the purchase of a popular toy as the act of a loving parent rather than an extravagance, for instance, consumers may buy it not because their child needs it but because it makes them feel good about what generous parents they are.']

['What are the potential consequences of using psychological appeals in advertising?', 'This is how psychological appeals become successful, and when they do work, this often constitutes a victory for the power of psychological persuasion at the expense of ethical truthfulness.']

['Teacher: How does our notion of what constitutes a necessity versus a luxury affect our purchases?', 'Purchases are also affected by our notion of what constitutes a necessity versus a luxury, and that perception often differs across generations.']

['Teacher: Can you provide another example of how our notion of what constitutes a necessity versus a luxury has changed across generations?', 'Older consumers today can probably remember when a cell phone was considered a luxury, for instance, rather than a necessity for every schoolchild.']

['Teacher: How does the perception of a cell phone as a luxury versus a necessity vary between older and younger generations?', 'On the other hand, many younger consumers consider the purchase of a landline unnecessary, whereas some older people still use a conventional phone as their main or even preferred means of communication.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how the notion of what constitutes a necessary purchase has shifted for millennials compared to previous generations?', 'The cars and suburban homes that were once considered essential purchases for every young family are slowly becoming luxuries, replaced, for many millennials, by travel.']

['How do advertisers utilize generational differences in their campaigns to influence purchases?', 'Generational differences like these are carefully studied by advertisers who are anxious to make use of psychological appeals in their campaigns.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a consumer craze that does not drive unnecessary purchases?', 'A consumer craze based on little more than novelty—or, at least, not on necessity or luxury in the conventional sense—is the Pet Rock, a recurring phenomenon that began in 1977.']

['Teacher: What characteristics of the Pet Rock make it a consumer craze that does not drive unnecessary purchases?', 'Pet Rocks have been purchased by the millions over the years, despite being nothing more than rocks.']

['Teacher: How does the retail price of the Pet Rock contribute to it being a consumer craze that does not drive unnecessary purchases?', 'During the 2017 holiday shopping season, they retailed at $19.95.16']

['Teacher: What impact does the success of the Pet Rock craze have on the argument that advertising drives us to unnecessary purchases?', 'In the annals of marketing, the Pet Rock craze denotes one of the most successful campaigns—still unfolding today, though in subdued fashion—in support of so dubious a product.']

['Teacher: Why is there still no clear consensus on how to answer the questions about the impact of advertising on unnecessary purchases?', 'Many people have long asked exactly these questions, and we still have arrived at no clear consensus as to how to answer them.']

['Teacher: What is the responsibility of each new generation of marketers regarding the questions about the impact of advertising on unnecessary purchases?', 'Yet it remains an obligation of each new generation of marketers to reflect on these points and, at the very least, establish their convictions about them.']

['Teacher: How does the passage address the issue of how reasonable people should respond to marketing schemes?', 'A second ethical question is how we should expect reasonable people to respond to an avalanche of marketing schemes deliberately intended to separate them from their hard-earned cash.']

['What are the ethical considerations and potential responses discussed in the passage regarding the impact of marketing schemes on reasonable individuals?', 'These questions have no consensus answers, but they underlie any discussion of the point at which sophisticated advertising runs headlong into people’s obligation to take responsibility for the wisdom of their purchases.']

['Teacher: Why do you think children are particularly susceptible to the ads that commercial television regularly airs over them?', 'No one would argue that children are particularly susceptible to the ads commercial television rains over them regularly.']

['Teacher: What is one reason why children may not be able to discern which advertised products are beneficial or harmful to them?', 'Generally, young children have not developed sufficient judgment to know what advertised products are good for them and which ones have little or no benefit or perhaps can even harm.']

['Teacher: How does the inability of young children to separate what is real on television from what is not contribute to their susceptibility to advertisements?', 'Research has even shown that very young children have difficulty separating what is real on television from what is not.']

['Teacher: How does the susceptibility of children to advertising for junk food contribute to their consumption of unhealthy products?', 'This is especially so as it pertains to advertising for junk food.']

['What strategies do marketers use to specifically target young children when advertising junk food?', 'Savvy marketers take advantage of the fact that young children (those younger than age seven or eight years) view advertising in the same manner they do information from trustworthy adults—that is, as very credible—and so marketers hone pitches for junk food directly to these children.']
['Teacher: According to the passage, at what age do children start to view advertising in the same manner they do information from trustworthy adults?', '17']

['Teacher: Why should special care be taken when creating ads targeting children?', 'We could argue that they should take special care that ads targeting children make absolutely no exaggerated claims, because children are less capable of seeing through the usual puffery that most of us ignore.']

['How does the inability of children to see through exaggerated claims in ads make them more susceptible to influence?', 'Children are more literal, and once they gain the ability to understand messages directed toward them, especially when voiced by adult authority figures, they typically accept these as truthful statements.']

['Teacher: How has the expansion of technology affected the range of advertising?', 'We have no easy answers to these questions, though they have taken on special urgency as technology has expanded the range of advertising even to our smartphones.']

["Teacher: How might marketing techniques influence consumers' judgment in ways that are not favorable?", 'It may be possible for marketing to be unfairly persuasive in ways that overwhelm the better judgment of consumers.']

['Teacher: Why do you think the responsibility for resisting persuasive marketing appeals is debated between consumers and marketers?', 'Whether it is the consumers’ responsibility to resist or marketers’ to tone down their appeals, or both, will continue to be debated.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what ethical ramifications are associated with the question of responsibility in consumer decision making influenced by marketing appeals?', 'Yet the question of where responsibility lies when consumers are steered to make choices certainly has ethical ramifications.']

['Teacher: What do some psychologists and educational specialists claim about the ability of the very old and the very young to exercise good judgment in relation to subliminal advertising?', 'Some psychologists and educational specialists claim that the very old and the very young are particularly ill prepared to exercise good judgment in the face of subliminal advertising, that is, embedded words or images that allegedly reach us only beneath the level of our consciousness.']

['What is the opinion of other experts regarding the existence of subliminal advertising?', 'Other experts, however, disagree and insist that subliminal advertising is an urban myth that no current technology could create or sustain.']

['Teacher: Who published The Hidden Persuaders in 1957 and what was the main claim made in the book?', 'A U.S. journalist, Vance Packard, published The Hidden Persuaders in 1957, contending that subliminal messaging had already been introduced into some U.S. cinemas to sell more refreshments at the theaters’ snack bars.']

['What was the main claim made by Vance Packard in his book The Hidden Persuaders?', 'Alarms sounded at the prospect, but it turned out that any data on which Packard was relying came from James Vicary, a U.S. market researcher who insisted he had engineered the feat in a cinema in New Jersey.']

["What was James Vicary's involvement in the claim made by Vance Packard in The Hidden Persuaders?", 'No other substantiation was provided, and Vicary’s claim was eventually dismissed as self-promotion, which he seemed to concede in an interview five years later.']

["What are some concerns that people still have regarding the possibility of subliminal advertising, despite James Vicary's claim being dismissed?", 'Although the immediate threat of subliminal advertising receded, some people remain concerned that such persuasion might indeed be possible, especially with the advent of better technologies, like virtual reality, to implement it.18']

['Teacher: What was the purpose of the study conducted at the University of South Carolina regarding subliminal advertising?', 'A 2015 study at the University of South Carolina found that thirsty test subjects placed in the role of shoppers in a simulated grocery store could be subliminally influenced in their choice of beverages if they were primed by images of various beverage brands within fifteen minutes of acknowledging being thirsty.']

['What did the 2015 study at the University of South Carolina discover about the impact of subliminal advertising on thirsty test subjects in a simulated grocery store?', 'After that window of time passed, however, any impact of subliminal messaging receded.']
['How long did it take for the impact of subliminal messaging to recede after the thirsty test subjects acknowledged being thirsty?', '19']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what does the scientific evidence reveal about the existence of subliminal advertising?', 'So the scientific evidence establishing any real phenomenon of subliminal advertising is inconclusive.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the scientific evidence on subliminal advertising is considered inconclusive?', 'Put another way, the evidence to this point does not definitively demonstrate the existence of a current technology making subliminal marketing pitches possible.']

['Teacher: Why is it difficult to determine the effectiveness of a hypothetical technology for subliminal advertising?', 'Given this, it cannot be clearly determined whether such a technology, if it did exist, would be effective.']

['Teacher: How do virtual reality and augmented reality relate to the potential viability of subliminal advertising?', 'Another question is whether virtual reality and augmented reality might eventually make subliminal advertising viable.']

['Teacher: In what ways might vulnerable populations be more susceptible to subliminal persuasion?', 'Real subliminal persuasion might render children, the elderly, and those with developmental disabilities more vulnerable to falling prey.']

['Teacher: What role does advertising play in informing consumers of new or modified products and services?', 'Advertising plays a useful role in informing consumers of new or modified products and services in the marketplace, and wise purchasers will pay attention to it but with a discerning eye.']

['Teacher: How can consumers benefit from paying attention to advertising while also maintaining a critical mindset?', 'Even the exaggerated claims that often accompany ads can serve a purpose as long as we do not unquestioningly accept every pitch as true.']
['Teacher: What is the underlying sentiment towards insurance coverage expressed in the passage?', 'The irony of insurance coverage of any sort is that we buy it hoping never to use it.']

['Teacher: What is the driving factor behind individuals and businesses seeking insurance coverage despite the irony mentioned in the passage?', 'Still, business and consumers alike appreciate that a catastrophic loss can be financially devastating and so they seek to protect against it.']

['Teacher: What is the main purpose of insurance coverage, according to the passage?', 'Insurance coverage does not prevent illness, accidents, or other unforeseen events from occurring, but it does offer a means to recover, at least partially, from the monetary costs associated with them.']
['Teacher: What is the relationship between insurance policies and the insured?', 'Insurance policies constitute a form of contract between insurers and the insured.']

["What are insurers' efforts to reduce their losses in situations where they need to pay on a claim?", 'To reduce their losses in those situations in which they must pay on a claim, insurers do their best to attach high premiums to the coverage and identify exclusions and limits on it.']

['What are the concerns of insurers and policyholders in relation to insurance claims?', 'They worry about being forced to pay out on frivolous and exaggerated claims, while policyholders fear that on the rare occasions when they will have to file a claim, their reimbursement will be minuscule and/or their future premiums will rise.']

['What is the main motivation for consumers to pay insurance premiums?', 'From the perspective of the consumer, the guarantee of a fair payout on a claim is the only inducement to pay insurance premiums in the first place.']
['Teacher: What is the nature of insurance protections?', 'Insurance protections are, in fact, limited.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example that illustrates the limitations of insurance protections?', 'In August 2017, Hurricane Harvey dumped fifty-two inches of rain on Houston, Texas, accompanied by fierce winds.']

['Teacher: How did the occurrence of Hurricane Harvey in 2017 relate to the limitations of insurance protections?', 'Tens of thousands of homes, stores, factories, and other industrial sites suffered severe damage and flooding.']

["Teacher: Why does normal homeowners' and business owners' insurance not cover loss due to flooding?", 'Although normal homeowners’ and business owners’ insurance provides for loss due to hurricane winds, it does not cover loss due to flooding.']

['Teacher: According to The Economist, what is the difference in coverage between wind damage and flood damage under most standard insurance policies in America?', 'As The Economist observed in the immediate aftermath of the hurricane, “whereas wind damage is covered under most standard insurance policies in America, flood insurance is a government-run add-on that far from all homeowners buy.']
['What percentage of property losses in Texas may be insured according to The Economist?', 'As a result, of over $30 billion in property losses in Texas, only 40 percent may be insured.']
['What does the limited coverage of insurance protections mean for the majority of homeowners and business owners in America?', '”21']
['Teacher: Why is it true that few private insurers offer flood insurance for homeowners?', 'Not only do few homeowners buy flood insurance; few private insurers offer it.']

['Teacher: What is the reason behind private insurers being reluctant to offer flood insurance for homeowners in flood-prone areas?', 'After all, most insurance carriers are for-profit, and companies would make little money insuring everyone against flood damage in flood-prone areas.']

['Teacher: Why do insurance companies benefit from having few claims and small payouts?', 'It would be a losing proposition for any carrier to undertake, because insurance companies enjoy their highest returns when claims are few and payouts small.']

['Why does the federal government offer flood insurance for homeowners, despite it not being a commercial broker?', 'But the federal government is not a commercial broker and does not intend to make a profit from extending any sort of insurance coverage.']
['Why was the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 established?', 'For that reason, the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 established a way to dispense flood coverage through a federal agency.']

['What is the role of the Federal Emergency Management Authority (FEMA) in providing flood insurance coverage?', 'Today that supervising agency is the Federal Emergency Management Authority (FEMA), in partnership with the Department of Homeland Security.']
['What is the purpose of FEMA-sponsored flood coverage for homeowners?', 'As of August 2017, just before Harvey struck, some five million households had taken out FEMA-sponsored flood coverage.']
['How many households had taken out FEMA-sponsored flood coverage just before Hurricane Harvey struck in August 2017?', '22']

['Teacher: What entity is responsible for managing privately funded insurance against earthquakes in California at the state level?', 'The California Earthquake Authority serves a similar function at the state level by managing privately funded insurance against earthquakes in California.']

['Teacher: How do the private brokers in the program benefit from offering insurance against earthquakes in California through the California Earthquake Authority?', 'The private brokers in the program make no profit from offering this coverage, but they do earn the right to offer (and profit from) other insurance in California.']

['Teacher: What is the reason behind the uncertainty regarding the effect of climate change on the incidence and severity of natural disasters?', 'We do not know with certainty what effect climate change will have on the incidence or severity of natural disasters (i.e., accidents that do not appear to have any direct human cause).']

['Teacher: What are the potential consequences of natural disasters for both insurance companies and the individuals affected by them?', 'We do know, however, that these events can be ruinously expensive, for the carriers that insure against them and for those who suffer them and must put their lives back together afterward.']

['Teacher: According to Don Jergler, what has climate change created in California?', 'Business writer Don Jergler said, for example, that “climate change has created a ‘wildfire crisis in California,’ which in turn is ‘causing a fire insurance predicament.’”']

['Teacher: According to California insurance commissioner Dave Jones, what did he warn about regarding insurance in some areas of the state?', 'California insurance commissioner Dave Jones warned in December 2017, after a particularly disastrous fire season in California, that “insurers may start to back off writing insurance in some areas [of the state],” and this would pose a crisis for homeowners who consequently lost insurance protection against losses caused by wildfires.']
['Teacher: In what year did California insurance commissioner Dave Jones warn about insurers potentially backing off from writing insurance in certain areas of the state?', '23']

['Teacher: What are some of the environmental risks that insurers in Canada need to consider in relation to climate change?', 'In Canada, too, “environmental risks linked to climate change are becoming important issues for insurers who need to consider their response to related risks and climate related losses whether arising from weather related events such as flood and storms or liability risks from third party claims.']
['What specific challenges do insurers face in Canada when it comes to climate-related losses and liability risks?', '”24']

['Teacher: What is the impact on insurance carriers when they have to pay claimholders frequently due to natural disasters?', 'When insurance carriers must pay claimholders more often on claims arising from natural disasters, they lose money at a rate that could make them less willing to underwrite similar policies in the future.']

['Teacher: Why would insurance carriers become less willing to underwrite similar policies in the future when they have to pay claimholders frequently due to natural disasters?', 'This unwillingness, in turn, would deny coverage against these disasters to an increasing number of individuals and companies.']

['Teacher: What are the consequences for policyholders when insurance carriers become less willing to underwrite similar policies in the future due to frequent payouts for natural disasters?', 'The high cost of disaster claims and subsequent shrinking of policy offerings are losses first experienced by the insurance industry, but they have rapid and dire consequences for policyholders.']

['Teacher: What is the ethical conundrum when it comes to insurance carriers and clients seeking indemnification against natural disasters?', 'Again, we come to the ethical conundrum as to what we might fairly expect from insurance carriers and from clients who seek to indemnify themselves against natural disasters.']

['What are some factors that contribute to determining a reasonable profit for insurance carriers in the context of indemnifying against natural disasters?', 'With these questions, we return to the ethical consideration of what constitutes a reasonable profit for carriers and what premium policy holders ought to be charged for sufficient coverage.']

['Teacher: How does the United States compare to other nations in terms of private/public ownership of industries like petroleum extraction or air travel?', 'The United States does not have the strong tradition of private/public ownership of industries, such as petroleum extraction or air travel that some other nations do.']

['Teacher: Why might some nations have a stronger tradition of private/public ownership in industries like petroleum extraction or air travel compared to the United States?', '25 Essentially, private/public ownership is an arrangement in which private (industry) and public (government) monies are combined to more safely bear an industry’s risk and also share in its profit.']
["Teacher: How does private/public ownership of industries like petroleum extraction or air travel help to bear an industry's risk?", 'It is often a successful partnership.']

['Teacher: Why would insurance be an appropriate industry in the United States for private/public ownership of some policies, especially when considering natural disasters?', 'When we consider the scale of loss that can result from natural disasters, and the extent of the public’s need for protection from such loss, insurance may be a U.S. industry in which private/public ownership of some policies would be appropriate.']

['Teacher: Can you provide examples of public agencies in the United States that manage insurance coverage for natural disasters?', 'The National Flood Insurance Program and the California Earthquake Authority are rare examples of public agencies managing insurance coverage that private insurers have declined to provide because the potential for profit is too low.']

['Teacher: What are some ethical questions that arise when considering the expansion of partnerships for public agencies managing insurance coverage for natural disasters?', 'Whether partnerships like this can and should be expanded, and whether they can be funded from federal and state budgets, are ethical questions for federal and state governments and policyholders alike.']

['Teacher: What is one specific ethical challenge within the insurance profession related to discrimination?', 'A specific ethical challenge within the insurance profession is the tendency to engage in redlining.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how redlining specifically affects inner-city neighborhoods in terms of insurance coverage?', 'Redlining is the practice of assigning or denying coverage for certain policies, such as auto, homeowners, or business insurance, on the basis of the geographic neighborhoods where applicants for such coverage live, particularly inner-city neighborhoods.']

['Teacher: How does the practice of redlining impact the affordability of insurance for residents in inner-city neighborhoods?', 'A variation on the practice is to charge considerably higher prices for the same coverage in different neighborhoods.']

['Teacher: What are some potential consequences for residents in inner-city neighborhoods when insurance coverage becomes unaffordable due to redlining?', 'Redlining assumes that the propensity for accidents, burglaries, fires, and other catastrophes is higher in some areas than others, so claims and costs will be higher for the insurance carrier.']

['Teacher: What is the initial perception regarding the practice of redlining from the viewpoint of the insurer and insured?', 'At first glance, this practice appears to make economic sense from the perspective of both the insurer and the insured.']

['Teacher: How does looking beneath the surface change the initial perception of redlining for both the insurer and the insured?', 'Looking beneath the surface, however, reveals that redlined neighborhoods are often areas where racial and ethnic minorities live.']

['Teacher: Why would insurance carriers typically not admit to engaging in redlining practices?', 'No insurance carrier ever admits to engaging in discriminatory redlining (the term refers to an older practice by which insurance companies marked certain neighborhoods in red on print copies of coverage maps).']
['What are some of the consequences that insurance carriers could face if they were found guilty of redlining practices?', 'Nearly every state in the United States forbids the practice.']

['Teacher: How does the 2017 study by Consumer Reports and ProPublica suggest that redlining may still be a reality despite being prohibited in almost every state?', 'Yet a comprehensive 2017 study by Consumer Reports and ProPublica, a nonprofit research organization, indicated the phenomenon may remain very much a reality.']

['Why is it concerning that auto insurers charge higher premiums to drivers in predominantly minority urban neighborhoods compared to drivers with similar safety records living in majority White neighborhoods?', 'This study focused on rates for auto insurance and found that for “decades, auto insurers have been observed to charge higher average premiums to drivers living in predominantly minority urban neighborhoods than to drivers with similar safety records living in majority White neighborhoods.']

['What does the study by Consumer Reports and ProPublica suggest about the justification that insurers provide for charging higher premiums in minority urban neighborhoods?', 'Insurers have long defended their pricing by saying that the risk of accidents is greater in those neighborhoods, even for motorists who have never had one.']

['What are some of the factors that contribute to the higher premiums charged by insurance carriers in predominantly minority urban neighborhoods according to the study by Consumer Reports and ProPublica?', '”28']

['Teacher: What did the authors of the report compare in terms of auto insurance premiums and claims paid?', 'The authors of the report compared auto insurance premiums and claims paid in four states (California, Illinois, Missouri, and Texas) and found similar results whether the carrier was Allstate, Geico, Liberty Mutual, or another.']

['What did the authors of the report argue regarding the disparities in auto insurance prices between minority and White neighborhoods?', 'They contended “that many of the disparities in auto insurance prices between minority and White neighborhoods are wider than differences in risk can explain.”29 This is significant because laws do typically permit premium rates to be set according to the incidence of claims filed within certain neighborhoods.']

['What was the significant point made by the authors regarding the setting of premium rates in different neighborhoods based on race or ethnicity?', 'Yet laws never allow rates to be based solely or predominantly on the race or ethnicity of the residents in different neighborhoods.']
['What is the essence of prohibited redlining?', 'This is the essence of prohibited redlining.']

['Can you explain why it is important for professionals in the insurance industry to avoid the practice of redlining?', 'Professionals in the industry do well to steer clear of this practice or even the appearance of it, and that is the overriding theme of this study.']

['Teacher: What is the ethical challenge for responsible insurance carriers in relation to the premiums assigned to policyholders?', 'Drawing back, the ethical challenge for any responsible carrier is to ensure that the race, ethnicity, or creed of any policyholder plays absolutely no role in the premiums assigned him or her.']

['What factors should responsible insurance carriers consider when assigning premiums to policyholders, according to the passage?', 'There is no defensible reason to base a carrier’s decision to extend or deny insurance coverage or assign the premium amount for it on these factors.']

['Teacher: How are medical services typically dispensed in the United States?', 'Typically in the United States, medical services have been dispensed through a multipayer health care system, in which the patient and others, such as an employer and a private health insurance company, all contribute to pay for the patient’s care.']
['Teacher: Besides the United States, which other countries have multipayer health care systems?', 'Germany, France, and Japan also have multipayer systems.']

['Teacher: How does a single-payer health care system differ from a multipayer system in terms of funding and payer responsibilities?', 'In a single-payer health care system such as those in the United Kingdom and Canada, national tax revenues pay the largest portion of citizens’ medical care, and the government is the sole payer compensating those who provide that care.']
["Teacher: In a multipayer system, who contributes to pay for the patient's care in addition to the patient themselves?", 'Contributions provided by employers and employees provide the rest.']

["Teacher: In a multipayer system, who besides the patient, employers, and employees contributes to pay for the patient's care?", 'Both single- and multipayer systems help reduce costs for patients, employers, and insurers; both, especially single-payer, are also heavily dependent on taxes apportioned across employers and the country’s population.']

['Teacher: How does the accessibility of medical services differ between a single-payer system and a multipayer system?', 'In a single-payer system, however, because payment for health care is coordinated and dispensed by the government, almost no one lacks access to medical services, including visitors and nonpermanent residents.']
['Teacher: Why does the United States have a predominance of the multipayer system?', 'Many reasons exist for the predominance of the multipayer system in the United States.']

['Teacher: What is one of the primary factors that contributes to the predominance of the multipayer system in the United States?', 'Chief among these is the U.S. tradition that doctors’ services and hospital care are privatized and run for profit.']

['Teacher: How does the absence of a federal health care apparatus contribute to the predominance of the multipayer system in the United States?', 'The United States has no federal health care apparatus that organizes physicians, clinics, and medical centers under a single government umbrella.']

['What are some factors that contribute to the high cost of health care in the United States compared to other nations?', 'Along with the profit motive, the fact that providers are compensated at a higher average rate than their peers abroad ensures that health care is more expensive in the United States than in most other nations.']

["Teacher: That's an interesting point about the United States having more health care professionals and medical centers. Can you discuss how this abundance of resources impacts the delivery of health care services in the country?", 'The United States also has more health care professionals per citizen than most other countries, and more medical centers and clinics.']

['What are some positive impacts of the abundance of health care resources in the United States in terms of wait times for medical procedures and accessibility to medical facilities?', 'One positive result is that the wait for most elective medical procedures is often shorter than in other countries, and travel time to a nearby medical facility is often less.']

['What are some of the drawbacks or challenges associated with the current health care system in the United States?', 'Still, paying for health care remains one of the most controversial topics in the United States, and many question what it is that Americans gain from the current system to balance the cost.']

['What does the study from The Commonwealth Fund reveal about health care spending in the United States compared to other high-income countries?', 'As an exhaustive study from The Commonwealth Fund asserted, “the United States spends far more on health care than other high-income countries, with spending levels that rose continuously over the past three decades.']

['What are some possible reasons for the United States spending significantly more on health care compared to other high-income countries, according to the study from The Commonwealth Fund?', '. . .']
