['Why does the study from The Commonwealth Fund suggest that the United States spends significantly more on health care compared to other high-income countries, despite having poorer health outcomes?', 'Yet the U.S. population has poorer health than other countries.']

['What are some examples of specific health outcomes in the United States that contribute to the perception of poorer health compared to other countries, as mentioned in the study from The Commonwealth Fund?', '”31']

['Teacher: What are some challenging ethical issues that professionals in the field of U.S. health care face due to the state of the system?', 'Besides its inefficiencies, the state of U.S. health care raises challenging ethical issues for professionals in the field and for patients as well.']

['Teacher: What evidence might supporters of the status quo use to argue for the success of health care in the United States?', 'Supporters of the status quo for health care in the United States may point to state-of-the-art facilities as evidence of its success.']

["Teacher: That's a great point! So, what would be a counterargument to the claim that state-of-the-art facilities are evidence of the success of health care in the United States?", 'Yet other nations, such as Australia, the United Kingdom, and the Netherlands, have equal levels of medical technologies available for patients and are given much more favorable marks for universal health insurance and accessibility by The Commonwealth Fund.']

['Teacher: Why is it enough to observe that prescription drugs are expensive in the United States?', 'Discussions of health care accessibility have become politically charged, so for now it is enough to observe that not only is medical care enormously expensive in the United States but so are prescription drugs.']

['Why is the establishment of the generic drug program at the FDA considered a significant victory in the battle to control drug prices according to William B. Schultz?', 'According to William B. Schultz, an attorney writing in the Washington Post in 2017, “in the past 35 years, the only significant victory in the battle to control drug prices has been the enactment of legislation that established the generic drug program at the FDA [Federal Drug Administration].”']

['What has been the most significant victory in the battle to control drug prices, according to William B. Schultz?', 'Otherwise, he stated, “prescription drug prices account for 17 percent of the nation’s health-care costs, up from 7 percent in the 1990s,” and “prescription drug spending accounts for nearly 20 percent of total program spending for Medicare, the largest of the governmental health-care programs.”32 (Schultz is not entirely impartial; he is a partner in a law firm that represents generic drug providers, among other clients.)']

['Teacher: According to the pharmaceutical industry, why do they claim they need to pass on the <mask> to consumers in order to recoup the enormous cost of developing new drugs?', 'The only way to recoup the enormous cost of developing new drugs, says the pharmaceutical industry, is to pass it along to consumers.']

['Teacher: What do critics argue is one of the main factors contributing to the high expenses within the pharmaceutical industry?', 'Critics, on the other hand, assert that the much of the expense incurred within the industry results from the high cost of marketing new drugs.']

['What is the impact of exorbitant prices for much-needed medicines on their social value?', 'Wherever the truth lies in this debate, it remains that exorbitant prices for much-needed medicines dramatically reduce their social value when only a few individuals can actually afford to obtain them.']

['Teacher: Who do many U.S. workers traditionally look to within the multipayer system to subsidize the cost of care and make it available for them and their families?', 'Within the multipayer system, many U.S. workers have traditionally looked to their employers or their unions to subsidize the cost of care and thereby make it available for them and their families.']
['What are some reasons why many U.S. workers traditionally look to their employers or unions to subsidize the cost of care within the multipayer system?', 'Many reasons explain why this is so.']

['What is the traditional U.S. approach to the responsibility of securing health care coverage for workers and their families in contrast to European and Canadian perspectives?', 'In contrast to the European and Canadian perspective, for example, in which both the state and employers are presumed to have an interest in and responsibility for underwriting the cost of health care, the traditional U.S. approach is that workers and their employers should be responsible for securing this coverage.']

['What is one potential concern that some people may have about assigning health care services to the government?', 'This belief reflects an unease on the part of some about assigning services to the government, because this implies the need for a larger governing entity as well as additional taxes to sustain it.']

['What are some potential benefits or advantages that some people may associate with assigning health care services to the government?', 'The sentiment also reflects a conviction on the part of some that self-reliance is always to be preferred when securing the necessities of life.']

['Teacher: What explanation did John E. Murray, a professor of economics at the University of Toledo, offer?', 'John E. Murray, a professor of economics at the University of Toledo, offered a related explanation.']

['What were the industrial sickness funds that John E. Murray mentioned?', 'He cited the existence of industrial sickness funds in the United States, which arose in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.']

['Teacher: What were the main aspects of the industrial sickness funds that provided health insurance in the late 19th and early 20th centuries?', 'These were monies “organized by workers through their employer or union [that] provided the rudiments of health insurance, principally consisting of paid sick leave, to a large minority of the industrial workforce of the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.']

['What were the reasons for the decline in popularity of industrial sickness funds mentioned by John E. Murray?', '”33 Murray stated that these funds declined in popularity not because they were ineptly administered or rendered bankrupt by World War I or the Great Depression but rather because they gave way to even more effective instruments in the form of group insurance policies offered by employers or labor unions.']

["Teacher: How did the U.S. worker's experience regarding health care coverage differ from that of European labor?", 'So the U.S. worker’s experience differed from that of European labor in that much significant health care coverage was provided under the auspices of unions and employers rather than the state.']

['What were the sources of health care coverage for U.S. workers compared to European labor, according to the passage?', 'Murray noted another source of relief for workers who experienced illness or injury that prevented them from working for any period of time, and that was charity.']

['What were some specific versions of charity that provided health care coverage for workers, according to the passage?', '34 Specific versions of charity were offered by religious organizations, including Christian churches and Jewish synagogues.']

['What organizations were involved in providing monetary benefits for sick or injured members of their faith, according to the passage?', 'Often, these religious bodies banded together to provide monetary benefits for sick or injured members of their own faith who might otherwise have been denied health coverage due to prejudice.']

['What was a downside of the ethnic and cultural diversity in the U.S. regarding health care coverage, according to the passage?', '35 The U.S. social experience featured more ethnic and cultural diversity, especially in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, than was present in many European nations, and a downside is the racial, ethnic, and religious prejudice it inspired.']

['Teacher: What is a final distinction that Murray pointed out regarding the American Medical Association?', 'A final distinction Murray pointed to is the past opposition of the American Medical Association to any sort of state-sponsored insurance.']

['Teacher: What was the anticipation of early supporters of industrial sickness funds regarding the support of doctors towards these funds?', 'Early supporters of industrial sickness funds, including some physicians, anticipated that most doctors would support these funds as pathways ultimately directed to state-provided coverage.']

['Teacher: Why did the American Medical Association oppose government health insurance in 1920?', 'Instead, in 1920, “the American Medical Association voted officially to state its opposition to government health insurance.']

['What were the consequences for U.S. workers as a result of physicians opposing government insurance from the 1920s to the 1960s?', 'A sociologist concluded that from this time to the 1960s, physicians were the loudest opponents of government insurance.”36 By default, then, many U.S. workers came to rely more on their employers or unions than on any other source for coverage.']

['What is the ongoing ethical question that remains unsettled regarding the provision of health insurance to residents and citizens in the United States?', 'However, this explanation does not answer the larger ethical question of who should provide health insurance to residents and citizens, a question that continues to roil politics and society in the nation even today.']

['Teacher: What can you tell me about the ethical standards that physicians and healthcare professionals need to uphold when caring for their patients in the United States?', 'Physicians and other healthcare professionals in the United States have always been held to high ethical standards in terms of the care they provide their patients.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what the code of medical ethics proposed by the American Medical Association in 1847 entails for physicians and healthcare professionals in the United States?', 'In fact, the American Medical Association first proposed a code of medical ethics in 1847, its founding year.']

['What are some of the key principles and values outlined in the code of medical ethics proposed by the American Medical Association in 1847?', 'Since then, the AMA has continued to revisit precisely what constitutes medical ethics for its members.']
['What were some of the revisions made to the code of medical ethics by the American Medical Association in 2008?', 'In 2008, its code of medical ethics was revised.']
['What updates or changes were made to the code of medical ethics by the American Medical Association in 2008?', '37']

['What is the implication of the revisions made to the code of medical ethics by the American Medical Association in 2008, in terms of education for healthcare professionals?', 'The revisions imply that education in medical ethics for healthcare professionals is not accomplished once and for all.']

['What is the importance of retraining and recertification for healthcare professionals in relation to the revisions made to the code of medical ethics in 2008?', 'Rather, retraining and recertification is an ongoing process.']

['Teacher: What has been the approach of large corporations when it comes to providing insurance plans for their employees, as mentioned in the passage?', 'More recently, large corporations have moved from providing one-size-fits-all insurance plans to compiling a menu of offerings to accommodate the different needs of their employees.']

['What is the reason behind large corporations offering a menu of insurance plans instead of a one-size-fits-all option, as discussed in the passage?', 'Workers with dependent children may opt for maximum health care coverage for their children.']

['What is the advantage for employees without dependents or a partner in electing a plan without coverage for dependent children, as mentioned in the passage?', 'Employees without dependents or a partner may elect a plan without this coverage and thereby pay lower premiums (the initial cost for coverage).']

['What is one possible way for employees to use the money saved from opting for a plan without coverage for dependent children, as discussed in the passage?', 'Yet others might minimize their health-insurance coverage and convert some of the employer costs that are freed up into added pension or retirement plan value.']

['What is one example of employees and employers being creative in tailoring benefit plans to suit the needs of employees, as mentioned in the passage?', 'Employers and workers have become creative in tailoring benefit plans that best suit the needs of employees.']

['What are some standard features of benefit plans that are mentioned in the passage?', 'Some standard features of such plans are the copayment, a set fee per service paid by the patient and typically negotiated between the insurance carrier and the employer; the annual deductible, a preset minimum cost for health care for which the patient is responsible each year before the carrier will assume subsequent costs; and percent totals for certain medical or dental procedures that patients must pay before the carrier picks up the remainder.']

['Teacher: Why have employers found the group coverage policies they offer to be expensive for them too?', 'Despite the intricacies of this customization, employers have found the group coverage policies they offer to be expensive for them too, more so with each passing year.']

['Teacher: Why is full health care coverage becoming rarer as a standard employment benefit?', 'Full health care coverage is becoming rarer as a standard employment benefit, and it is often available only to those who work full time.']

['Teacher: Why does California stipulate that most workers need not be provided with employer health care coverage unless they work at least twenty hours a week?', 'California, for example, stipulates that most workers need not be provided with employer health care coverage unless they work at least twenty hours a week.']

['Teacher: What factors have contributed to fewer employees having health care benefits at any given time?', 'Rising costs for both employers and employees have combined to leave fewer employees with health care benefits at any given time.']

['What are the consequences of employees having limited or no coverage for themselves and their dependents?', 'Employees with limited or no coverage for themselves and their dependents often cope by cutting back on the medical attention they seek, even when doing so places their health at risk.']

['Why is it an ethical quandary for employers when workers skip medical services due to cost considerations?', 'Whenever workers must skip medical services due to cost considerations, this places both them and their employers in an ethical quandary, because both typically want workers to be in good health.']

['What are some of the consequences for employers when their employees are unable to access necessary health care services?', 'Furthermore, when employees must deny their dependents appropriate health care, this dilemma is all the more intensified.']

['Teacher: What are some measures that companies have taken to minimize their expenses on employee health care insurance coverage?', 'To try to reduce the costs to themselves of employee health care insurance coverage, some companies have instituted wellness programs to try to ensure that their workforces are as healthy as possible.']

['What are some examples of wellness programs that companies have implemented to reduce their expenses on employee health care insurance coverage?', 'Some popular wellness program offerings are measures to help smokers quit, workout rooms on work premises or subsidized gym memberships, and revamped vending and cafeteria offerings that provide a range of healthier choices.']

['What are some other ways that companies incentivize their employees to participate in wellness programs besides offering bonuses or rewards?', 'Some companies even offer employees bonuses or other rewards for quitting smoking or achieving specific fitness goals such as weight loss or miles walked per week.']

['What is the benefit of companies implementing wellness programs for employee health care insurance coverage?', 'Such employer efforts appear benign at first glance, because these measures truly can produce better health on the part of workers.']

['What are some ethical questions that arise when companies implement wellness programs for employee health care insurance coverage?', 'Still, ethical questions arise as to who the true beneficiaries of such policies are.']

['What are some potential concerns or criticisms raised regarding the beneficiaries of wellness programs implemented by companies for employee health care insurance coverage?', 'We discuss this in the following paragraphs.']
['Teacher: What were wellness programs inspired by?', 'Wellness programs were inspired by safety programs first created by U.S. manufacturers in the 1960s.']
['What were some examples of U.S. manufacturers that first created safety programs in the 1960s?', 'These companies included Chrysler, DuPont, and Steelcase.']
['What was the purpose of safety programs created by U.S. manufacturers in the 1960s?', 'Safety programs were intended to reduce workplace accidents resulting in injuries and deaths.']

['What was the evolution of safety programs created by U.S. manufacturers in the 1960s?', 'Over the years, such programs slowly but steadily grew in scope to encompass the general health of employees on the job.']

['What has happened as wellness programs have expanded and grown in scope?', 'As these policies have expanded, they also have fostered some skepticism and resistance: “Wellness programs have attracted their share of criticism.']
['What is one of the criticisms that wellness programs have received?', 'Some critics argue workplace programs cross the line into employees’ personal lives.']

['What is one potential abuse that can occur in workplace wellness programs according to Ann Mirabito?', '”38 Ann Mirabito, a marketing professor at the Hankamer School of Business at Baylor University agrees there is potential for abuse: “It comes back to the corporate leader.']
['What does Ann Mirabito believe is the key to preventing potential abuse in workplace wellness programs according to the passage?', '. . .']

['What is the key to preventing potential abuse in workplace wellness programs according to Ann Mirabito?', 'The best companies respect employees’ dignity and offer programs that help employees achieve their personal goals.']
['According to the passage, what are some factors that contribute to the success of workplace wellness programs?', '”39']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what factors contribute to employees having a better chance of remaining well compared to their peers?', 'Employees who exercise, eat healthily, maintain their ideal weight, abstain from smoking, and limit their alcoholic consumption have a much better chance of remaining well than do their peers who undertake none of these activities.']

['Teacher: What is one benefit for employers when employees engage in healthy habits and remain well?', 'The participating employees benefit, of course, and so do their employers, because the health insurance they provide grows cheaper as their workers draw on it less.']

['Teacher: How can participating in smoking-cessation, weight-loss, and disease-screening programs benefit employees?', 'As Michael Hiltzik, a consumer affairs columnist for the Los Angeles Times, noted, “Smoking-cessation, weight-loss and disease-screening programs give workers the impression that their employers really care about their health.']

['What is the potential impact of employees participating in smoking-cessation, weight-loss, and disease-screening programs on employers?', 'Ostensibly they save money too, since a healthy workforce is cheaper to cover and less prone to absenteeism.']
['What are some of the benefits of having a healthy workforce for employers?', '”']
['What are some of the benefits of having a healthy workforce for employers?', '40']

['Teacher: How are employers benefiting from their efforts to reduce the cost of insuring their workers?', 'Certainly, employers are also serving their own interests by trying to reduce the cost of insuring their workers.']

["What concerns are raised regarding the transparency of workers' health profiles to their employers?", 'Hiltzik suggested one: “The dark downside is that ‘voluntary’ wellness programs also give employers a window into their workers’ health profiles that is otherwise an illegal invasion of their privacy.”41 Thus the health histories of workers become more transparent to their bosses, and, Hiltzik and others worry, this previously confidential information could allow managers to act with bias (in employee evaluation and promotion decisions, for instance) under cover of concern about employees’ health.']

['Teacher: What concerns do you have about the potential intrusion into employee privacy through wellness programs?', 'The potential for intrusion into employee privacy through wellness programs is alarming; further, the chance for personal health data to become public as a consequence of enrolling in such programs is concerning.']

['What argument do Herzog, McClain, and Rigard make regarding employee privacy when they enter the workplace?', 'Some, such as researchers Richard J. Herzog, Katie Counts McClain, and Kymberleigh R. Rigard, argue that workers surrender a degree of privacy simply by going onto payroll: “When employees enter the workplace, they forfeit external privacy.']

['What are some ways in which employee privacy can be compromised in wellness programs according to Herzog, McClain, and Rigard?', 'For example, BMI [body mass index] can be visually calculated, smokers can be observed, and food intake monitored.”']

['What do Herzog, McClain, and Rigard suggest about the balance between protecting privacy and enhancing productivity in wellness programs?', 'They acknowledge, however, that “protecting privacy and enhancing productivity can provide a delicate balance.']
['What are some potential consequences if the delicate balance between protecting privacy and enhancing productivity is not maintained in wellness programs?', '”42']

['Teacher: What is the official name of the health care reform act commonly referred to as the Affordable Care Act (ACA)?', 'Health care reform on a major scale emerged in the United States with the passage of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, more commonly known as the Affordable Care Act (ACA), in March 2010, during the Obama Administration.']
['What is the commonly known nickname for the Affordable Care Act?', 'The ACA (so-called Obamacare) represents a controversial plan that strikes its opponents as socialist.']

['What are the differing views on the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and how is it commonly referred to by its opponents?', 'For its supporters, however, it is the first effective and comprehensive plan to extend affordable health care to the widest segment of the U.S. population.']

['What is one reason why the Affordable Care Act (ACA) has been subject to revisions since becoming law?', 'Furthermore, like most new federal policies, it has undergone tweaks and revision each year since becoming law.']
['What are the sources of funding for the Affordable Care Act (ACA)?', 'The ACA is funded by a combination of payments by enrollees and supplemental federal monies earmarked for this task.']

['Teacher: What are some of the key mandates set by the Affordable Care Act (ACA) for health insurance carriers participating in the plan?', 'The ACA mandates a certain level of preventive care, a choice of physicians and health care facilities, coverage at no extra cost for individuals with preexisting health conditions, protection against the cancellation of coverage solely on the basis of becoming ill, and mental health and substance abuse treatment, all of which must be met by carriers that participate in the plan.']

['What are some of the key benefits guaranteed by the Affordable Care Act (ACA) for individuals who participate in the plan?', 'The ACA also permits its holders to select from a number of marketplace plans as opposed to the limited number of plans typically offered by any given employer.']
['How many plans are typically offered by any given employer, according to the passage?', '43']

['How does the availability of marketplace plans under the ACA compare to the number typically offered by any given employer, according to the passage?', 'All in all, it is a far-reaching and complex plan whose full implications for employers and their employees have yet to be appreciated.']

['What do preliminary results seem to indicate about the cost of employer-provided coverage compared to the Affordable Care Act (ACA) plans?', 'Preliminary results seem to indicate that employer-provided coverage on a comprehensive scale remains a cheaper alternative for those workers eligible to receive it.']
['What is the number of Affordable Care Act (ACA) plans offered compared to employer-provided coverage, according to the passage?', '44']

['What ethical issue arises when considering the efficiency of group insurance policies offered by U.S. employers, according to the passage?', 'Given the general efficiency of group insurance policies provided by U.S. employers, an ethical issue for all managers is whether these policies offer the best care for the greatest number of employees and so should be the responsibility of management to offer whenever it is possible to do so.']

['What are the requirements for companies employing fifty or more workers in terms of providing insurance coverage, according to the passage?', 'Current law requires all companies employing fifty or more workers to make insurance available to that part of their workforce that qualifies for such coverage (e.g., by virtue of hours worked).']

['What is the ethical obligation that small businesses have regarding insurance coverage for their employees, according to the passage?', 'Even if the law does not require it, we hold that an ethical obligation resides with small businesses to do everything in their power to provide this coverage for their employees.']

['Teacher: What is an example of the intense debate surrounding the Affordable Care Act?', 'Evidence of the intense debate the act has engendered is the Trump administration’s attempts, beginning in January 2017, to repeal the ACA entirely, or at least to dilute significantly many of its provisions.']

['What is one action taken by the Trump administration in regard to the Affordable Care Act shortly after President Trump took office?', 'Nearly immediately upon his inauguration, President Trump signed Executive Order 13765 in anticipation of ending the ACA.']

['What is the purpose of Executive Order 13765 signed by President Trump in relation to the Affordable Care Act shortly after his inauguration?', 'Also that same month, the American Health Care Act was introduced in the House of Representatives, again with an eye to eliminating or seriously weakening the existing act.']

['What was the response from proponents and opponents of the Affordable Care Act following the introduction of the American Health Care Act in 2017?', 'Much political debate within both the House and Senate ensued in 2017, with proponents of the ACA seeking to ensure its survival and opponents attempting (but, as of this writing, failing) to repeal it.']

['Teacher: What major milestone does the Affordable Care Act (ACA) represent in terms of health care coverage?', 'The ACA represents the first far-reaching health care coverage to take effect since 1965, after many stalled or otherwise frustrated attempts.']

['What were some of the attempts made by different presidential administrations to enlarge health care coverage before the Affordable Care Act?', 'Since the passage that year of the Medicare and Medicaid Act, which provided health coverage to retired, elderly, and indigent citizens, many presidential administrations, Democrat and Republican alike, have worked to enlarge health care coverage for different segments of the national population.']

['What were some of the direct implications for business proprietors and their employees as a result of the Medicare and Medicaid Act?', 'In addition to expanding eligibility for benefits, the Medicare and Medicaid Act had direct implications for business proprietors and their employees.']

['What were some of the responsibilities that employers were required to take on as a result of the Medicare and Medicaid Act?', 'For one, the act set up new automatic earnings deductions and tax schedules for workers and employers, and employers were made responsible for administering these plans, which help fund the programs’ benefits.']

['Teacher: What factors appear to determine the future of the ACA?', 'The future of the ACA appears to depend on whether a Democrat or Republican sits in the White House and which party controls the Senate and the House in the U.S. Congress.']

['Teacher: What implications does the statement "what is ethical does not lend itself to a majority vote" have on the future of the Affordable Care Act?', 'Although legislation does hinge on the political sentiments of the president and the majority party in Congress, what is ethical does not lend itself to a majority vote.']

['Teacher: How can the provision of health care continue to pose ethical implications for U.S. business and its employees, regardless of whether the ACA survives, is revised, or is replaced entirely?', 'So regardless of whether the ACA survives, is revised, or is replaced entirely by new health care legislation, the provision of health care will likely continue to pose ethical implications for U.S. business and the workers who are employed by it.']

['Teacher: What are the consequences for management and labor regarding the ethical debate over universal health care coverage, regardless of the outcome of the <mask> or other legislation?', 'The ethical debate over universal health care coverage is larger even than business and its employees, of course, but it still carries immense consequences for management and labor irrespective of how the ACA or other legislation fares in the halls of government and the courts.']

['What are some ethical dilemmas that employers may face in relation to providing health coverage for their workers?', 'An ethical dilemma for employers is the extent to which they should make health coverage available to their workers at affordable rates, particularly if federal and state government plans provide little or no coverage for residents and the costs of employer-provided coverage continues to climb.']

['Teacher: How have some individual states in the United States advanced the issue of health care coverage for their citizens in the context of federal attempts to institute national health care over the past several decades?', 'Against the backdrop of federal attempts to institute national health care over the past several decades, some individual states in the United States have used their own resources to advance this issue by proposing mandated health care coverage for their citizens.']

['What was the name of the act that Massachusetts passed in April 2006 to ensure near-universal health care coverage?', 'For example, in April 2006, Massachusetts passed An Act Providing Access to Affordable, Quality, Accountable Heath Care, the first significant effort at the state level to ensure near-universal health care coverage.']

['Teacher: What was the purpose of creating the Commonwealth Health Insurance Connector Authority in Massachusetts?', 'The Massachusetts act created a state agency, the Commonwealth Health Insurance Connector Authority, to administer the extension of health care coverage to Massachusetts residents.']

['What role did the Commonwealth Health Insurance Connector Authority play in the development of the federal ACA?', 'In many ways, it served as the most significant precursor of and guide for the federal ACA, which would follow approximately four years later.']

['What were some of the purposes and achievements of the Massachusetts legislation on health care coverage?', 'By many accounts, the Massachusetts legislation has achieved its purposes with few negative consequences.']

['Teacher: According to the Boston Globe examination, how did the Massachusetts legislation on health care coverage perform after five years of its passage?', 'As Brian C. Mooney, reporting in the Boston Globe, put it about five years after the act’s passage: “A detailed Globe examination [of the implementation of the act] makes it clear that while there have been some stumbles—and some elements of the effort merit a grade of ‘incomplete’—the overhaul, after five years, worked as well as or better than expected.']
['Based on the given dialog, what conclusion can be drawn about the performance of the Massachusetts legislation on health care coverage after five years of its passage?', '”45']

['Teacher: Can you provide me with an example of a state-level experiment with a single-payer health care plan, specifically mentioning the proposed Healthy California Act?', 'The proposed Healthy California Act (SB 562) is another example.']
['Teacher: When did SB 562 pass in the California State Senate?', 'SB 562 passed in the California State Senate in June 2017.']

['When did SB 562 pass in the California State Senate and why is a hearing necessary for the bill to advance to ratification?', 'However, the Speaker of the Assembly, the lower house of the legislature, blocked a hearing of the bill at that time, and a hearing is necessary for the bill to advance to ratification.']

['What was the outcome of the new effort in February 2018 to permit the bill to be considered by the lower house?', 'A new effort was initiated in February 2018 to permit the bill finally to be considered by the lower house.']

['bill are that the California bill would cover all residents regardless of immigration status, and it would eliminate co-pays and deductibles.)', '(Two differences between the California bill and the Massachusetts']

['What is one difference between the California bill and the Massachusetts Act, specifically in terms of the number of state residents who would be affected?', 'Act include the number of state residents who would be affected.']

['What is another difference between the California bill and the Massachusetts Act, specifically in terms of the scope of coverage for individuals?', 'Massachusetts has a population of about seven million compared to California’s nearly forty million.']
['Act is a mandate for individuals to obtain health insurance.', 'A second distinction is that SB 562 is constitutes a single-payer plan, whereas the Massachusetts']
['What is one difference between the California bill and the Massachusetts Act in terms of the requirement for individuals to obtain health insurance?', 'Act does not.)']

['Teacher: How would you describe the core principle of single-payer health care plans?', 'Single-payer health care plans essentially concentrate both the administration of and payment for health care within one entity, such as a state agency.']

["Teacher: Can you explain why California's single-payer health care plan is considered simple in principle but complex in its implementation?", 'California’s effort is a very simple plan on its face but complex in its implementation.']

['Teacher: What are the key components of California Senate Bill 562 that contribute to the complexity of its implementation?', 'Here is how Michael Hiltzik summarized the intent of California Senate Bill 562: “The program would take over responsibility for almost all medical spending in the state, including federal programs such as Medicare and Medicaid, employer-sponsored health plans, and Affordable Care Act plans.']

["Teacher: What are some of the programs and plans that California Senate Bill 562 aims to take responsibility for, according to Michael Hiltzik's summary?", 'It would relieve employers, their workers and buyers in the individual market of premiums, deductibles and copays, paying the costs out of a state fund.”46 The bill would create a large, special program apparatus tentatively entitled Healthy California.']

['Teacher: Why is the California Senate Bill 562 considered contentious and what factors contribute to its complexity?', 'It is contentious on many fronts, particularly in that it would create the largest single-payer health insurance plan sponsored by a U.S. state and the scope of the plan would necessitate a huge bureaucracy to administer it as well an infusion of state monies to sustain it.']

['Teacher: What is one specific aspect of the California Senate Bill 562 that makes it contentious and contributes to its complexity regarding health care coverage?', 'Furthermore, it would extend health care coverage to all residents of the state, including undocumented immigrants.']

['Teacher: What are some specific challenges that the passage of Healthy California faces?', 'A specific hurdle to passage of Healthy California is that it would cost anywhere from $370 billion to $400 billion and would require federal waivers so California could assume the administration of Medicare and Medicaid in the state as well as the federal funds currently allotted to it.']

['What are some challenges that would make meeting the conditions for the passage of Healthy California difficult and time consuming?', 'All these conditions would be enormously difficult and time consuming to meet, even if the federal government were sympathetic to California’s attempts to do so.']
["Teacher: Why was the federal government not sympathetic to California's attempts to meet the conditions for the passage of Healthy California in 2018?", 'In 2018, that was decidedly not the case.']

['Teacher: What is the context and the nature of the ethical question discussed in the passage?', 'This is a foundational ethical question that would invoke different responses on the part of nearly everyone you may ask.']

['Teacher: What type of system has the United States traditionally favored for paying for healthcare?', 'As a nation, the United States has usually preferred a system predicated on private health care providers and insurers to pay for it.']

['Teacher: What alternative approach has been explored by some states in recent years as a potential solution for healthcare payment?', 'This arrangement has worked best in instituting high-quality care with minimal delays even for elective medical procedures.']

['Teacher: How has the alternative approach of single-payer health care plans worked in terms of providing high-quality care and reducing delays for elective medical procedures?', 'It has systematically failed, however, in establishing any sort of universal dispensation that is affordable for many citizens.']

['Teacher: What is the current trend in the United States regarding the management of health care, particularly at the national or state level?', 'In the early twenty-first century, the United States is moving ever so slowly and with plenty of hiccups toward some degree of national or state management of health care.']

['Teacher: How would you describe the level of agreement and controversy surrounding the political, economic, and ethical dimensions of public management of health care in the United States?', 'The political, economic, and ethical dimensions of public management of our health care drive considerable controversy and very little agreement.']

['Teacher: What does the term telecommuting refer to?', 'The term telecommuting emerged in the 1970s to describe the practice of working at a specific location, whether the employee’s home or an alternate office, to reduce commuting time to a centrally located office space or store.']
['How did new telecommunications technology facilitate telework?', '“Telework” was greatly facilitated by new telecommunications technology, including the Internet, e-mail, and mobile phones.']

['What are some examples of employment types that fall under the category of telecommuting?', 'Today, telecommuting means any mode of working at a remote location (home or other space) by virtue of an electronic connection and/or telephone and encompasses a variety of employment types, from gig assignments to part-time contract work to traditional full-time employment.']

['Teacher: How many U.S. employees skip the commute for at least part of each week, according to the most recent Census data?', 'The most recent Census data reveal that almost four million U.S. employees skip the commute for at least part of each week, and according to a 2012 poll, worldwide, one in five workers telecommutes frequently, with approximately 10 percent working from home every day.']

['What countries are depicted in Figure 10.2 that show the growth of telecommuting?', '1 Figure 10.2 depicts the growth in telecommuting in the United States, China, India, France, Germany, and the United Kingdom.']

['What are some benefits that employers find in telecommuting and why are they embracing it?', 'Clearly, employers are embracing telecommuting as a tool for flexibility, on a scale from occasional use to full-time implementation.']
['What are some advantages that employees see in telecommuting and why are they opting for it?', '2']

['Teacher: How can employees connect to networked company computers from home to make real-time connections with their colleagues?', 'Employees can connect to networked company computers from home and use work-enhancing tools on their laptops, tablets, and smartphones to make real-time connections by voice, text, or video with inexpensive or free applications (or “apps”) like FaceTime and Skype.']

['How can employees make real-time connections with their colleagues using inexpensive or free applications?', 'Other software solutions, like GoToMeeting or WebEx, make setting up and even recording a synchronous meeting with sound and video possible for even the smallest companies at fairly low cost.']

['What is the potential for growth in the number and sophistication of communication and productivity tools for telecommuting?', 'The communication and productivity tools that facilitate telecommuting can only grow in number and sophistication.']

['What is an example of a virtual reality tool that allows workers to communicate with holographs of other people in real time?', 'Virtual reality tools like Microsoft’s Mixed Reality allow a worker in one location to communicate with the holograph of another person in real time.']
['What is an example of how telecommuting can facilitate remote job interviews?', 'For example, this technology could enable a job interview with a remote candidate.']

['What are some considerations or precautions that need to be taken into account when using technology for telecommuting?', 'Of course, the use of technology brings with it the need to ensure information security and protection against hacking, including guaranteeing the authenticity of the persons engaging via this technology.']
['Teacher: Why do employers allow employees to telecommute for a variety of reasons?', 'Employers allow employees to telecommute for a variety of reasons.']

['Why is telecommuting considered a powerful recruiting tool for people who want to balance their work and personal lives?', 'First, it is a powerful recruiting tool for people who want to balance their work and personal lives.']

['What is one benefit of telecommuting in terms of work-life balance?', 'It allows employees to work a more flexible schedule to care for children or older relatives while maintaining a career and earning income.']
['What is another advantage of telecommuting in terms of work-life balance?', '3']

['Teacher: What is one group of individuals who benefits from the flexibility of telecommuting in terms of work-life balance?', 'Individuals with ability challenges also prefer the flexibility that telecommuting affords them.']
['Teacher: How does telecommuting promote work-life balance for individuals with ability challenges?', '4']

['Teacher: How does telecommuting affect the amount of time employees spend traveling to and from work?', 'Telecommuting also reduces the hours that employees spend traveling to and from the job and can help keep cars off the road.']
['What is one advantage of telecommuting in relation to public transportation?', 'Fewer workers commuting equals less crowding on public transportation.']
['What is the numerical impact of telecommuting on the number of hours employees spend traveling to and from work?', '5']
['How does telecommuting contribute to reducing air pollution?', 'Fewer cars mean less air pollution as well.']

['What is one financial benefit for employees who telecommute?', 'The average U.S. employee (who commutes 30 miles and 60 minutes per day) will save more than $1000 on gas per year by telecommuting (along with associated costs of parking and vehicle upkeep and insurance).']
['What is the estimated annual financial savings for the average U.S. employee who telecommutes?', '6']
['What is one advantage of telecommuting in relation to inclement weather?', 'Remote workers can continue to do their jobs despite weather conditions that impede travel.']

['How does telecommuting affect the spread of illness among coworkers and sick leave?', 'They are not exposed to sick coworkers’ germs and may take fewer sick days (which sometimes translates to fewer sick days company-wide).']
['What is one advantage of telecommuting in relation to punctuality?', 'Remote employees are also seldom late for work or early to leave when their workday starts at home.']

['Teacher: What does the evidence suggest about telecommuting and its effects on worker productivity?', 'More broadly, there is a good deal of evidence suggesting that telecommuting has beneficial effects on worker productivity.']

["What specific findings were reported in the call-center study mentioned in the passage regarding telecommuting employees' productivity and job satisfaction?", 'For example, a call-center study reported in the Harvard Business Review found that telecommuting employees made 13.5 percent more calls, resigned their positions at only half the usual rate, and had much higher job satisfaction compared with employees who did not telecommute.']
["What were some of the specific benefits reported in the call-center study regarding telecommuting employees' job satisfaction?", '7']

["What were the specific findings reported in the study conducted by the Colorado Department of Transportation regarding telecommuting employees' productivity and call rates?", 'The Colorado Department of Transportation, in a study of telecommuting productivity for a branch that issued permits, found 48 percent faster turnaround times for issuing permits and 5 percent more calls for telecommuters.']
['What were some of the specific benefits reported in the study conducted by the Colorado Department of Transportation regarding telecommuting employees?', '8']

['How does the productivity of JD Edwards teleworkers compare to their office colleagues?', 'Furthermore, studies of JD Edwards teleworkers found them to be 20 to 25 percent more productive than their office colleagues; American Express employees who worked from home were 43 percent more productive than workers in the office.9']

['What are some factors that contribute to the increased productivity of teleworkers compared to their office colleagues?', 'With none of the distractions of a traditional office setting, like water-cooler gossip and long lunches, and with the happier attitude, workers tend to enjoy when they have control over their work lives.']

['What are some advantages of telecommuting in terms of efficiency, productivity, and worker retention?', 'Telecommuting facilitates increased efficiency and productivity and also typically results in higher retention of workers, thereby reducing recruiting and training costs for firms.']

['Teacher: What are some of the negative effects experienced by individuals who commute for an hour a day, as mentioned in the passage?', 'Studies have shown that a person who commutes for an hour a day experiences added stress, anxiety, social isolation, and possibly depression.']
['What is one advantage for companies that implement telecommuting, according to the passage?', '10 Perhaps that is why companies that implement telecommuting experience less absenteeism overall.']
['What are some personal advantages mentioned in the passage for individuals who telecommute?', '11']

['What are some advantages for companies that implement telecommuting, according to the passage?', 'It may also be easier to collaborate when not sharing a limited amount of space (such as in a cubicle forest), and people may be more willing to share resources with one another when the total number of workers present at the facility is reduced.']

['What are some personal advantages mentioned in the passage for individuals who telecommute?', 'Another point is that there may be less chatting and gossip among remote workers who are not in daily contact with each other or their colleagues.']
['Teacher: What are some other reasons that may make employers interested in telecommuting?', 'Employers may be attracted to telecommuting for other reasons.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how telecommuting can help reduce office-space costs for employers?', 'Having remote employees can reduce office-space costs.']
['Teacher: How does having remote employees reduce office-space costs for employers?', '12']

['Teacher: How can telecommuting help a company expand its operations without needing to invest in more physical facilities?', 'In fact, a company can consider expanding even when there is no available real estate or capital to enlarge or improve the physical facilities.']

['Teacher: What is one advantage that companies gain by widening their pool of potential applicants through hiring remote employees?', 'Companies that hire remote employees can also widen their pool of potential applicants.']
['What is the benefit that companies gain by widening their pool of potential applicants through hiring remote employees?', '13']

["Teacher: How can widening the pool of potential applicants through hiring remote employees benefit a company's sales and marketing territory expansion?", 'They can choose recruits with better job skills than the local population could provide and expand their sales and marketing territory by hiring employees based in a new area.']
['Teacher: What can you tell me about the external environmental benefits of telecommuting?', 'Finally, there are many external environmental benefits of telecommuting.']

['Teacher: Can you give me an example of how reducing total office space can benefit the environment in the context of telecommuting?', 'We have seen that a business that reduces total office space also reduces its impact on the environment.']

["Teacher: How does the increased individual consumption of utilities by remote workers while working at home compare to their home's energy consumption while they are at a traditional job?", '14 Remote workers would increase their individual consumption of utilities while working at home, but chances are that their home’s energy consumption partially continues during the time spent at a traditional job as well (Figure 10.3).']

["Teacher: Why did Yahoo's then-CEO, Marissa Mayer, end the company's work-at-home policy in 2013?", 'In 2013, Yahoo’s then–chief executive officer (CEO), Marissa Mayer, ended the company’s work-at-home policy, contending that the change would boost communication and collaboration by bringing people back to the office to work with their colleagues face to face.']

["Why did other companies like IBM, Aetna, and Bank of America also end their work-at-home policies, following the lead of Yahoo's then-CEO Marissa Mayer in 2013?", '15 IBM, Aetna, and Bank of America followed her lead, citing a greater need for collaborative communication to compete with smaller firms.']

['What was the reason for the backlash in the media after the announcement of ending the work-at-home policy at Yahoo?', '16 A backlash in the media followed this announcement, because working at home is popular among Yahoo employees.']
['What is the current stance of Yahoo regarding its work-at-home policy?', 'Yahoo has since shown greater flexibility in allowing some employees to once again work at home.']
["What is one potential benefit of bringing people back to the office to work with their colleagues face to face, according to Yahoo's then-CEO Marissa Mayer?", '17']

['What does recent research reveal about employee collaboration when they meet face to face to discuss projects?', 'But recent research does reveal that employees collaborate more creatively when they meet to discuss projects face to face.']

['What are the implications for firms dependent on research and development for their future growth, based on the finding that employees collaborate more creatively when they meet to discuss projects face to face?', 'This finding has important implications for firms dependent on research and development for their future growth.']

['What measures did Steve Jobs take to increase the likelihood of conversations that promote idea generation in the Pixar facility?', 'In fact, Steve Jobs designed the Pixar facility to increase the likelihood of conversations that would promote idea generation.']
['What are some drawbacks of telecommuting that were mentioned in the passage?', '18']
['Teacher: Why is it difficult to convey corporate culture over distance?', 'Corporate culture is not easy to convey over distance.']

['Why is it challenging for remote workers to convey their working habits and adapt to a different corporate culture?', 'The remote worker might have developed certain working habits at a different company with a different corporate culture (sometimes in another country).']

["What are the challenges that remote workers face when trying to adapt to a new company's culture while working remotely?", 'It can be challenging to help employees adapt to the culture of a new company when they work remotely.']
['What are some drawbacks of telecommuting in terms of building a cohesive and collaborative team culture?', '19']

['Teacher: What is one of the drawbacks mentioned in the passage regarding monitoring work-related progress for employers when employees are telecommuting?', 'It is also more difficult for employers to monitor some kinds of work-related progress when an employee is working remotely.']

['What is a potential consequence of the increased likelihood of miscommunication when work must be transmitted electronically or virtually?', 'The likelihood of miscommunication increases when everything must be transmitted electronically or virtually.']
['What is one consequence of not being able to "manage by walking around" when an employee is working remotely?', '20 A manager cannot “manage by walking around” when the worker is remote.']

['What is one disadvantage for employers regarding the lack of incidental opportunities to observe employee interactions with clients or customers when telecommuting?', 'There are no incidental opportunities to witness a worker interacting with a client or customer.']

['What is one disadvantage for employees regarding the potential increase in hesitation to ask for direction on a project when telecommuting?', '21 Workers may also be more hesitant to ask for direction on a project.']
['What is one concern that some managers have regarding employee productivity when telecommuting?', 'Some managers worry that employees will slack off if there is no one there to watch them.']
['What is one drawback mentioned in the passage about the potential decrease in team collaboration and camaraderie when employees are telecommuting?', '22']

['Teacher: What concerns might a remote worker have when it comes to privacy during the workday?', 'The remote worker may have qualms about privacy when his or her personal life inevitably intersects with the workday (as when a family member walks into the room or the dog barks during a conference call).']

["How might a remote worker's availability for family responsibilities be affected?", '23 Children may be confused when it seems like their parent is home but is not available for meals or play or homework help.']

['What are some potential challenges that remote workers face in terms of maintaining a work-life balance?', 'It may be difficult for remote workers to maintain a work-life balance when their home becomes their office (especially if their hours are flexible).']

['How might the financial cost of setting up a home office impact remote workers?', 'Workers may have to set aside living space for a home office and spend money to buy computing equipment, a desk, and other supplies.']

['Teacher: Why is it difficult for an on-site technology team to provide technical assistance or secure data at the required level when people are working from home?', 'Furthermore, it is difficult for an on-site technology team to provide technical assistance or secure data at the level the company may require when people are working at home.']

['Teacher: What is one reason why an on-site technology team may find it challenging to provide technical assistance or secure data at the required level when people are working from home?', 'The employer is unable to exercise the same control over safety measures that holds in a traditional workplace.']
['What is one reason why an employer may be unable to exercise the same control over safety measures when employees are working from home?', '24']
['Teacher: What other potential drawbacks or concerns are mentioned in the passage?', 'There may also be productivity concerns.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how remote workers can overcome productivity concerns and motivate themselves to work diligently?', 'Some remote workers will rise to the challenge of motivating themselves to work diligently.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for remote workers to find ways to motivate themselves to work diligently?', 'In fact, studies have shown that some remote workers are more productive than their traditional counterparts.']
['Teacher: How does the productivity of remote workers compare to that of traditional workers, according to studies?', '25']

['What challenge does the process of sorting potential employees into workers and procrastinators pose for employers when it comes to remote work?', 'But it is not easy to sort potential employees into workers and procrastinators without some period of trial and error, which may be costly.']
['Teacher: Why are not all fields equally suited to telecommuting?', 'Not all fields are equally suited to telecommuting.']

['Why do some jobs require consistent in-person contact with clients or customers?', 'Some jobs require consistent in-person contact with clients or customers, such as counseling, physical therapy, and medicine.']
['Teacher: Why do industries such as banking and finance require the highest computer security?', '26 Some industries need the highest computer security, such as banking and finance.']

['Why do some work settings, such as law enforcement, have increased needs for building security?', 'Other work settings, such as law enforcement, have increased needs for building security that would make working remotely an unsafe alternative for employees.']
['What are some potential drawbacks of telecommuting for employees in fields that require constant collaboration and teamwork?', '27']

['Teacher: What does recent research show about employer attitudes regarding telecommuting?', 'The biggest drawback of telecommuting for the individual employee is the bias that studies reveal in employer attitudes.']

['Teacher: Why does the passage mention that the bias in employer attitudes towards telecommuting is a drawback for individual employees?', 'Most managers, after all, attained their status in a traditional job.']

['What advantage do employees who work in the physical presence of their employer have over those who telecommute?', 'When some employees telecommute and others do not, those who are in the physical presence of the employer every day can more easily make an impression (good or bad) simply by interacting with their manager.']

['What might be a potential consequence for employees who choose to telecommute if they are seen as lazy or less dedicated compared to those who work traditional hours?', 'There is also some indication that employees who opt for a nontraditional work arrangement may be penalized if they are perceived as lazy or less dedicated than those who maintain traditional work hours.']

['What is one reason why employers might have a stronger recollection of the work produced by employees they see regularly compared to remote employees?', 'Employers might have a stronger recollection of the work produced by the employee they see regularly than they do of the work a remote employee is submitting online.']

['What is one potential consequence for employees who telecommute in terms of promotions and important projects?', 'Therefore, promotions and important projects may go to employees who are more visible.']

['What is one potential outcome for remote employees who are consistently overlooked for promotions and important projects?', 'The remote employee might eventually be left without equal footing in the push for increased pay and status.']

['Teacher: What are some of the potential ethical challenges that employers must navigate when managing remote employees?', 'Ethical employers must juggle the potential ethical challenges of managing remote employees, including developing trust in remote workers, encouraging trust among project team members when some are working remotely, keeping equity in mind when reviewing the performance of remote and in-office staff, and deciding which employees get to work remotely.']

['What are some examples of potential ethical challenges that supervisors face when managing remote workers?', 'Supervisors also must guard against abuse of the remote-work opportunity, maintain the security of the remote employee’s work-related data, foster a level of collaboration that is vital to product development, and protect the remote worker’s safety.']

['Teacher: Why should managers categorize jobs rather than people when considering telecommuting?', 'Although it is easy to consider allowing telecommuting for those who simply ask, managers should instead categorize jobs (not people) by their suitability for remote work.']

['What is the advantage of categorizing jobs rather than people when considering telecommuting?', 'Best Buy recently announced it would modify its work-from-home policy for employees in its corporate office, changing it from a perquisite (or “perk”) of employment to one granted by management on a case-by-case basis and mindful of the circumstances of individual workers.']
['What is the significance of the number 29 in the given dialog?', '29']

['Teacher: What is one important action that managers should take in relation to telecommuting?', 'Managers should also carefully set up a framework of policies to govern at-home work and ensure fairness.']
['Teacher: Why is it important for managers to set up a framework of policies for telecommuting?', 'For example, there could be a standard for how much time each person should spend in the office.']

['What was the purpose of the remote pilot project created by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology?', 'The Massachusetts Institute of Technology created a remote pilot project in its Executive Education Program.30 Employees were encouraged to work remotely two or three days each week and to be present in the office each Wednesday.']

['What was the recommendation of the employees after participating in the remote pilot project created by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology?', 'After six months of the pilot program, 100 percent of the employees recommended its continuation.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of clear expectations that managers should set for remote workers in terms of professionalism and productivity?', 'Managers should set clear expectations for remote workers, such as maintaining professionalism while working and accomplishing a certain volume of work or number of tasks by a certain time.']

['What are some possible rewards that managers could offer to remote workers who meet their goals of maintaining professionalism and achieving a certain volume of work or number of tasks?', 'Those who meet these goals should be rewarded.']

['What is the importance of treating remote workers in terms of expectations and rewards the same as in-house workers?', 'In the interests of fairness and equity, neither expectations nor rewards should differ from those established for in-house workers.']

['Teacher: How does the ethical employer demonstrate trust in employees when implementing telecommuting?', 'The ethical employer communicates trust in his or her employees when implementing telecommuting.']

["How does the ethical employer communicate trust in employees' motivation and work-life balance when implementing telecommuting?", 'That trust is based on respect for the employee’s motivation and the recognition that the employee has needs that are important in establishing work-life balance.']
["How does the recognition of employee's needs for work-life balance contribute to establishing trust in the ethical employer's implementation of telecommuting?", '31']

['What is one possible reason for the increase in productivity in successful telecommuting programs?', 'Perhaps the employer’s vote of confidence in the employee’s ability to work well remotely is the reason that productivity tends to increase in successful telecommuting programs.']
['What can be learned from the Figure 10.4 caption about successful telecommuting programs?', '32 The Figure 10.4 caption lists some of the best practices of successful telecommuting programs.']

['Teacher: What is said about placing workers in a new situation without assistance and the ethical implications involved?', 'It would be unethical to place workers without assistance in a new situation in which they can easily fail.']

['What specific skills should telecommuting workers be trained in to maintain their productivity and handle the challenges of working in a new environment?', 'Telecommuting workers must be trained in time-management skills so they can maintain their productivity in an environment that may have more or different distractions than a traditional workplace and may make different demands on their time.']

['What are some additional skills besides time-management that telecommuting workers should be trained in to maintain their productivity and handle the challenges of working in a new environment?', 'Training should also strengthen communication skills, such as responding to messages promptly, that help ensure success in a remote setting.']

['What is one important aspect that an ethical company should consider to prevent telecommuting employees from being unfairly overlooked or forgotten?', 'To help guard against the risk that telecommuting employees will be unfairly considered “out of sight, out of mind,” the ethical company will adopt written expectations about timely communication in both directions.']

['What are some measures an ethical company can take to ensure open lines of communication between managers and telecommuting employees?', 'For instance, it should ensure that managers’ lines of communication are as open to their remote employees as they are to those who can drop by their desk or office to chat.']

['Teacher: What is one common practice that successful firms with telecommuting programs implement to foster a sense of connectivity among their remote employees?', 'Finally, many firms with successful telecommuting programs create a social network among employees.']

['What is one specific example of an online social occasion that successful firms with telecommuting programs may sponsor?', 'They sponsor online social occasions to help employees bond even though they are not in the same place.']

['What is the purpose of sponsoring online social occasions for remote employees in successful firms with telecommuting programs?', 'Workers can then find a way to have some virtual fun, despite the distance that might separate them.33']

['Teacher: What are the characteristics of traditional workspaces in terms of work completion, environment, and distractions?', 'Traditional workspaces are designed to allow each person to get the maximum amount of work completed each day, spending most of the time alone in a fairly utilitarian environment with minimal distractions.']

['Teacher: What are some of the characteristics of traditional workspaces that indicate status and provide opportunities for social interactions?', 'The size and location of the offices indicate status (corner offices are prized), and lunchrooms or cafeterias and water coolers provide the only place for brief social encounters.']
['Teacher: How do state-of-the-art workplaces today differ from historical precedents?', 'State-of-the-art workplaces today, however, incorporate technology and encourage collaboration.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of how state-of-the-art workplaces today incorporate technology and encourage collaboration?', 'Ergonomic furniture is available for comfort, and laptops and tablets allow workers to move around the facility as desktop computers could not.']

['Teacher: How does the incorporation of technology and flexibility in state-of-the-art workplaces today impact the amount of time workers spend at their desks compared to historical precedents?', 'In fact, workers in the new flexible workplace spend less than 50 percent of their time at a desk.']

['Teacher: In addition to the flexibility of working away from a desk, what are some other ways that state-of-the-art workplaces today promote collaboration among workers?', '37 Moreover, as we discussed in the previous section, many enjoy the flexibility of telecommuting as needed.']

['Teacher: How does the absence of status signaling through location or size in open-plan workplaces promote collaboration among workers?', 'Furthermore, in open-plan spaces, all work positions locations are alike; status is not signaled by location or size.']

['Teacher: How did the workplace campuses of large companies in the 1960s compare to the campus settings of Apple and Google today?', 'As early as the 1960s, large companies like Bell Labs built suburban compounds for their corporate headquarters, but they were a far cry from the campus settings of Apple and Google today.']

['What are some key differences between the workplace campuses of large companies like Bell Labs in the 1960s and the campus settings of Apple and Google today?', 'Bell Labs’ design, for example, was a series of laboratories and office buildings grouped together, with a functional cafeteria.']

['Teacher: In what ways are workplace campuses similar to university campuses?', 'Workplace campuses are also modeled on university campuses that provide a relatively complete work and living environment for students.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how workplace campuses like Facebook and Google are incorporating the concept of a "relatively complete work and living environment" for their employees?', 'As noted, Facebook and Google are building apartments near their corporate campuses.']

['Teacher: How are workplace campuses like Facebook\'s Willow Village incorporating the concept of a "relatively complete work and living environment" for their employees?', 'Facebook’s new project, named Willow Village, is near Menlo Park, California, and will include some fifteen hundred units.']
["Teacher: What is one benefit that employees who lease an apartment in Facebook's Willow Village will receive?", 'Employees who lease an apartment there will be eligible for a company bonus.']
["What is the significance of the number 38 in the context of Facebook's Willow Village?", '38']

["What is the connection between the number 38 and the concept of workplace campuses like Facebook's Willow Village?", 'The future workplace campuses and mega-corporate campuses with housing bear a superficial resemblance to nineteenth- and early twentieth-century “company towns,” which existed around the world.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of a company town and how it relates to the workplace campuses we are discussing?', 'In a company town, the stores, entertainment venues, and housing were all owned by the same company, which also employed everyone in a local factory or mine.']
['What were some key features of a company town and how did it impact the lives of the people living there?', '39']

['What were the benefits and drawbacks of living in a company town for the workers?', 'The remote locations of factories sometimes made it necessary for such employers to provide workers with housing and a means to acquire the necessities of life, but those who lived and worked in the company town paid for all purchases from their wages, which, of course, went straight back to the employer.']

['What were some examples of company towns and who were the individuals responsible for their creation?', 'The owners and builders of company towns, like George Pullman or Henry Ford, were often idealists who envisioned creating a social utopia.40']
['How did the owners of company towns like George Pullman and Henry Ford envision creating a social utopia?', 'But the towns and their owners could also be paternalistic and self-serving.']

['What is the impact of a monopsony in a labor market, specifically in the context of company towns?', 'Indeed, company towns created what is called a monopsony in the labor market, where there is only a single buyer, and the economic analysis of monopsony shows that with the lack of competition for labor, wages of workers are suppressed.']
['What is the effect of suppressed wages on the workers in a company town?', 'That is, “a monopsonist in the labor market can leverage its market power.']
['How does the leverage of market power by a monopsonist affect the wages of workers in a company town?', 'Because it is the only firm hiring, it can pay its workers less.']
['What are some potential consequences of the monopsonistic power of a company town on the wages of its workers?', '”41']
['Teacher: What was one significant factor that contributed to the decline of company towns?', 'Company towns began to disappear when cars became affordable and employees could drive to work.']

['What effect did the affordability of cars have on the working conditions in company towns?', 'However, all that driving lengthened some workdays and disrupted the balance people enjoyed between working hours and personal time.']
['What is one proposed solution to reduce the time employees spend commuting to work?', 'Like telecommuting, corporate villages are one approach to cut down drive time.']

["What are some concerns raised by critics regarding Facebook's Willow Village and its impact on work-life balance?", 'However, critics of Facebook’s Willow Village are calling the property “Zucktown” and wondering whether the development will further blur the work-life balance for employees of Mark Zuckerberg’s social media company.']

['Teacher: How many U.S. employees in multiple industries were surveyed and reported feeling "super stressed" as they juggled work and home responsibilities?', 'Twenty-five percent of U.S. employees in multiple industries were recently surveyed and reported feeling “super stressed” as they juggled work and home responsibilities.']
['Teacher: What percentage of U.S. employees in multiple industries reported feeling "super stressed" while managing work and home responsibilities?', '42']

['Teacher: What are some health effects that can be caused by daily stress from trying to maintain work-life balance?', 'Daily stress from trying to maintain work-life balance can produce health effects like reduced immunity and inadequate sleep.']
['Teacher: How can daily stress from striving for work-life balance affect work productivity?', 'Stressed workers are also less productive in the workplace.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of employers offering an ever-widening array of amenities to employees?', 'Efforts to offer employees an ever-widening array of amenities appear to be an effort by employers to create work-life balance and make their companies more desirable as places of employment.']

['Teacher: How does offering an ever-widening array of amenities contribute to creating work-life balance and making companies more desirable as places of employment?', 'The idea is that life is simpler if food is readily available and free at work, if a doctor’s office or hair salon is just down the hall, and if home is right on campus.']

['Teacher: What is the belief of millennials regarding the integration of work and leisure in fostering work-life balance?', 'Some research shows that millennials believe integrating work and leisure in some combination fosters work-life balance.']
['Teacher: According to the passage, what does the number "43" refer to in the context of millennials\' belief about work-life balance?', '43']

['What is the reason behind millennials seeing less need to have clear boundaries between their work world and home life?', 'They may see less need to have clear boundaries between their work world and their home life as technology pushes them to be connected in so many ways that once did not exist but now seem inescapable (e.g., an employee of a global firm that conducts business around the clock may never be truly separated from the office due to connectivity provided by mobile devices).']

['Teacher: How can living right next to work potentially promote work-life balance?', 'Living right next to work clearly will reduce commuting time, and via this path, it may promote work-life balance.']

['What is a potential downside to living right next to work in terms of work-life balance?', 'But the expectation that long hours should be routine just because they are possible will hamper, rather than facilitate, the quest for work-life balance.']

['Teacher: How does reduced worker mobility due to living next to work affect labor markets and their ability to adapt to change in conditions?', 'Furthermore, to the extent that mega-corporate campuses do tie workers to their jobs, reduced worker mobility means that labor markets will be less able to adjust to changing conditions.']

['Teacher: What is the attitude towards a job that offers amenities similar to a campus-like environment?', 'It is hard to imagine that anyone could find fault with a job that came with all the amenities of a campus-like environment.']

["Teacher: Why does a manager's job description greatly expand in a workplace that offers amenities similar to a campus-like environment?", 'However, the all-encompassing aspect of these workplaces means a manager’s job description greatly expands to include small-city management functions.']
