['What is one significant reason why corporate campuses may have a greater need for security?', 'As the April 2018 shooting of employees at YouTube’s headquarters suggests, corporate campuses may have a greater need for security, with duties that dovetail those of the city police.']

['Why is the growth of the compound challenging for managers in terms of complying with city planning and zoning regulations?', 'Growth of the compound will challenge managers to comply with city planning and zoning regulations.']
['Teacher: What is involved in job sharing?', 'In job sharing, two or more employees perform the work of a full-time position, each taking part of the total workload for the job.']

['Teacher: How do the employees divide the workload in job sharing?', 'For example, one job-sharing employee might work three eight-hour shifts a week and the other would take two such shifts at the same job.']
['Teacher: How do employees divide the workload in job sharing?', 'In some ways, job sharing is simply another name for part-time work.']

['Teacher: What is another name for job sharing according to the passage?', 'The two people need not work equal numbers of hours, but they perform a single job, doing the same tasks and shouldering the same responsibilities.']

['Teacher: How are the responsibilities and tasks divided between the two employees in job sharing?', 'Unlike nurses, who work shifts but each has their own job, job sharers work one job between them.']

['Teacher: Why do most people in the United States seek a full-time job of thirty-five hours a week or more?', 'Most people in the United States seek a full-time job of thirty-five hours a week or more, usually because they want the income and benefits (such as health insurance) that often come with such a job.']

['Teacher: What are some reasons why people may choose to forego full-time work and opt for job sharing or flextime?', 'But some are willing to forego full-time work because they need or want to care for children or an elderly or ailing family member, pursue their education, run a business on the side, or volunteer.']

['Teacher: How can job sharing contribute to enhanced work-life balance for individuals?', 'Allowing two people to share a job is an option that can lead to enhanced work-life balance for both individuals.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how job sharing can lead to cost savings for individuals?', 'A job-sharing parent can work weekends only, for example, saving on daycare costs during the week.']
['Teacher: According to the passage, what benefits do many job sharers report experiencing?', 'Many job sharers report less stress and an increased ability to produce high-quality work.']
['What does the passage suggest about the relationship between job sharing and productivity?', 'Studies have shown that many accomplish more in a shorter workweek due to higher morale.']

['Teacher: How does job sharing potentially contribute to reducing absenteeism among employees with children?', '49 Typically there is less absenteeism when the team can plan around the appointments and vacations of each individual.50 Job sharing may also reduce the absenteeism of employees with children by providing increased flexibility to cover family emergencies or obligations.']

['What is one advantage of job sharing mentioned in the passage that can contribute to problem-solving?', 'There is even a synergistic effect when two people bring their insights to problems that one person would usually face alone.']
['What is the potential effect of job sharing on job satisfaction, according to the passage?', '51']

['Teacher: How do employers benefit from hiring two individuals to fill one job in terms of talent acquisition?', 'Employers find that hiring two individuals to fill one job also opens the door to recruiting new talent.']

['Teacher: How does job sharing help employers retain knowledgeable associates who may wish to reduce their work hours?', 'Job sharing might allow an employer to retain a knowledgeable associate who is ready to cut back work hours.']

['Teacher: How does job sharing enable employers to ensure a smooth transition and knowledge transfer when an employee is leaving or retiring?', 'Furthermore, an employee who is leaving or retiring can share the job for a time to train a replacement.']
['Teacher: How do job sharers typically apply for jobs?', 'Many job sharers apply for jobs as a team.']

['Teacher: What is one important strategy that job sharers recommend in order to have a successful job-sharing arrangement?', 'Those who have successfully shared a job advocate for setting clear performance expectations and progress checkpoints.']
['Teacher: How can job sharers ensure effective communication and collaboration with each other?', 'Two employees might share an e-mail account and brief each other daily on their work.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a job sharing arrangement where the employees work different shifts?', '52 Specific examples include translators of legal documents at an international law firm—one translator takes the morning shift; the other, the afternoon.']

['Teacher: Can you provide another specific example of a job sharing arrangement where the employees work different shifts?', 'Or technical writers at an engineering firm—one might work Monday through Wednesday noon; the other, Wednesday afternoon through Friday.']
['Teacher: What is one important factor to consider when designing a job sharing arrangement?', 'This scenario works when common documents are being written or translated.']

['What is a key aspect of effective job sharing arrangements when the employees have different shifts?', 'If the job sharers are equally competent, work can be passed off to one another at specific intervals.']
['Teacher: What are some aspects of job sharing that benefit employers?', 'Other aspects of job sharing actually benefit employers, but not necessarily employees.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how job sharing benefits employers in terms of cost savings?', 'Replacing a full-time position with two or more part-time employees may allow an employer to avoid paying for the benefits to which a full-time employee would be entitled, such as health insurance mandated by the Affordable Care Act, and sometimes optional benefits as well.']
['What is the relationship between the number of involuntary part-time workers and the business cycle?', 'The number of involuntary part-time workers varies over the course of the business cycle:']

['Teacher: How does the number of involuntary part-time workers change during an economic downturn compared to a period of economic growth?', 'In 2009, as a consequence of the Great Recession, U.S. Department of Labor statistics put the number of involuntary part-time workers at more than nine million; in mid-2018, that number was just below five million.']
['How does the number of involuntary part-time workers in mid-2018 compare to the number in 2009?', '53']
['Teacher: Can you please explain what some of the purely business drawbacks to job sharing are?', 'There are some purely business drawbacks to job sharing.']
['Teacher: Why does job sharing not work in all fields?', 'First, the practice does not work in all fields.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how coordination issues can impact the quality of work in job sharing partnerships?', 'Second, some work can suffer because of the extra time, and sometimes expense, necessary for coordination between job-sharing partners, especially if neither is formally in charge.']

['Teacher: How can competitive instincts within a job sharing partnership affect the outcome of a project?', '54 Job-sharing arrangements also presuppose that the two people are going to work together collaboratively, but competitive instincts could lead one partner to withhold information or even sabotage the project.']

['Teacher: How does the "two Mondays effect" impact the overall productivity of a job sharing partnership?', 'Another drawback is the “two Mondays effect”—the potential productivity loss due to the time it takes each partner to get up to speed on the first day back.']
['Teacher: What is one reason why some managers are reluctant to engage in job sharing?', '55 Finally, some managers do not want the added responsibility of managing two people instead of one.']

['Teacher: What is the ethical question that arises when it comes to job sharing?', 'The ethical question raised by job sharing boils down to whether the employer is hiring job sharers to improve productivity and meet employee preferences, or hiring part-time workers to improve profitability at the employees’ expense.']

['Teacher: How does an ethical employer view the purpose of hiring job sharers and part-time workers in relation to productivity and profitability?', 'The ethical employer hires employees to best serve the needs of the customer and the company while respecting the needs of each employee.']
['Teacher: What is the first step in ethically managing a job-sharing partnership?', 'The first step in ethically managing a job-sharing partnership is to pick the right job to share.']

['Teacher: How does the ease of managing a job-sharing partnership relate to the type of job being shared?', 'Data-entry jobs and those that require less supervision and coordination between partners are more easily managed.']

['Teacher: What steps should be taken by a manager to create a shared written agreement in a job-sharing partnership?', 'Then, with both employees present, the manager should spend some time creating a shared written agreement about procedures to follow and responsibilities to accept.']

['Teacher: How can a manager ensure that job sharers are working cooperatively and meeting their goals?', '56 Follow-up is important to be sure job sharers are working cooperatively and meeting their goals.']

['Teacher: What is flextime and how does it allow employees to customize their work hours?', 'The practice of offering flexible hours, or flextime, lets employees choose their own start and finish time each day, arriving and leaving earlier or later than the normal 9-to-5 workday.']

['Teacher: What is one specific group of employees that benefit from the flexibility of flextime and why?', 'Parents benefit particularly because they are better able to schedule their work around their children’s lives.']
['Teacher: What is one specific reason why women benefit the most from the flexibility offered by flextime?', 'Women are the predominant users of this family-friendly work policy.']
['Teacher: How does job sharing differ from flextime in terms of the number of employees involved?', '57']
['Teacher: What was a starting place for creative new approaches to work?', 'Flextime was a starting place for creative new approaches to work.']
["Teacher: How do teams currently manage to accommodate their members' need for time off?", 'Teams now trade shifts to accommodate members’ needs for time off.']

['Teacher: What is one alternative work schedule that some companies allow to accommodate efficient employees?', 'Some companies allow a compressed work week that caters to the efficient employee who can get a week’s work done in less than forty hours.']

['Teacher: What is one profession where employees might be allowed a reduced schedule during the off season?', 'In some professions, such as accounting, employees might be allowed a reduced schedule during the off season.']
['Teacher: How many hours does a typical part-time job entail?', '58']
['Teacher: How do these variations in job sharing and flextime benefit employers in terms of workforce diversity?', 'All these variations allow employers to recruit a more diverse workforce.']

['Teacher: How does the availability of job sharing and flextime help in expanding the pool of potential employees for employers seeking workforce diversity?', 'No longer is it necessary that someone be free of weekday responsibilities to have full-time work and gainful employment.']

['What is one benefit of flextime that extends beyond the employers and also benefits clients and customers?', 'Flextime also benefits clients and customers because companies can extend their hours of operation when workers are willing to cover flexible shifts.']
['How can job sharing and flextime contribute to improving work-life balance for employees?', '59']

['Teacher: What do ethical employers base their decision to allow flextime on?', 'Ethical employers base the decision to allow flextime on a clear and well-written policy that relies on objective job-related criteria.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for ethical employers to have a clear and well-written policy for flextime based on objective job-related criteria?', 'Without an objective policy, employees could claim discrimination if all were not eligible.']

['Why is it important for employers to be aware of the law regarding daily work hours and overtime when implementing flextime?', '60 Employers should also be aware of the law; in some states, daily work hours are set by law, and allowing some employees to work more than eight hours a day might require payment of overtime.']

['Teacher: What have some studies found regarding employees who request a later start to the workday?', 'Some studies have found a troubling bias against employees who request a later start to the workday.']

['Teacher: What is one reason why managers may incorrectly perceive employees who prefer a late start as less motivated?', '61 Managers may incorrectly regard people who prioritize an early start as more desirable employees and attribute a request for a late start to lack of motivation.']

['Teacher: What skills do managers need in order to effectively manage teams where some employees are working flexible hours and others are not?', 'Managers need greater supervisory skills to ensure flextime workers are using their time productively and to effectively manage teams in which some are working flexible hours and others are not.']

['Teacher: What is the main characteristic of the access economy in terms of consumer participation?', 'The access economy is essentially a resource circulation system in which consumers participate on both sides of a transaction, as both providers and obtainers of resources (the transaction is usually facilitated by a third party acting as a go-between).']

['What is the popular name for the access economy model when the asset is expensive to obtain and not fully consumed by the user?', 'The model, sometimes called peer-to-peer (or P2P), is particularly popular when the asset is expensive to obtain and is not fully consumed by the user (such as a house or condo).']

['What is the fundamental difference between the traditional capitalist economic model and the access or sharing economy model?', 'In the traditional capitalist economic model, goods are bought and sold by businesses and individuals, but in the access or sharing economy, goods and services are traded on the basis of access rather than ownership.']
['Teacher: What is the primary way owners in the access economy make money?', 'In this business model, owners make money from underused assets.']
['What is an example of a global online hospitality marketplace?', 'The global online hospitality marketplace is an example.']

['What is the average income earned by consumer-hosts in San Francisco through home rentals on Airbnb?', 'Airbnb says consumer-hosts in San Francisco who rent out their homes do so for an average of about sixty nights a year, making almost $10,000 from such rentals.']

['What is the average monthly income earned by car owners using the service RelayRides?', 'Car owners using the service RelayRides make an average of $250 a month from allowing others to use their cars.']

['What is one benefit for consumers in participating in the access economy and sharing their assets?', 'This helps consumers supplement their incomes or even finance the purchase of the assets they share.']

['What are some examples of household names in the sharing economy and P2P decentralized markets?', 'Many of the original sharing-economy businesses are now household names, including Airbnb, Uber, and Lyft; thousands more are part of the P2P decentralized markets.']

['Teacher: How do sharing or collaborative economy business models primarily operate in terms of conducting transactions?', 'Most sharing or collaborative economy business models use the Internet to facilitate transactions, so it might be more accurate to refer to them as part of the online platform economy.']

['Teacher: Can you provide examples of sharing or collaborative economy business models that primarily facilitate the renting of assets?', 'However, whereas some facilitate the renting of assets, such as real estate (think Airbnb), others are essentially selling labor (think Task Rabbit), and some bridge the two categories by offering a combination (think Lyft) (see Figure 10.7).']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the sharing or collaborative economy business models create a decentralized and democratized marketplace?', 'The new business models all have something in common, however: a decentralized and democratized marketplace featuring broad-scale participation, with consumers serving multiple roles.']

['Teacher: What is one of the benefits of online and digital business models, according to the passage?', 'Online and digital business models allow almost anyone to start a business from scratch in what some call the democratization of free enterprise.']

['How does the democratization of free enterprise through online and digital business models benefit buyers?', 'An economy so open to new players is a significant step toward increased buyer access to goods and services at all levels, even as it raises legitimate questions about how to ensure trust between the transacting parties.']
['Teacher: What is one issue that the access economy currently faces?', 'One issue facing the access economy is regulation.']

['Teacher: What specific taxes are access economy participants increasingly likely to be charged with?', 'They are not only subject to income taxes on the money they earn but they are increasingly likely to be charged hotel or occupancy taxes.']

['What are some specific regulations that cities have put in place regarding real estate rentals in the access economy?', 'Some cities have passed ordinances to limit real estate rentals to minimum stays of a week or a month; shorter stays will be considered hotel rentals subject to regulations such as health and safety code rules.']

['What are some specific regulations that cities have implemented for ride-sharing services in the access economy?', 'In the ride-sharing segment, some cities have said drivers must undergo the same scrutiny as taxi or limousine drivers, such as fingerprinting, commercial licensing, training, and background checks.']

['Teacher: What are the challenges that the access economy poses for all levels of government in terms of ethics and regulation?', 'The access economy presents an ethical and regulatory challenge for all levels of government—balancing the need to have at least some rules to protect consumers with the desire to allow competition from new business models.']

['What is the effect of big businesses lobbying for the same regulations on the access economy as the traditional economy?', 'Big businesses are lobbying legislative bodies to apply the same regulation to the access economy as to the traditional economy in an effort to reduce or eliminate the threat of competition.']

['Teacher: How does the lobbying of big businesses for the same regulations on the access economy as the traditional economy impact the competition and innovation in the industry?', 'This, in turn, raises an ethical question for society as a whole.']

['What are some potential consequences of traditional means of raising capital being dominated by big players in terms of competition and innovation in the access economy?', 'Traditional means of raising capital, whether through initial public offerings (IPOs) or venture capital, are often dominated by big players.']

['What is one example of traditional businesses investing in smaller, more nimble platforms in the access economy?', 'In one sign of increasing acceptance of the access economy, traditional businesses are starting to invest in smaller, more nimble, platforms, as the following feature on Oasis Collections demonstrates.']
['Teacher: What specific case exemplifies the challenge entrepreneurs face in obtaining funding?', 'As the Oasis case shows, getting access to funding is often a challenge for entrepreneurs.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the process of an IPO and how it relates to obtaining funding for startups?', 'An IPO is essentially a method of funding a startup by selling its stock to the public at large, a process heavily regulated by the government.']

['Teacher: What role does the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) play in the process of obtaining funding through an IPO?', 'The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) oversees the applicable federal laws, which require the filing of a registration statement and a full disclosure of financial information, along with months of effort by accountants, attorneys, underwriters, and company executives.']

['Teacher: Why do entrepreneurs find the cost and complexity of the IPO process outweighing the benefits when they want to raise a modest amount of capital?', 'The cost and complexity of this process usually outweighs the benefit for entrepreneurs who want to raise a modest amount of capital ($10 million or less).']

['Teacher: What is the argument that the student is making in regards to businesses participating in the U.S. economy?', 'However, as a matter of business ethics, businesses of all sizes should be able to participate fully in the U.S. economy and not be shut out by the “gatekeepers of capital”—the investment banking community.']

['Teacher: How did Congress respond to the issue of businesses being shut out by the investment banking community in the U.S. economy?', 'Thus, in 2012, Congress enacted new legislation called the JOBS (Jumpstart Our Business Startups)']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of the JOBS Act in relation to enabling small businesses to participate in the U.S. economy?', 'Act, which amended U.S. securities laws to enable small businesses to use a variation on a technique known as crowdfunding.']

['Teacher: How does crowdfunding enable small businesses to participate in the U.S. economy?', 'Crowdfunding is already in use as a way to give or lend money to consumers and businesses through web portals such as GoFundMe.']

['Teacher: How does the JOBS Act differ from web portals like GoFundMe in terms of offering sales of securities in a business?', 'But those sites do not offer SEC-compliant sales of securities in a business, as the JOBS Act now permits emerging growth companies (EGCs) seeking capital to do.']

['Teacher: How is the JOBS Act seen as a way of democratizing access to capital for emerging growth companies (EGCs)?', 'This new type of funding should help level the playing field for EGCs; many view it as a way of democratizing access to capital.']
['Teacher: Why do many view the JOBS Act as a way of democratizing access to capital for emerging growth companies (EGCs)?', '64']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an entrepreneurial startup that has successfully utilized the JOBS Act to access capital?', 'One entrepreneurial startup that used this new method successfully is Betabrand, a San Francisco–based retail clothing company that doubles as a crowdfunding platform.']

['What is the advantage of Betabrand operating as both a retail clothing company and a crowdfunding platform?', 'The company lets users of its platform crowdsource clothing concepts and develop prototypes into actual products.']

['Teacher: How long have opportunities for limited-term employment, also known as "gigs," been present in the music and entertainment industry?', 'Opportunities for limited-term employment, sometimes referred to as “gigs,” have existed for decades in the music and entertainment industry; they have even been likened to the widespread small-scale self-employment typical of the pre-union and pre-Industrial eras.65']

['What is one factor that differentiates gig work today from gig work in the past in the music and entertainment industry?', 'What is new about gig work today is that it is often made possible by technology, which frees workers from the need to travel to the employer’s workplace and allows them to work multiple jobs at once.']

['What are some advantages and disadvantages that workers and managers may experience in gig work today compared to traditional employment?', 'This offers workers, and perhaps even managers, a new set of advantages and disadvantages in the employment equation.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what the gig economy is, and how it differs from traditional employment models?', 'The gig economy is an environment in which individuals and businesses contract with independent workers for short-term assignments, engagements, or projects, offering few or no benefits beyond compensation.']

["Teacher: That's a great explanation of a freelancer or contractor. Can you give an example of a short-term assignment or project that someone in the gig economy might be hired for?", 'A freelancer or contractor is a self-employed worker who may work with more than one client but who usually has a contract that covers the details of the job, including compensation.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a situation where a freelancer or contractor might work with more than one client simultaneously?', 'The terms freelancer and contractor are generally used interchangeably.']

['Teacher: How do freelancers and contractors differ in terms of their employment status and the number of companies they work for simultaneously?', 'However, if there is a distinction, it is that a freelancer is almost always self-employed and works for multiple companies, whereas a contractor may or may not be self-employed and may work for only one company at a time (Figure 10.8).']

['Teacher: What are some reasons why individuals in the gig economy might choose to work as freelancers or contractors instead of seeking traditional employment?', 'Some may be happily committed to their independent status; others are involuntarily self-employed while they search for more permanent or full-time positions.']

['Teacher: What are some characteristics of gigs in the gig economy in terms of time and scope?', 'Gigs might be full- or part-time; they might be limited to a specific task or a specific time; and they may serve as the worker’s sole employment or as a “moonlighting” job.']

['What are some potential challenges or drawbacks of working in the gig economy compared to traditional employment models?', 'Regardless of the terminology, the trend toward a gig economy has begun.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what percentage of U.S. workers are predicted to be independent contractors by the year 2020?', 'A recent study by Intuit predicted that by 2020, a surprisingly large 40 percent of U.S. workers would be independent contractors, and according to the Freelancers Union, more than 55 million adults in the United States (that is, 35 percent of the U.S. workforce) already work as independent contractors and/or moonlighters.']

['What is the total percentage of U.S. workers, according to the passage, that will be independent contractors by the year 2020 when considering the predicted 40 percent from the Intuit study and the 35 percent from the Freelancers Union?', '66']

['What is the number of members in the Freelancers Union, as mentioned in the passage?', 'The nature of freelance work leaves some workers searching for the qualities of traditional full-time work, and the Freelancers Union has attempted to provide them by giving its more than 375,000 members a voice through policy advocacy and access to some group benefits.']
['How many members does the Freelancers Union have, as mentioned in the passage?', '67']
['Teacher: What aspect of freelance work hours do many people value?', 'Many people value the flexibility of freelance work hours.']

['What are some examples of how freelance workers can utilize the flexibility of their work hours?', 'They work off premises (frequently at home), make their own schedules, and juggle assignments as needed.']

['Teacher: What are some potential drawbacks that freelance workers face in terms of benefits?', 'However, benefits such as health care and retirement plans are usually unavailable (unless an employment agency sponsors them for those it places in temporary work).']

['What are the options available for freelance workers to obtain health insurance and retirement plans?', 'Freelancers most often must establish their own retirement accounts and obtain their own health insurance through an employed spouse or partner or in a health care insurance exchange.']

['What are some of the concerns raised by Robert B. Reich regarding the gig economy?', 'Robert B. Reich, the former Secretary of Labor and professor at the University of California, Berkeley, says, “This on-demand economy means a work life that is unpredictable, doesn’t pay very well, and is terribly insecure.']
['What are some of the characteristics of work life in the gig economy according to Robert B. Reich?', '”68']

['Teacher: What additional financial responsibility do gig workers have in comparison to employees on the payroll?', 'Unlike employees on the payroll, gig workers must also pay both the employee’s and the employer’s halves of the federal payroll tax (referred to as FICA [Federal Contributions Insurance Act], which funds Social Security and Medicare).']
['What is the purpose of the federal payroll tax that gig workers must pay?', 'This combined tax currently totals 15.3 percent of a freelancer’s earnings.']

['What are the two major components funded by the federal payroll tax?', 'Payroll taxes overall bring in about 24 percent of combined federal, state, and local government revenue, 69 making them the second-largest source of government revenue in the United States after individual federal income taxes.']
['What is the significance of payroll taxes as a source of government revenue in the United States?', 'Here is one of the ethical issues employers face:']

['Teacher: Can you explain how Microsoft was able to save a significant amount of money by hiring contract workers?', 'Microsoft was one of the first companies to save huge amounts of money by hiring contract workers, avoiding paying benefits and payroll taxes and escaping a wide variety of employment and labor laws.']

['Teacher: What were some of the reasons why Microsoft hired contract workers in order to save money?', 'However, the company found itself the object of legal action by both the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and its contract workers on the grounds that a large portion of its contract workforce should have been classified as employees instead.']

['Teacher: What was the stance taken by Microsoft in regards to the employment status of the workers in question?', 'Microsoft ended up conceding the IRS position that the workers were de facto employees.']

['Teacher: How did Microsoft demonstrate that the workers in question were considered de facto employees?', 'It issued W-2s (earnings statements) for the workers’ past two years and paid its share of payroll taxes.']

['Teacher: What were some of the claims made by the workers who sued Microsoft regarding their employment status?', 'It hired some of the workers as well, but others sued for fringe benefits they had been denied as freelancers.']

["What was the outcome of the litigation and appeals regarding the workers' claims against Microsoft?", 'After lengthy litigation and appeals, in 2000, Microsoft agreed to pay thousands of plaintiffs a total of $97 million, the value of stock options they would have received if it had employed them.']
['What was the reason behind Microsoft agreeing to pay a total of $97 million to the plaintiffs?', 'It was the largest settlement ever received by a group of temporary employees.']
["What percentage of Microsoft's current workforce consists of temporary or contract workers?", 'Today, Microsoft has more 110,000 employees, and about 75 percent are temporary or contract workers.']

['Why did Microsoft change their policy regarding fringe benefits for temporary and gig workers?', 'However, Microsoft says it now requires staffing companies to give temporary and gig workers it hires fringe benefits.']
['How many temporary or contract workers does Microsoft currently employ?', '73']
['Teacher: Can you explain the nature of the work relationship between employers and interns in the gig economy?', 'A particularly hazy work relationship exists between employers and interns.']

['Teacher: Why do business or professional-track students seek internships while still in school?', 'Many business or other professional-track students seek—indeed, are encouraged to find—internships while still in school.']

['Teacher: What are some factors that determine whether internships in the gig economy are paid or unpaid, and whether they offer academic credit or not?', 'Sometimes these positions are paid, sometimes not; some carry academic credit and some do not.']

['Teacher: What are some potential benefits and drawbacks of internships in the gig economy in terms of the tasks interns perform and the quality of professional experiences they gain?', 'The tasks interns perform, and therefore the quality of the professional experiences they gain, can vary widely.']
['Teacher: What can be the consequences of interns functioning as a source of unpaid labor in the gig economy?', 'However, many interns clearly function as a source of unpaid labor.']

["Teacher: How can the crossing of ethical boundaries affect the intern's experience in the gig economy?", 'Ethical boundaries are often crossed, even if students are willing to undertake these positions.']

['How do state labor laws play a role in ensuring fair treatment of interns in the gig economy?', 'Although state labor laws governing internships vary, responsible companies will insist that their interns are paid for their services or receive academic credit, or both.']

['Teacher: How have advances in the field of robotics impacted the way work is conducted in various settings, such as medicine?', 'Advances in the field of robotics—a combination of computer science, mechanical and electronics engineering, and science—have meant that machines or related forms of automation now do the work of humans in a wide variety of settings, such as medicine, where robots perform surgeries previously done by the surgeon’s hand.']
['How have advancements in robotics made work more efficient and cost-effective for employers in various industries?', 'Robots have made it easier and cheaper for employers to get work done.']

['Teacher: How has the incorporation of robotics in the workplace affected employment opportunities for humans in certain industries?', 'The downside, however, is that some reasonably well-paying jobs that provided middle-class employment for humans have become the province of machines.']

['Teacher: What did the McKinsey Global Institute study reveal about the potential impact of robotics on jobs?', 'A McKinsey Global Institute study of eight hundred occupations in nearly fifty countries showed that more than 800 million jobs, or 20 percent of the global workforce, could be lost to robotics by the year 2030.74']

['Teacher: What percentage of the global workforce could potentially be lost to robotics by the year 2030, according to the McKinsey Global Institute study?', 'The effects could be even more pronounced in wealthy industrialized nations, such as the United States and Germany, where researchers expect that up to one-third of the workforce will be affected.']

['Teacher: According to the report, how many jobs are estimated to be eliminated in the United States by 2030 due to robotics and automation?', 'By 2030, the report estimates that 39 million to 73 million jobs may be eliminated in the United States.']

['What is the estimated range of job loss in the United States by 2030 due to robotics and automation, according to the report?', 'Given that the level of employment in the United States in mid-2018 is approaching 150 million workers, this potential loss of jobs represents roughly one-quarter to one-half of total current employment (but a smaller share of employment in 2030 because of future population and employment growth).']

['Teacher: What is the concern regarding the future of the workers affected by automation and robotics in the workplace?', 'The big question, then, is what will happen to all these displaced workers.']

['What did the McKinsey report estimate regarding the number of displaced workers who will be able to transfer easily to other industries for employment?', 'The McKinsey report estimates that about twenty million of them will be able to transfer easily to other industries for employment.']

['What are the challenges faced by the remaining displaced workers who are unable to transfer easily to other industries for employment?', 'But this still leaves between twenty million and more than fifty million displaced workers who will need new employment.']

['What are some factors that make occupational retraining less likely for older and geographically immobile workers?', 'Occupational retraining is likely to be a path taken by some, but older workers, as well as geographically immobile workers, are unlikely to opt for such training and may endure job loss for protracted periods.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what does the report predict about the number of jobs requiring less education in developing countries?', 'In developing countries, the report predicts that the number of jobs requiring less education will shrink.']

['Teacher: Why does the report suggest that robotics will have less impact in poorer countries?', 'Furthermore, robotics will have less impact in poorer countries because these nations’ workers are already paid so little that employers will save less on labor costs by automating.']

['Why is India expected to lose only about 9 percent of its jobs to emerging technology by 2030, according to the report?', 'According to the report, for example, by the same date of 2030, India is expected to lose only about 9 percent of its jobs to emerging technology.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, which occupations are expected to be hit hardest by the advancements in robotics and automation?', 'Not surprisingly, the McKinsey report concludes that machine operators, factory workers, and food workers will be hit hardest, because robots can do their jobs more precisely and efficiently.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an occupation mentioned in the passage that is expected to be heavily impacted by advancements in robotics and automation?', '“It’s cheaper to buy a $35,000 robotic arm than it is to hire an employee who’s inefficiently making $15 an hour bagging French fries,” said a former McDonald’s CEO in another article about the consequences of robots in the labor market.']
['Teacher: What is the estimated cost of a robotic arm mentioned in the passage?', '75']

["Teacher: According to the passage, how has automation affected the number of people working at McDonald's since the 1960s?", 'He estimated that automation has already cut the number of people working in a McDonald’s by half since the 1960s and that this trend will continue.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, which other occupations are expected to be heavily impacted by advancements in robotics and automation, apart from machine operators, factory workers, and food workers?', 'Other hard-hit jobs will include mortgage brokers, paralegals, accountants, some office staff, cashiers, toll booth operators, and car and truck drivers.']

['What industry has the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) estimated will lose eighty thousand jobs by 2024 due to advancements in robotics and automation?', 'The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) estimates that eighty thousand fast-food jobs will disappear by 2024.']

['According to the passage, which industry is expected to be heavily impacted by advancements in robotics and automation, potentially putting 7.5 million jobs at risk over the next decade?', 'As growing numbers of retail stores like Walmart, CVS, and McDonald’s provide automated self-checkout options, it has been estimated that 7.5 million retail jobs are at risk over the course of the next decade.']

['What has been estimated to be the number of jobs potentially lost in the early 2020s due to the replacement of automobile and truck drivers by self-driving cars and trucks, according to the passage?', 'Furthermore, it has been estimated that as self-driving cars and trucks replace automobile and truck drivers, five million jobs will be lost in the early 2020s.']

['Teacher: What is typically the level of risk for jobs requiring human interaction to be replaced by automation?', 'Jobs requiring human interaction are typically at low risk for being replaced by automation.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of jobs that require human interaction and are at low risk of being replaced by automation?', 'These include nurses and most physicians, lawyers, teachers, and bartenders, as well as social workers (estimated by the BLS to grow by 19 percent by 2024), hairstylists and cosmetologists, youth sports coaches, and songwriters.']

['Teacher: According to McKinsey, which types of specialized lower-wage jobs are anticipated to be less affected by automation?', 'McKinsey also anticipates that specialized lower-wage jobs like gardening, plumbing, and care work will be less affected by automation.']

['Teacher: What is the potential impact of robotics and automation on the job market, according to the passage?', 'The challenge to the economy, then, will be how to address the prospect of substantial job loss; about twenty million to fifty million people will not be able to easily find new jobs.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, how does the McKinsey report suggest new technology will impact the job market?', 'The McKinsey report notes that new technology, as in the past, will generate new types of jobs.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, why is it unlikely that new technology will help a significant number of people who are facing unemployment?', 'But this is unlikely to help more than a small fraction of those confronting unemployment.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what are some potential challenges that the United States may face as a result of robotics and automation in the workplace?', 'So the United States will likely face some combination of rapidly rising unemployment, an urgent need to retrain twenty million or more workers, and recourse to policies whereby the government serves as an employer of last resort.']

['Teacher: How can robots learn to work without human intervention, and what advantages does this provide over humans?', 'Although some robots are remotely controlled by a human operator or a computer program written by a human, robots can also learn to work without human intervention, and often faster, more efficiently, and more cheaply than humans can.']

['Teacher: What is the branch of science that uses computer algorithms to replicate human intelligent behavior in machines with minimal human intervention?', 'The branch of science that uses computer algorithms to replicate human intelligent behavior by machines with minimal human intervention is called artificial intelligence (AI).']

['Teacher: How might the implementation of artificial intelligence have a particular impact in the fields of banking, financial advising, and the sales and management of securities?', 'Related professions in which the implementation of AI might have particular impact are banking, financial advising, and the sales of securities and managing of stock portfolios.']

['Teacher: How does Accenture define Artificial Intelligence?', 'According to global consulting giant Accenture, AI is “a collection of advanced technologies that allows machines to sense, comprehend, act and learn.”']

['Teacher: According to Accenture, how does AI transform business and compare it to the Industrial Revolution?', 'Accenture contends that AI will be the next great advance in the workplace: “It is set to transform business in ways we have not seen since the Industrial Revolution; fundamentally reinventing how businesses run, compete and thrive.']

['Teacher: How does Accenture describe the impact of implementing AI technologies in business?', 'When implemented holistically, these technologies help improve productivity and lower costs, unlocking more creative jobs and creating new growth opportunities.']

['What did Accenture analyze to assess the impact of AI in various industries?', '”76 Accenture looked at twelve of the world’s most developed countries, which account for more than half of world economic output, to assess the impact of AI in sixteen specific industries.']

['What are some of the potential impacts of AI on the global economy, according to the Accenture report?', 'According to its report, AI has the potential to significantly increase corporate profitability, double rates of economic growth by 2035, increase labor productivity by as much as 40 percent, and boost gross value added by $14 trillion by 2035, based on an almost 40 percent increase in rates of return.']
['What factors did Accenture consider in their analysis of the impact of AI on the global economy?', '77']
['What are some examples of AI technologies that Accenture considers in their analysis of the impact on the global economy?', 'Even news articles have begun to be written by robots.']
['What are some specific examples of industries that Accenture analyzed to assess the impact of AI technologies in their report?', '78']

['Teacher: According to the report by KPMG, what percentage of workplace activities could potentially be automated using existing AI and automation technology?', 'A report by KPMG, another global consulting and accounting firm, indicates that almost 50 percent of the activities people perform in the workplace today could be automated, most often by using AI and automation technology that already exist.']

['What does the report by KPMG indicate about the percentage of workplace activities that could potentially be automated using existing AI and automation technology?', 'The ethical question facing the business community, and all of us on a broader level, is about the type of society in which we all want to live and the role automation will play in it.']

['What other factors should a company consider as it moves towards increased automation, according to the textbook passage?', 'The answer is not simply about efficiency; a company should consider many variables as it moves toward increased automation (Figure 10.9).']

['Teacher: How can a philosophical approach help us determine whether consciousness is necessary to be considered a person in the context of artificial intelligence?', 'Although traditional business ethics can provide us with a starting place to answer such questions, we will also need a philosophical approach, because we also need to decide whether it is necessary to have consciousness to be considered a person.']

['What can a philosophical approach contribute to our understanding of the relationship between consciousness and personhood in the context of artificial intelligence?', 'This issue is further muddied when a human employee largely is tapping AI i to serve customers or clients.']
['Teacher: What aspect of AI and automation is a concern when it comes to liability?', 'Another issue in AI and all forms of automation is liability.']

['What is the purpose of the legislation that lawmakers in Europe have agreed upon regarding robots and their use in relation to liability?', 'According to Reuters News, “lawmakers in Europe have agreed on the need for [European Union]-wide legislation that would regulate robots and their use, including an ethical framework for their development and deployment, as well as the establishment of liability for the actions of robots, including self-driving cars.']
['What are the key elements included in the proposed European Union-wide legislation regarding robots and their use?', '”79']

['What are the legal and ethical questions surrounding the assignment of liability for decisions made by robots and AI?', 'The legal and ethical questions in assigning liability for decisions made by robots and AI are not only fascinating to debate but also an important legal matter society must resolve.']

['What are the potential consequences if liability for decisions made by robots and AI is not properly addressed?', 'The answers will one day directly affect the day-to-day lives of billions of people.']
